content:
Posted: June 11, 2015
												Edit 3: 1100 hours.  GM a server now.  Where'd my life go?  Can't wait for the MMO.Edit2: 700 hours in.  Woah. Edit: 300+ hours in.  Still great.  I'm writing this review because some negative reviews led to me almost not buying it.  I am sincerely glad that I did.  This is the game that I've always wanted.Let me tell you about my first night on LiF.  I logged into an RP server and was almost  instantly greeted by experienced players who were not only willing to help me with every question that I had - but also fillled me in on all the political happenings that were revelant to that evening.  the community, if nothing else, makes this game worth playing.Before I knew it, they outfitted me with a basic sling and some sling ammo and I was marching off to battle.  We arrived through the woods to a small fort in the north which seemed relatively empty - I was disappointed at first: This was it?  Little did we know that the enemy was crouching behind their walls equipped with heavy plated armor and bowmen galore.  After about 20 minutes, two concussions, an arrow through the chest, and general astoundment that I was still alive - I heard that the enemy king was knocked unconscious and his nobles lay dead around him.  Opposed to killing the enemy king, our king inisisted that we let him regain consciousness so he could role play his reaction to the embarassing defeat. While waiting patiently around him, celebrating our clear victory, we were ambushed by almost a dozen of the fallen king's allies from the west.  They streamed in behind us and we fled with our tails behind our legs.  By the time we hobbled back home, bloodied and broken, we had only lost one ally - a clear victory if you ask me! Since then, peace has been negotiated and I've decided to make a pacifist character. - dedicating  my time to building a religious school on top of a mountain.  That's the best part of this game, you can literally do whatever you want.  Want to be a cook? Someone needs you in their guild.  Want to be a warrior? Someone wants you for their realm.  Want to dedicate your time to stacking wood, mining deep into a mountain, watching wheat grow? Well, you're probably going to have to do it anyway. Admittedly, I've only been playing LiF for 15 hours (and that is not much for this game!) but i felt like it was my duty to defend it at least a little bit.  Yes this game is still in development, yes there are many features that haven't been implemented yet.  But I promise you that if you connect with the right people in-game then its not something you will regret contributing to.  There's a steep learning curve but once you get a hang of it everythings really intuitive and well thought out.  I can't wait for final release.

number of helpful: 93 of 108 people (86%) found this review helpful12 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 2, 2015
Early Access Review
								I did not have the option of clicking the "Maybe" option.  A very interesting game but...Keeping in mind that it is just a pre Alpha and very buggy I will limit my comments to gameplay and not stability and such.The world is detailed and beautiful.  The crafting system is deep and satisfying.  As many others have said it can be a bit grindy but not in a bad way.  I felt a real sense of accomplishment when I built my first shack and began setting up my first base of operations.Just as I felt I was getting somewhere a 12 year old punk ran up to me, called my mother a bad name and smacked me with a shovel knocking me out and taking all of my hard won stuff.I tried three different servers over a few weeks and the results were the same.  Just when you feel you are getting somewhere some  rag wearing peasants show up, kill you for sport and take all your stuff, over and over.  Currently, there is no way to protect yourself from being completed looted until you can build a warehouse which takes a significant amount of skill accumulation and materials.  If you don't log in to the server for a few days even those locked items can be freely looted by anyone.The mantra is "Life is Feudal it is supposed to be tough." Well, feudal life was not full of phsycopathic 12 year olds that kill and loot you for sport with no repercussions.  At the moment the 'penalties' for kiling players are largely ineffective and once you acquire something worth having you can expect to be killed/robbed every few hours of gameplay.If you can get on a server when it first starts you will have a huge technology advantage over anyone that comes later and if you can make friends and work together you will be alright.  If you are a latecomer then God help you.  You will be farmed over and over.  The player turnover on every server I have played is very high and the servers quickly become full of empty shacks and half built structures.  No wonder most the servers are dead or go through frequent wipes.I really want to love this game.  There is a ton going for it  but the constant ganking/zerging/ glitching (its in alpha, lots of glitches) make the game very frustrating.    I give the game a  MAYBE because it could be great but it is not at the moment.  And $40 to play test an unfinished game is more than a little too pricey.

content:
Posted: October 17, 2014
Early Access Review
								While this game has tremendous potential, it is nowhere ready to play.  This is not pre-alpha software, this is in the developer unit testing stage.   In a few months of hard development I think this game could be something pretty awesome but at this stage I wouldn't recommend spending your money to assist the deveopers testing their code.  The user interface is clunky at best, the game is completely unforgiving but also gives no assistance to the player, the crafting lines, although intricate, make no sense and EVERYTHING takes way too long.   I continually get a deadlock error that crashes the game and then when I trie to restart it tells me to wait for the game to close.  It takes 5 minutes for the game to close so I can go back in and find I lost my last few actions.  Myself, I can't sit and play a game that tries to mask frustration as entertainment.  For example, wolves that are nearly unkillable to a brand new player, but spawn in your chosen settlement area, When you die you loose everything plus stats and skills.  To top that off you spawn in one of several points around the island and you have to start all over again, trying to make it back to your grave.  When you arrive there you are killed again by the same wolf.  I don't necessarily disagree with the concept of requiring multiple player/crafters to progress.  But to be able to make a steel sickle to harvest (yes i know you can use a flint one) you must have a prospector/miner/smelter/forger of appropriate level.  But you also need to have flux to make steel and to make flux you have to have an alchemist.  But for the alchemist to have a better chance of finding herbs they have to have ... you guessed it ... a steel sickle.Frustrations like this make the game feel like the developers making it are figuring things out as they go.   I don't believe it is unreasonable to expect a developer to have figured out how to fill in a tunnel while they were figuring out how to dig one.I don't recommend this game at this point, however, in 6 to 9 months it might be playable.

content:
Posted: December 26, 2015
												Now let me get one thing straight, this game is not for everyone.  This game is one of the very few honest to god hardcore games I have ever played (You can attribute this to a lot of the negative reviews).  Playing solo is possible on modded servers, but if you want the REAL LiF experience by playing on vanilla, you WILL need a group of people.  This is boderline non-negotionable, this is where a lot of new players make a mistake and thus ruin the experience for themselves.Now to get on to actually reviewing it...Let me start off by critiquing it.  The game does have some honest issues.  Animations are stiff and unnatural (Which normally wouldn't be a huge issue, but this effects combat so I have to point it out), game does have some performance issues, and can be VERY tedius.But onto why I recommend the game, even though the game has it's own set of problems and isn't exactly perfect I still have to give this game a big thumbs up on it's core design philosophy.  If you enjoy a game that punishes you, a game that is unforgiving, but pays out when you work your♥♥♥♥♥off to achieve something....This game feeds this desire better than no other in my experience.  End game isn't achieved with ease.  It takes the combined efforts of you and your group working hard to achieve your goals, which gives you a sense of satisfaction I have never felt in a game before.So in conclusion, if you are the type of player who can't and won't dedicate all their free time to a game, a player who wants things handed to them on a silver platter, or a player who just might not have the time in their lives to play this game.....Please don't buy this game, the game wasn't made for you to begin with.  But if you are like me, someone who enjoys the feeling of putting in hours of work and grinding into a game to accomplish things other players don't have the stomach for, this game is meant for you.

number of helpful: 235 of 325 people (72%) found this review helpful96 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 16, 2015
Early Access Review
								It is very interesting, and if you're dedicated and have the patience for this game, then it's for you. It's a nice medieval game full of crafting and adventuring, although, here's where you'll have to be patient: You could work on getting all of your stuff built and grown for 100 hours and some random people could come over, do something stupid, and then all of a sudden BAM. You're back at hour 1 again. The server could restart too, and BAM. You're literally at hour 1 again. You can't just spend 30 minutes to build stones walls and gates around your little village, no no... It can take about 10 hours to finish of none stop gathering. Oh and is there a little clift that you need to expand to get more land? No problem, as long as you got a couple of weeks of nonstop playing, then you'll get about a couple feet of land out of it for sure! And then there's the fact that you'll most likely be told that the server will restart in a month or so right after you're done. So if you got a lot of time on your hands and you have the patience to start all over again, even if you spent 300 hours on it, then here's a game for you!(sorry, I tried to write it positive, but I wrote this right after a rage quit so.. All I'm saying is that you should maybe wait until the game's finished so there aren't as many server restarts. It's actually a pretty fun game, though.)

Early Access Review
								This is not what is described in the store page.  Directly quoted from store page: “Life is Feudal: Your Own” (LiF:YO) is a 64 player 3km x 3km gameworld that places you in a realistic medieval setting with the ability to host your own private world with your own rules" (You cannot host your game without 3rd party tools. It is not included by default in the game purchase.)In addtion this game has functionality issues with anyone actively using an antivirus. Any game that requires its users to be exposed to viruses and or hack attempts should not be listed anywhere on steam.And to top things off, The MMO aspect of this game is limited to you playing on other peoples servers, Those people have installed MariaDB to operate those servers, and to open your own you will also have to install, and use MariaDB. As there is no way currently to simply open a server from the game itself. Therefore it forces you to use 3rd party tools to do what the content itself is suggesting its capeable of. I do not recommend this game to anyone untill its developers secure it, place the tools required to use its features within the game, and supply the content you pay them to access.

Early Access Review
								First of all I would like to state that in comparing the reviews you should look at how many hours the player has spent. You will notice that most of the negative reviews have less than 100 hours in game. Many of which hardly spent more than 10 hours. A lot of the sudden negativity came since the game when on sale and all the kids bought it.I am not going to lie, to truly unlock the fun in this game you will need to be dedicated. This isn't a game that you play a few hours and be done with it. You also need to make friends or have friends play with you, as this game was not designed to be played solo.Make sure that if you intend to purchase this game that you have a decent computer. It is graphic and so it takes a lot of power.The devs have been very active in releasing updates at least once a month. Sometimes with a minor patch in between because of some new bugs that suddenly appeared. In each update, they keep releasing new features.As to the price of early access. To be honest I have seen a lot of early access games that aren't nearly as playable at this game. In fact I would dare to call this game LATE ALPHA as it has a lot of features already implemented and the devs do a pretty good job at testing before releasing so running into game breaking bugs is rare. I did purchase this game when it was on sale, however now knowing what I know and having played it a lot. I wouldnn't have mind paying $40 for this game.AS I STATED BEFORE. This game isn't for everyone. If you plan to play solo? Don't get it. If you don't plan to be dedicated? Don't get it. If you don't like Medieval time settings? Don't get it.ELSE, GET IT.

number of helpful: 96 of 119 people (81%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 24, 2014
Early Access Review
								Life Is Feudal is a hardcore sandbox MMO('ish) game with great potential. You'll be able to build villages, farms, castles, craft armor and weapons. And not to mention - kill people with those crafted weapons. There's an arsenal of weapons waiting to be crafted, both ranged and melee, but not all of them are implemented yet. The game is still in alpha but you can already get a feeling of what the released game will become. It can sort of be described as a mix between Wurm Online in gameplay, and Rust with it's graphics. There's a couple crucial bugs at this point (for example the server browser freeze) and the servers go down alot, but once you get on a server and start playing there's hardly any bugs bothering you - which is pretty impressive for a alpha build these days. One thing that's important to mention though, is that this is not really a singleplayer/solo game, you would want to gather your friends or join someone else in-game when you set out to build those small, big and gigantic settlements. And you and your friends will need alot of patience in the process of building your land and skills. The world is available for you to shape and form as you like, but like the real world it's going to take lots of time to shape it. I would definetly recommend buying the game for the sandbox fans out there, but there's no rush in doing so. I would guess the most crucial bugs are getting fixed pretty soon though, and when they do Life Is Feudal will bring you tons of hours of fun even in it's alpha stage.

I was inevitably waking up in the morning to check my crops before going to work! In all, I recommend this game to anyone without a life in general.

number of helpful: 155 of 211 people (73%) found this review helpful10 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 8, 2015
Early Access Review
								The game description for Life is Feudal: Your Own refers to itself as a "realistic medieval multiplayer sandbox". Sadly what has been delivered so far is a grind intensive RNG experience in frustration. While I have quite a few criticisms about this early acces game, in this review I will cover my initial thoughts, focus on my attempt at making a torch, and present my conclusion for the game in its current form.The player starts off with a small amount of food and some clothes resembling a cloth sack. From there it is up to you to start living your life any way you want. I was initially surprised by the depth of options presented in the tool tips. I could prospect the ground for ore, strip the bark from a tree, collect sticks, search for edible food on the ground, and much more. I could already picture the village I would build in my mind, bustling with life and promise. How wrong I was. Most actions in Life is Feudal are painfully slow or based on random chance. Each time you search the ground for food the action takes a significant period of time and often turns out no results. If you don’t find food you don’t skill up. If you do find food you gain a skill up, yet seemingly don’t increase your chances of being successful in future searches. My friend and I tried with default settings and with skill gains set to high with the only benefit being additional skills unlocking faster. The only things in the game that are close to realistic are extremely frustrating. Digging a tunnel  or terraforming takes a very long time and requires you to go drop all your dirt in a different location after every 5 or so digging actions.One of the most pointless grinds I have experienced is trying to create a torch. Torches are often one of the first items crafted in a sandbox game and usually one of the most simple. This is not the case in LiF:YO even though only two materials are required. The first material, a stick, is easily gathered from a tree. The second, naptha, is synthesised from herbs. The process is as follows: - Create a sickle,- Search for herbs - Gather the herbs- Discover their properties by combining random herbs- Gather more of the herbs that have the correct properties- Create the napthaWhile this initially doesn’t sound too difficult it is important to note that all the herbs look the same. You are given a random herb each time you gather so you cannot focus on collecting a certain type. Each herb was taking around 10 seconds to pick up and there are also a lot of different herb types which makes the odds of geting a specific one a lot worse. Due to poor inventory management/UI it takes a long time to combine herbs to discover what properties they have. After devoting more than half an hour to nothing but gathering and combining herbs I had not found the correct ones to make torches. In comparison It was far easier to build a house.To conclude, my biggest problem with LiF:YO is that the developers seem to equate realism with random chance. If the game were more realistic a player would be able to identify herbs by sight before gathering them. Players would be able to locate berries and mushrooms visually instead of having to click on a tile hoping for the RNG gods to award them something to eat. While the idea of the game has merit and the future of the game does not look entirely grim it is my hope that the developers shift a focus more towards something that is more user friendly and gives rewards based on work and skill rather than random chance.

number of helpful: 67 of 78 people (86%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 4, 2015
												First things first. The game has a very steep learning curve. Much of it does not make sense at the outset. It is not intuitive and you will not enjoy the time you lose learning hard lessons - for example, that you need to figure out how to make a primitive hammer in order to make a blacksmiths hammer to make other things - oh, and that same hammer is sitting next to the forge thingee but that's just stickering, you can't use it.. Oh - and you can't even use the forge until you learn how to mine, etc.Looking at the negative reviews, it looks like most of those people did not get past this point. If you want fun and whimsical out of the box then stop reading now. If you're looking for something gritty and unique, keep reading.Once you are past the learning curve and get confident with the interface, it really opens up. There's no AI enemies. Just people. People will be friend or foe based on how you treat them and how you respond to their treatment. People will lie and cheat, People will steal from you and take your hard work. People will break or ignore the rules to shortcut themselves at others expense. People will bully you and exploit weakness. People will also believe in you. You will meet people. You will trust them and in turn they will trust you. You will build bonds and with those bonds grind out amazing things that you never thought possible. You will be there for them and they will be there for you. You will get addicted. You will find yourself staying up way too late or getting up way to early to care for what you've made in some foolish video game you almost didn't figure out. You will be afraid. Someone you do not know will suddenly approach you and your heart will race as you struggle to figure out what to do. Those that make is this far are all experts - skill counts for little advantage and all that will matter is how you've treated friend and foe. It's just like life; it's what you make it. Game on.  -= Update 1.1.2017 =-I've noticed a lot of people spouting misinformation about the MMO version (for example, you have to buy it again) or complaining about how things have changed or that it was so much better before. It's unfortunate that people don't take the time to understand early access - that there will be bugs, that there will be changes.. I also understand that, to run hundreds of servers it takes money to launch, and three years in that can be hard to come by. I believe the team is very much trying to do right by the game still. As for the MMO - Well. I've played it - and it's awesome. Everything is harder. The terrain, the animals, the skill tree.. Finally a game where we don't all just get a trophy for showing up.

Early Access Review
								Only play this game if you've got alot of time on your hands that you're willing to commit to it. it takes a good long time to do anything, but for this type of game that isn't necessarily bad. There is an actual feeling of acomplishment when you and your group finish something that you had to put alot of effort into. Things aren't exactly clear as to what you need or what you need to do, but the community (at least what i saw of it) is almost always willing to help you figure things out. Which is more than i can say for alot of survival game communitys *cough* rust *cough cough.* If you're going into it alone don't be afraid to ask to join groups. they won't always accept you, but the ones that do are really the ones you want to group with anyway. Anyway, yes the game is enjoyable, don't go into it thinking "I'll just play it every once in awhile," and make sure to find yourself a good group. Do these few things and this game is worth the time really.

												My first life, in Life is Feudal: Your Own(My life was feudal, it was my own)Spawned.Walked a bit.Ate cookies.Saw a guild in global chat, decided to look for them in the South.Met up with a wanderer called Thorbjorn, travelled with him to The South.We got hungry and tried hunting a boar.It rekt us, and I fell into a hole with spikes and glitched into a jumping animation.Relogged.We decided not to hunt the boar.Mysterious man on horseback appeared. He was silent.Then another appeared. He started rambling and calling us mortals.His name was Reaper. He was asked me if I was strong, I said yes. We dueled and I died.Reaper said return to him for gifts.I returned and found my companion.Reaper gave us horses, armour, farming tools, weapons and food.Me and Thorbjorn made a camp not too far from Reaper's fortress.We got raided by The Kingdom of the North. All our supplies....gone....We told Reaper's gang, they were on our side. Then we told the Kingdom of the South.The South let us join, then we got free houses and I became a farmer.This was my first time playing LiF and it was quite the adventure.A great RPing game, with good community, and survival aspects.If you don't mind lots and lots of hardwork, it the best medieval survival game on the market.

Posted: March 1
												TLDR: Get a guild or a big group of friends. You can't play this solo. There are some things in this game that I both hate and love. I really don't know should I actually recommend or not recommend this game, I wish Steam had a neutral thumb. First off, don't buy this game if you aren't capable of doing these:- Getting some friends to this game also- Finding company to play with- Time. - Time and more of your time.- Looking for some kick♥♥♥♥♥medieval combat but with open world & crafting (you have to spend hundreds of hours before you get armors & weapons first)- PvP (to get any combat gear, yup, grind hundreds of hours, others who have done this before you on a non-wiped server will just♥♥♥♥♥♥you)It's for a specific audience. I loved the game for the first 40 hours with my friend until we noticed we were living on this game AND to actually get anywhere you have to live on this game and micromanage like hell. Take care of your stable, take care of your farm, take care of everything. It's truly immersive and when you get somewhere, you feel good that you actually made something but holy♥♥♥♥♥♥is the GRIND REAL!!! To get contruction to 90 is hell. Everything you do in this game takes ♥♥♥♥ing loads of time. It's one of the most grindiest games actually I have ever witnessed.Haven't visited your coop in two days? Chickens are dead, your progress is gone with animal lore skill. Wanna make linen rope? Chickens died, you have to get more of them and you need 30 skill of animal lore to get the skill so you can make linen rope, one of the most needed items in the game. Actually it's not just linen rope, everything, get to 30 skill, unlock another skill, grind it to 30, oh wait, you need that too from skill #1, grind it to 90 so you can unlock 2 more skills.IT'S SO GRINDY!Other aspects? The graphics are good and the world is beautiful too. The world is immersive and you feel like you're living in a world.  Pros? It's immersive. It's authentic. You get rewarded from your hard work if you have the patience. Terraforming is an awesome feature. I hope they fix some of the grindy aspects at the MMO, actually make it so you can progress without having to dedicate your life to this game.Rating:Too hardcore for me, maybe coming back at some point/10

content:
Posted: July 12, 2015
Early Access Review
								First, I would like to say that you will either love or hate this game, and you will know it within the first few hours of playing. I dont see anybody that just sort of plays this game here and there for fun. This game simply does not work that way. However, I will dissagree with other reviews in regards to playing alone. I play alone, and have my own little medieval farm tucked away surrounded by forest. It took me many many hours to get to that point, and the server does not skill cap anything, so people can level up as much as they want. Those types of servers, one can go solo and thrive. With that little background, the game is for the most part realistic. Almost everything in this game is time consuming, and Im not going to lie... perhaps a little too time consuming. I have a small hut, back yard garden with wattle fence surrounding it, and that literally took me three days to build. However, during the time of construction, I had to stop and go looking for food because the last thing you want to do in this game is die. So what is the goal of this game? What ever you want it to be. My goal was to simulate a nice little medieval farm, tend to it, improve it... etc. I am very pround of what I have built, and this game has some lasting rewards. Some may strive for control, the amount of weapons and possibilites in this game is ridiculously huge thus allowing them to control by force is neccessary. However, you will not really find players like Reign of Kings, just running around killing people. You dont do that in this game because their is just too much to lose, too much progress, and too much hard work being put in by people. With that being said, the community is awesome, very mature, and helpful. Buy this game if you......1. Want realistic medival simulator2. Are a dedicated player 3. Willing to actually learn the game, because the learning curve is huge!Do not buy this game if you...1. Are a casual PC gamer2. Think progress in Rust, or Reign of Kings is too slow3.  Cant deal with a little bit of bugs, not game breaking... but complete lack of understanding for early access games.

number of helpful: 139 of 194 people (72%) found this review helpful8 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 16, 2015
Early Access Review
								This is an Early Access title at the time of writing this review.::TL/DR Version::Single (solo) players - Game is overpriced and not worth the purchase. Development is too focused on the MMO that is being built from this funding project.Multiplayer/Co-op Players - Game is still overpriced, but somewhat enjoyable with the right server and players.:: The LONG Version ::After a little more than 50 hours of playing this game, I have to honestly reject recommending this game. The videos and screenshots look great and I could not help but be very hopeful about this game. While that hope is still there for the potental of Life is Feudal and most of it's features, it has dwindled very rapidly. The fact that this game makes you work for everything, instead of just handing you everything like Minecraft, is the strongest reason why I was so interested in playing. With that said, this game feels more like an unenjoyable job than an enjoyable game at the time of this review. Life is Feudal: Your Own gives the impression of being the fantastic single-player little brother to the anticpated MMO version to be released later. I bought into the dream, and watched it crumble as soon as I tore into the wrapper. There is no single player experience to this game. Er, wait, what? Yes, you heard that correctly. The only way a person can play this game and enjoy it, or progress, is by using boosted server settings (skill rate, tunnelling rate, skill point limit) and GM commands. I tried this route, and the game had no enjoyment for me because I didn't feel that I had accomplished anything on my own, regardless of having a house and some walls. I started a second server, to play solo, with all default settings and found no enjoyment for a multitude of reasons. Life is Feudal: Your Own has no NPCs, other than wildlife. For a solo player, this makes building walls and gates for your settlements pointless. And while there are the combat skills, they are pointless against wildlife. I found myself killed by a boar several times because I was lacking any combat skills to be able to land a hit on them with melee or ranged weapons. Utilizing the GM commands, I gave myself some armor and boosted my skills, only to still die after just a few hits (usually 3-4). If there is no difference is survivability with armor, and no increased chance to hit with better skills, then what is the reason for attempting combat with wildlife? I guess the only thing left is to just be a Lumberjack and a Farmer, right? I will say that the Lumberjack role is about the only role that seemed to work for me. You can strip trees of their branches and bark, and even a few saplings. Sure you can cut down those trees, and even turn them into boards and building logs. However, you can't do anything with it without the supporting crafting skills. Most everything requires some form of metal component to build, so you also need those supporting skills. Suddenly, the skill cap is looking smaller and smaller. Farming is a mixed bag of ideas. The system to find random plants (crops) works to help you find food that you can cook on a campfire to keep you alive or plant to start your crops. That part of the farming skill system works great, but also leads into my issues with the server side of the game.The problems that do not work for me as a solo player, is the fact that the server has to run almost 24-hours of real time before you are able to harvest those crops that you have planted. Planted trees also require the server to run for an extremely long time period of real time before they have grown enough to be of any real use for the player. The server side is a mixed bag of confusion. The systems used to determine decay and time of day (in-game) will progress between the time a server is shutdown to when it is restarted. This takes place even if the server settings for decay are set to 0 (disabled). A person that is not able to play everyday, like myself, will find this to be quite annoying. Monuments that are used to protect your items from decaying, are not able to be managed while they are damaged. (See Update Note 1) If the monument reaches the end of it's hitpoints before the server is restarted, then it will be deleted upon server restart. This is the same with any other items (dropped items, campfires, snares, etc.) that are not protected or held by the player. Systems such as the growth of crops and the growth of tamed animals will not progress or update while the server is offline. It must be ran non-stop for these to progress. The slightest amount of items will overburden your character to the point you can not pick up anything, or even swap equipment. While there are storage options in the game, the storage limitations on the smaller, yet easier to craft items make them almost pointless. The larger storage options are impossible to obtain for a solo player, due to their increased material requirements, skill levels to craft, and the rate of decay for the numerous dropped items while collecting the other components. This basically adds up to the single player being a lot of the "let the game run, while I go play something else" type of scenerio. For these reasons, I have to warn all players looking for a single player experience to avoid this title at this time. Especially for the overpriced tag of $40 USD.I found the multiplayer side of this game to be just as much work, with a lot more frustrations. I tried several public servers and found the combat against other players to be just as annoying and unbalanced as my single player experience against boars. There is also the inability to progress on public servers (in my experience) because you are constantly being murdered and robbed for usually crappy primative tools, or the log on your back. Talking to other players, I was bothered by the need to have scheduled shifts between players to guard their settlements from being attacked while others were offline.Overall, this game made me feel like an over-worked, under-appreciated, non-paid employee that wished I had never even tried. If there was an option of getting my money back on this game, then I would love to use it. WIth the experience that I've had with this game so far, I don't think I will ever re-consider Life is Feudal: YO or the MMO in the future.UPDATE NOTE 1:--- Update 0.3.2.6 added craftable repair kits that can be used to repair damage cause by players and decay.

content:
Posted: May 1, 2015
Early Access Review
								First off let me say that I LOVE THIS GAME!!!!This is probably the most fun sandbox game I've played, ever. I initially opted to start solo on my own locked instance; just to learn the ropes, learn the UI and the crafting. I figured that would allow me to survive more easily when I moved to a PVP server. I expected it to be a learning experience, not a fun one. Actually it turned out to be so much fun that I got all carried away in the crafting and forgot to check out the multiplayer experience.I've now restarted anew 3 times, as the server I settled on recently migrated. And one of my favorite things about this game is the leveling system. For one thing it makes it easy to start anew; no more spending an entire month of long grinding hours just to get back to level x at which you can finally do fun stuff. Nope, in this game you can train the basic combat skills in minutes and start to have fun. You can train your crafting skills in a couple days and hit the ground running on building. That is just great. The game is barely half way done and already it offers and amazingly rich, deep and compelling experience. It sucks you in, but in the same time it allows short gaming sessions (which few MMOs do). So even if you only have 30 minutes to play you always have something you can do. The Devs are very passionate about the game and are very active; they offer regular updates and even provide a public roadmap showing their progress on upcoming features.I've fallen head over heels for this game, it has destroyed my Battlefield 4 career. :D

number of helpful: 59 of 71 people (83%) found this review helpful54 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 30, 2016
												Life is Feudal: Your Own Review 8.5/10I bought this game last week as I wanted to play with friends, and had just tried ESO and it was not scratching my itch. I watched some review videos, and LIF caught my eye as something I would be into –after all, who doesn’t want to be a peasant and eek out an existence in a bleak wilderness setting? As long as my aspirations of Knighthood remained viable, there should be reason for optimism…or so I told myself.I hit the server with my buddy, Drek Stonebrow, and after several futile attempts to find each other, we finally hooked up –two disheveled figures in rags, hugging each other atop a bluff as night settled in. We marched to a location Drek had noticed on his way to me, and we settled in under the stars with our newly fashioned sleeping mats.On the first day we spent several (Real) hours crafting primitive tools and experimenting with them. Yup this new shovel will lower and raise the terrain…oh wow, did I just spend 2 hours digging a ditch for the fun of it? Yes. That only took the crafting of five shovels.  Hey, how about this axe? It does chop down trees…oops, broke that too. Oh well no worries, I’ll quickly break off a few branches from this nearby oak, rustle up some plant fibers, tie it all in to this shapely piece of flint I discovered, and voila, I’ll have a new axe to play with. And although I know these activities aren’t for everyone, I found it thoroughly enjoyable.Over the next few days we hammered out several long sessions where we:1. Learned to fish and hunt2.  Built ourselves peasant hovels3. Gathered stone to pave a small road4. Raided our neighbors for their goods at night5. Whistled peasant tunes and looked at our feet as a Knight in full plate came to stare down upon us from his mount and enquired about recent robberies6. Created a guild and managed to talk three other friends into purchasing the game so that we could keep the Knight off our backs (Shout out to: Thulgar, Moe Poon, and Fung U)7. Booted one of our friends from our guild for turning on us -he now has his own property. We don’t ask how he keeps the Knight away, and we don’t want to know …on a side note we should have been suspicious with a name like Fung U8. Chopped wood, dragged wood , and piled wood for 20hrs (real …agonizing…hours). The pain of this was offset by the discovery of each craftable item we produced. Oh the look of pride on Drek’s face when he finally had his forge up and running. And then it all came to a crash two days ago with the release of a new update. For whatever reason, the server we were playing on hasn’t been online since. Fung and I tried to entertain ourselves by creating new characters and raiding on several other servers, but after numerous bans, we are left scratching our heads and feeling like we have been ousted from our homeland.With nothing to do but start on a new server (Or create our own) we are left with the impression that Life is indeed futile. Despite the somewhat bad taste in our mouths, Drek remains optimistic as he claps me on the back and says:  “Damned if I am giving up. Somewhere out there, a knight is looking for a peasant to bully.”UPDATE:We made our own server. Find us at 2NerdsRaging

content:
Posted: September 9, 2016
												After 224 hours of playing this game, running a server, and checking up on it from time to time, I can honestly say that I do not recommend this game. While it is unique in that it has a medieval theme amongst a sea of zombie survival shooters, it is executed poorly. Essentially, this will more than likely never be a finished, final product. Rather this is a testing/launch base for a F2P MMO with microtransactions. As the months have gone on, it's become far more evident that they are abandoning the "Your Own" model in favor for yet another subpar MMO. The loss of potential for this game saddens me, because what is actually here is pretty good, the crafting is deep, the combat unique (Buggy and clunky, but fun nonetheless.), decent looking character creation with the option of either gender, this COULD have been amazing, had they set their sights on completing this project before moving onto their MMO. If you're not a fan of PVP, then really, I hope you like crafting shovels and digging, or hunting terrible animal AI over and over again. In the beginning they had promised some sort of primitive mob for you to fight, or some kind of NPC enemies, but they seem to have decided to not break off from that, to once again, save it for the upcoming MMO. Now, please understand that I am not saying that the MMO is going to be bad or terrible, I cannot judge the MMO as I have not, nor have I any interest in playing it, this is my review of the LiF: YO experience, one that I am disappointed in.Also, don't judge this game based on the epic trailer narrated by Sean Bean...there are no monsters to fight.

Early Access Review
								Bearing in mind this is infact an alpha (which many gamers are forgetting nowadays means there will be bugs and issues).This is a really fun and addicting crafting/survival game. It relies on teamwork to go beyond having a small hutt in a forest. You need a cook, a miner, a blacksmith, lumberjack, farmer, etc. You can't be all at once, so you actually need to be a part of a group to get anywhere. You can build everything from a tiny wooden hut, to a spawling castle with its own village inside massive stone walls.Playable? Yes. Though there are optimization issues. FPS isn't amazing unless you turn your settings way down.Enjoyable? Definitely. This is an amazing concept for a survival game. Every update adds more features to the game to make it more addicting.Total recomendation: Great for survival/crafting game lovers. Has more realism to it than most. There are many bugs and missing features, but this is also nowhere near being released, and updates come frequently enough to keep you interested.

content:
Posted: November 27, 2016
												There are a lot of negative reviews for this game, and I think a lot of them are a bit unfair. This game is not for everyone. If you're expecting 24/7 action, don't bother. This game requires a lot of grinding, however it's extremely rewarding once you've finished the grind.The main tip i'd give people who are looking to buy the game or players struggling with the game is to focus on finding a good group you feel comfortable in. This game revolves around communal play, and spending 10 hours bantering on voice chat while you grind is a lot more interesting than spending 10 hours grinding alone in silence. Putting the grinding aside, the combat is quite interesting, though not particularly good. The game is plagued with poor performance because the developers spend the majority of their manpower on their mmo.However, where this game truly shines is in it's rp community. You'll see it all, political betrayal, forced marriages, prostitution, alliances, coalitions, kingdoms, bandits. There really are no limits to what you can do with Rp. I began playing the game without ever really being aware of the Rp aspect of it and by coincidence ended up on an rp server, and i suppose the amount of hours i have on the game can attest to how great it's been. All my hours have been on the same server, Rpclif.

content:
Posted: August 29, 2015
Early Access Review
								Totally under rated being "mixed" reviews.This is probably the most balanced sandbox builder I've played to date.Your skill tree is complex without being OP as you don't just gain ridiculous typical MMO quality stats. For example, if you want to build something, you need to first begin with forestry. To get your forestry levelled up you need to inspect trees/take bark/branches from them (which you can use along with stone you gather from terraforming to make tools) and then when your forestry is high enough you unlock logging which allows you to begin on chopping down trees. This leads to carpentry which of course allows you then to begin preparing the logs properly for contructing your buildings by sawing out the necessary boards of different sizes. You or someone else is also required to have the knowledge of forging which is about the 5th skill in the mining skill set, so that you can make nails. And as for terraforming, this is no minecraft "punch punch punch" goodbye dirt. No siree, this requires effort and time, and a lot of trips back to the edge of your mine shaft to dump countless amounts of dirt from your inventory weighing you down onto a pile, just as you would if you were digging in real life. While it is complex and a grind, it's a fun grind that feels realistic and is actually very fun and addictive, unlike the typical sandbox builders where you just gather 200 wood for a basic shack and build it in no time at all. What makes it even better is how difficult it is to construct the needed weapons to destroy these buildings. So all in all a very balanced game thus far.As for combat, for those of you who know war of the roses/mount and blade, this is very similar, directional attacks with realistic physics (body swinging into attacks to make them do more damage) and different kinds of damage given/taken by different weapons/armor (piercing, blunt, slashing etc)This is only the testing game too, and only small occassional updates are coming through as the developers are working on the main mmo coming out next year that will feature many more things including a karma/alignment system for your actions. More info can be found at the bottom of this page http://lifeisfeudal.com/LiFYO#compare

content:
Posted: May 15, 2016
												***This will be my first review on any game from Steam/in general, so if I miss anything out, please forgive.***I only have 60 hours or so of play-time recorded, but around 55 hours of those 60, I had been playing Life Is Feudal with people I never even gamed with before. By this, I simply mean that while at first not knowing/understanding much, I came across one person, then a couple more people, etc, until eventually (my favorite moments in the game) this group of ours had owned a small farming/fishing/trade village. Needless to say, the very first 6 hours or so of game-time was quite unfamiliar and I had a lot of help. But from that point on, I realize now that there are probably slim-to-none other games that can replicate what Life Is Feudal is about. What do I mean? How can I say that (with only just one review/little experience)?This game boils down to having patience and having the ability to take in advice/learn from others. If you have no patience or have no interest in taking advice or learning from others, you won't enjoy this game to its fullest potential!The grind can be offsetting, the in-depth complex skilltrees can be confusing, but the learning and level of detail put into this game... I have not found one in this similar era/style, to be better. And I am still looking till this day for one to top it.You start off with basic character customization. Couple different race options, hair-styles, facial hair; you get the jist. From then, you either have no idea what to put what points into which stat/skill, or looked up a general guide and understand. If you didn't, which I didn't (at first), you'll then load into the game and be off to your new 'life'.The very first thing I can say that differs from most games: the controls. The way in which you switch in and out of different modes. Then, the way in which you interact with your environment. Not sure since when, but luckily now, you can Mass Produce things, which makes (incoming tip) gathering something such as Plant Fiber, so much easier. Now, you can follow the Tutorial, which guides you to making Primitive Tools. There are a plethora of them, each correlating with different crafts/skills. Once you have the Primitive Tools, you start to attempt to build things. You need resources of different types, in order to construct certain things. So you branch out to other skilltrees. Long story short, there is so much to do in this game that you could sit for 12 hours straight on this and not realize how long it's been!What I will not do is list pros/cons. I feel this game has enough positives in its arsenal to warrant at least a try. Hell, I was on a certain server or two, got really far in my skilltrees, then said server or two either would wipe their servers, or would be inactive/shutdown for a bit of time. I just recently got my gaming-motivation back and not even a few days later, I reinstalled this game and might even log back in after completing this review.Will you enjoy it? I have no damn clue. I think if you have a reasonable amount of time, a reasonable amount of patience and learning skills.. I *think* this game deserves a shot on your computer. Try it. I would also suggest something else, in terms of how you can get the game, but I will not say on this review (message me 'G). What I do think, though, is that if you are a person who enjoys a challenge; maybe even possess a taste for Medieval Realism, then I am confident you will enjoy this game as much as I have for my not-so-lengthy time spending (60 hours, to me, is quite a bit >.<)...Feel free to add me on Steam if you need any advice or help, I'll gladly play as well if time permits.Hope this review helped, even a little! Now get out there, ya 'Bloody Peasant!

I like the premise fo the game and it has potential, but the game needs a lot of work in playability for me to continue playing.  At the moment I truely feel I just wasted $40.

content:
Posted: November 24, 2015
												Short and sweet: If you like realistic sims (specifically Medieval era here, hence the name) than this is your game.  I have never enjoyed a crafting/survival game more than this particular gem, to include all of the Rust/Reign of Kings clones out there (which are fun as well in short spurts). The learning curve can be relatively steep, and the time investment required to get a fully functioning village or even a sword can be tremendous, but it's an utter blast if you don't mind the challenge. Mind you, the developers did a weird turn and released a somewhat different version of the game than what we had been testing throughout Alpha, so some repetitive glitches have been reintroduced. I'd say overall the Devs made a really poor decision by calling this a "released" product, and I fear that the hopes of their MMO and sales will suffer as a result. Nevertheless they're chipping away at the bugs currently, and I cannot recommend this game enough for the older generations out there that want a gritty, realistic experience.  Kids should probably stay away. Not enough graphical prowess, steep skill/combat curve, and no magical doodads to fiddle with.

number of helpful: 59 of 77 people (77%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 25, 2015
Early Access Review
								I've played this game enough now that I feel comfortable to put my seal of approval on it!It has a lot of potential, and I can't wait to see how it turns out as an MMO. Sure it's grindy, but at least the grind makes sense. You aren't grinding "XP points" or stupid tings like "pixie medals" to spend at vendors like in other RPG's. In fact, there are no vendors! EVERYTHING is player run and all work is done by hand. You want make 30 swords for your group of friends? Better invest in smithing related skills and buildings and go out and mine and/or barter for the metal ores. The map is 100% terraformable. Everything down to the grains of sand you walk on can be harvested and has a possible industrial use. The game is still in development, so combat is a bit wonky and it currently lacks critical things like horses and siege mechanics. But the player skirmishes and the building aspect are already a lot of fun.A few things that annoyed me:- Claims system: I won't go into detail here, but the forum is full of it. This mechanic needs a lot of work!- Terraforming: This is the least enjoyable part of the game. If you are a builder you will spend a lot of time leveling the ground. There is an observer mode, but this cannot be active during the actual digging. Also, mining leaves very ugly unrealistic "minecraft style" block shaped holes in the terrain and locks those cells for future terraforming. So digging tunnels is a perfect griefing tactic which permanently ruins someone's village/castle.- No NPC's other than wild animals. I wish we could let NPC's reduce some of the mindnumbing tasks like terraforming or to man the walls of your keep. What human player wants to spend their gametime playing guard on a watchtower? It would also make the villages feel a lot more alive.- Strange skill requirements: I understand the 600 skillpoint cap. Every society needs specialists if it wants to be more than a tribe of mud people. However what I don't understand is why I need to become a farmer and progress through several other professions in the same "line" before I can become a tailor. Especially when there are such harsh limits on the amount of skillpoints I'd like to have more precise control over how I invest them. I also don't understand why I need to train a skill to even equip a sword I looted off a corpse. Why can't I just be far less effective at using said sword  without formal training? That would make it a lot more realistic.I've already put hundreds of hours into this game, and I'm hoping to continue to add many more in the future!

number of helpful: 49 of 61 people (80%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 12, 2015
Early Access Review
								First let's get this out of the way: This game takes time and is quite a slow paced game. And expecting otherwise and getting this game will be entirely on you, because it's very much said to be right off the bat :PNow, with that said, we can talk about the game itself. I think this game is at a great start for early development, and the potential is phenominal. I've easily no lifed this game (No really... I got the achievment and everything.) and am still looking forward to playing more. It mixes RPG and Sandbox surprisingly well, making them both interdependent on one another. You need to level skills to build, and you need to build to level skills. Then there's the fact that other than using prefab structures, you get to design everything else to your liking. You decide how big or small your settlement or even castle will be, given if you're willing to put the time and effort into finishing it. This game won't be for those who like to get right in on the action, and if that's your cup of tea, I don't advise expecting it to be so. Though I will still suggest it, because you never know. This game makes you feel like it's the simulator that it is. If I could change anything about this game, it would be the green bar. But I'd change it to something they already plan to replace it with, metagames; something to keep you occupied and alert instead of staring blankly at a loading bar. There are a few bugs here and there, though I can't remember examples since I haven't played in a while, but I know there was. And that's to be expected, it's early alpha. VERY EARLY. It really is obnoxious to see how many kiddies whine about bugs or the fact that it's not done in some areas, because it's exactly that; early alpha development. It's like wanting a diamond out of graphite; It's not, but in time it can be. But I digress, this game is still fairly polished compared to other alphas, some even that are near beta. You will also find this game is NOT to be played alone, for extended periods of time. While it can be done, it's soon apparent that you'll need friends to aide you in your endeavours. So, get your guild/steam group/clan ready and get to work!So concluding my review, I'll rate it on categories:Bugs(Expected to change as it's developed): (few crashes, nothing else that's game breaking) 7/10Graphics(doesnt effect overall rating, but some people play for graphics): 10/10 (If you have the rig to support the graphics on max)Optimization: 8/10Replayablility: 9/10NewUserFriendliness: (Not going to lie, this game requires out of game sources to actually get the ball rolling.) 5/10Potential: 10/10Update Frequency: 7/10Overall Rating: 8/10*EDIT: So I forgot to take into account the sheer price of the game. If this is your kind of game, it will be worth every penny spent. However, if you don't know what you're getting into and don't like it, then you may find you're out $40.

												It's a very grindy co-op sandbox. Where Grindy just doesnt really do any justice as to explaining how grindy the grind actually is. It's a kind of rewarding grind though.. in a Stockholm Syndrome sort of way.       "Oh! It gave me a point! It likes me..."You'll also need to con at the very least, 4-5 friends into playing with you for around 20+ hours before you'll have almost gotten to a point where you feel like you may be able to accomplish something soon... maybe. The only way to get anywhere solo, you would need to run your own server and then cheat. I saw in another review, "The only thing that comes easy in this game is Death" and that is the truth!It's not ready, yet. Which pisses me off, because I really want to play this game! I played a fair bit when it first came out and decided to put it down for awhile due to bugs/burnout. I've come back again after a year or so and I can tell there's been some progress but it's still too buggy for me. I'm 20+ hours back into the game and I've found a bug that basically has the entire group stuck in limbo on the cusp of getting metal tools for the first time... and it's not going to happen. So we're going to put it back in the oven for another year. Expect an update in 2018... fingers crossed.

content:
Posted: January 10, 2016
												Day one and a farmer stopped me and pointed me to the village of Applewood where the inhabitants offered food and clothing in return for labour. Void of anything of worth, I took her advice and made my way to where a builder was hard at work, building a great wall around the village. We greeted each other and soon I was invited to join the village.---Day five and we are tracking down a group of bandits. My sword skills are undeveloped due to helping finish the wall yet I join my new brothers in the hunt until we corner our heavily armed quarry as they leave a major settlement. The stand off is tense, neither side wishing to draw first for fear of the reprisals. The sound of steel rings out as a sword is drawn, the melee is one of chaos, tactics go out of the window. My sword feels feeble, my bare chest exposed and my iron clad adversary unstoppable. I manage a glancing blow on his left side, a more meaningful one to his right but his two handed axe is unrelenting, it's great arc of death formidable and I am hewn to the ground.10/10 would draw my sword again.Island of Elli is in my opinion the best RP server (199.102.79.66:22685) Heavy RP with no tolerance for griefers. Come join us

Early Access Review
								I'm in a valley. It's dark.. possibly the middle of the night? I've been digging all day. I'm trying to stop the dirt from falling in to my man made hole. Creating a shelter is difficult. My hole is half complete. I light my camp fire with the little resources I have left, take a swig of water and get back to work. I'm pulling out my pickaxe when all of a sudden I hear a snap of a twig behind me. Before I can turn around, a man wielding a large club has knocked me out cold from behind. I collapse in to my hole and he starts pouring dirt over in to my shallow grave. When he has packed the dirt solid, he sits on top of my grave and feasts on a chicken leg that he cooked over my camp fire.. and all the while I'm wondering, devs.. where is the 'Gary' DLC? 9.5/10 No game is perfect.

number of helpful: 31 of 34 people (91%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 11, 2016
												Welcome to Work Simulator: 2016That is what this game.  Work.  You work at getting raw materials.  You work at building structures.  You live.  In a medieval setting and as someone who has done medieval re-enactment I can say LIF isn't terribly far off the mark duplicating life in that era.  The game itself is certainly picking up speed as the dev team seems to be working harder and harder on the game.  Updates are becoming more frequent and issues such as the blinking sky and invisible trees seem to be dealt with.  At least as of this date.  The graphics are excellent.  Even on my potato computer the visuals are lovely and my fps stays stable around the 20 mark.I know for many of you a game must be 60 fps but games in early access rarely come close to that mark.  ARK did not see an improvement in fps until late in its dev cycle.  Just as an example   Also, this is a very social game.  Playing it alone or on a dead server will bore you to death.   Unless you are truly dedicated.  A few tips for new players:1. There is no rush to settle down.  You can live nomadically for quite some time living off of wild apples from apple trees.2. When you do decide to settle down look for an area that is fairly flat and is reasonably close to stone, clay, iron and water.3. While a variety of crops are nice, the two most important are wheat and flax.  Wheat for taming animals and flax to make clothing and rope with.4. Plan your settlement in advance and get your claim monument up as fast as possible.

number of helpful: 112 of 168 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 26, 2014
Early Access Review
								LIF:YO - my first review after 18 hours gameplay...look carefully => it's an early access, alpha...this means bugs, missing content, crashes, compatibility issues, server wipes etc...but for an alpha, the game is pretty good developed (compared to other alpha games out there).the idea / concept is great and has a huge potential, even more if modding will be properly supported!skills / crafting is not fully implemented, for some this could be a CON...my PROs:runs smoothly on highest graphic settings on my Lenovo Thinkpad E530 (!!!)the game forces teamplay (imo something which has been missing in alot of multiplayer sandbox games)huge skill and crafting system (reminds me a bit of Star Wars Galaxies)skill dependenciesincreasing, freezing or decreasing skillscrafting dependenciesnice variety of materials and crafted items with quality indicators (related to your skill lvl)NO ZOMBIES (I'm tired of all these exodus scenarios...)my CONs: graphics (gladly it's not as bad as minecraft / wurm online)alot of servers available, but only a few are highly populatedserver connects (between 3-7 mins, maybe more?)recurring server-lagsalot of time wasted by watching the green progress bar filling up (gathering materials etc.)fighting is very unwieldy / lumberinghud needs more attention, i.e. lock inventory / chat etc. on one side of the sceen...alot of bad reviews on steam (mostly incomprehensible - it's an alpha not a fully developed game yet!!!)i've read alot about crashes (CTD), but so far this has happened to me only once as i've tried to change my graphic settings to max... so i can't add it to CONs (yet...)further i can't comment on the patch frequency nor the contents of patches, as i haven't experienced one yet!and unfortunately i didn't find many servers with high player amounts - i hope this changes over time...overall...graphics => 4/10gameplay => 5/10skillsets/progression => 8/10fighting => 3/10fun => 3/10 (alone), 7/10 (group)server availability => 4/10i do recommend this game for people who are long-lasting sandbox/roleplay gamers with a strong drive for teamwork!cheers and have fun!

number of helpful: 38 of 46 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 16, 2015
Early Access Review
								This game has offered me hundreds of hours of entertainment, and some of the greatest gaming experiences of my life.This is not a review of the contents of the game itself, but rather the effects of playing the game with a large community of players.Playing online on a server with an active community forces you to get into diplomacy, which is a first in any game for me.Other similar pvp-oriented games do of course offer diplomacy, but never have I had to ride up to the gates of a great kingdom and ask for assistance, and end up a vassal for a kingdom much larger and powerful than my own.When starting a conflict or a war, you have to pick sides, maintain alliances, choose whether or not you're strong enough to sustain vassals, that in return will provide you with their military strength.You have the option to display your strength to neighbouring kingdoms and risk war to prevent being attacked, or just lie down belly up and hope they take pity on you.The allies you choose, can result in major server-wide conflicts escalating, and breaking alliances can have the same effect.The choices of one kingdom affects all kingdoms.These are all features created by the community itself. Not because the game rewards it, but because the game allows it. And it's something that really puts Life is Feudal apart from other similar games.I give this game a big thumbs up, and I'm looking forward to the finished product.

content:
Posted: June 2, 2016
												Background: I have little time in survival/crafting games other then some time I put into minecraft years ago and a few hours in Don't Starve. The fact that they are all in early access for years turns me off. I followed this game since release because I liked the setting but only picked it up around March16 after they had upgraded the engine and ironed out alot of issues people complained about. I just had the itch to craft.Short and Sweet: Deep crafting systems, nice graphics, Long building times and skilling up can be a negative to some but it makes the accomplishment SOOOO sweet. Engine still seems to have issues and doesn't run great, concerning if they are using the same everything for the MMO. Worth it if you enjoy crafting games and don't mind that it takes awhile to craft things.Notes: I originally was turned off by the menu system, "why can't I just click a bunch of times to chop down a tree?" Well you can set an action to default click the menus are there because of all the options and how deep the game is compared to most open world/crafting games on the market. Bottomline: I spent 70 hours on a server that had speed up on leveling up your skills as well as a higher cap, however things still went at a snails pace. This is a great crafting/openworld ONLY if you can deal with the slow pace. Example: If you need logs for a house? You have to carry a giant log on your back slowly to your work site. Not just chop it down and place 30 logs in your inventory.

content:
Posted: January 19, 2016
												I'll start out by saying that the game has massive potential.  The skill systems and crafting are wonderful.  But there are a few problems that have been present for extended periods and make the game nearly unplayable for extended periods.  The method the game uses for saving changes to the terrain is very inefficient, which makes it very difficult to maintain a server for extended periods of time.  And if you terraform below the elevation of the water anywhere on the entire map, it causes corruptions in the game database which results in ongoing lag.  Leaving tree stumps after cutting down trees also causes server lag, and so does having too many trees on the server.  Each of these issues don't seem to be terribly important on their own, but they have all been present for an extended period and the game developers continue to add new features and have moved on to working on the MMO version fo the game rather than addressing existing bugs.  Until the developers give the game the attention it needs, this game is not worth playing.

content:
Posted: December 5, 2014
Early Access Review
								Normally, I refuse to buy Early Release games for obvious reasons - it's an unfinished product. It usually has me asking, "Why would I spend money on something that isn't finished with no guarantee for its release?"Even as it stands in its current stage, it's a great game with plenty to do - and this is coming from a person who typically hates Sandbox genre games.Pros:-More than enough to do-Great to play in groups-Feeling of accomplishment when you actually build something-Scale of map/construction-Logical and realistic sandbox:            -Survival mechanics            -Building mechanicsCons:-Questionable developer choices when it comes to storage-Obvious bugs due to it being an early release-Harsh learning curve      -Not noob friendlyI wouldn't recommend this game for people who want to play 20 minutes at a time or for younger people as it requires a bit more of a mature thought process. However, if you like the Mount & Blade series, it's similar to Persisent World Mod mixed with Minecraft. Mind you, this game is only the early release. The actual game will be a Massive Multiplayer Online with player driven politics and the world we be constantly changing based on real players' decisions. There are no NPCs, Quests, or any of the other typical things of an MMO - it truly is a sandbox.

number of helpful: 32 of 37 people (86%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 17
												If there is one thing I can say about this game its that it caters to a very specific audience, and it caters to that audience very well. If you've ever played an RTS or other overhead style of build and conquer game and thought to yourself, "Wouldn't it be cool if there was a game like this where everyone played own of the little pieces rather than having one person control them all?" Then you might really enjoy this game, because thats what its all about.LiF is a teamwork game where individual MUST work together to build something substantial. This is not a good single player game, its not designed for that, you will lose your mind if you try to play this game single player, or even try to go it alone on a multi-player server. 99% of the capabilities of this game come from interacting with others to create something. This game is also relatively slow pace, as you look through the comments sections you can see that most people giving a thumbs up have 1000+ hours in this game. The result is that people work hard and long to develop things in this such have strong sense of pride when its done. The amount of work and effort that goes into actually achieving things in this game makes griefing much more difficult than in other similar games, and the necessity of teamwork makes it much more compatible with Roleplay for those who want it.In my experience this is a great game, but you have to know what your getting when you buy it. If you want action and to be the hero of a grand and epic story, this is probably not the game for you. If you want to experience a truly immersive take on medieval life and contribute to making something greater then just yourself, this game is for you.

Early Access Review
								This is the game that you've been waiting for! It is reminiscent of the MMO's / multi-player games of old that we all got hooked on (Ultima Online, Mount & Blade). It's creative, challenging, and extemely addictive!The innovation in the design focuses on group play, and requires you to be part of a team in order to survive, much less succeed. The equipment is centered around crafting, in fact everything in the game is crafted. Want to be a blacksmith, with your own forge, furnance, and anvil? Great! But you better make friends with an herbalist so you can trade for flux to make steel from those iron ingonts you've been hoarding or you'll be left in the stone age!LiF: YO is the little brother of the expected MMO version that's still under development, and to be released later as a much more massive game.Even though this game is still in Early Access / Alpha state, it is very polished and worthy of support. A big thumbs up to the Devs so far.

number of helpful: 87 of 130 people (67%) found this review helpful4 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 21, 2016
												Honestly, at this point, it's hard to not recommend because the game COULD turn into a game I've ALWAYS wanted - a medieval RPG with a player run economy, politics, and world. That appears to be the vision, but it stumbles in execution. It's just so... bland. I have two underlining problems with the game. 1. the amount of time it takes to make things. Don't get me wrong, I understand where the devs are coming from. I think they're taking a similar approach to EVE Online, where acquiring new licenses for certain ships took literal YEARS to do. And that's fine. But it's pretty dull to sit there and watch my character take 3 minutes to cook a fish. That's literally half the time it takes me to cook a fish IRL. As the game stands, I feel like I need a book to entertain me while whatever is going on in the game takes its time to finish. It sounds like part of what they're going to do in the MMO is create mini games for everything to fill the time in, and that might help, but I still think taking 10 minutes to do anything meaningful is too long. The purpose of the game should be survival and construction, and you don't need to create mechanics that cause you to spend every moment of your free time to accomplish the most base tasks. The time spent should be spent on making things truly epic.2. The game seems pretty empty. You walk into any town, and it is empty. Empty homes, empthy trading posts, empty "schools" - all the building are there only for aesthetics, with no real reason to exist. At the very least, being able to fill them with furniture would be nice. At the most, the furniture you fill it with should all serve some function. And all of this compounds problem 1. What point is there in spending 10 real life hours to build my first humble shack when there's no real purpose to it? I guess if you're into things like legos, and you enjoy building things because it's fun to accomplish something, than this might suit you. But I play games because they're interactive and allow me to do things I wouldn't normally be able to do IRL. So we'll see, maybe the promised MMO will fix those two issues. But as it stands, I didn't really have fun in this game and don't recommend it.EDIT: When I wrote this review, I intended it to be just my two cents on the game. Instead, it has become the "most helpful" review of this game. I only noticed because I get comments every other day from some very passionate fans. Still, I thought it would be a good idea to follow up with a few comments (and fix a grammar mistake or two in the original review). First of all, people getting worked up on whether it actually takes 3 minutes to make a fish IRL are missing the point. One of my favorite game series of all time is the Sims. In that game, your sims do such mundane tasks as poo, eat, laundry, and dishes. But you're empowered to tell a story. It gave you a canvas to tell a story that could spread over generations. It made every in-game day special as you worked towards whatever goal you had established for your virtual family to achieve. Of course, it didn't hurt that Maxis' (and eventually The Sims Studios) signature humor was sprinkled throughout.LIF is missing all of that charm. It takes so damn long to do anything, every task is a chore instead of an exciting step towards a greater adventure. There is no charm, just a generic medieval world with even less character. Obviously I've already mentioned how everything felt empty. The game just needs something, anything, that's fun. As it stands, all you have to hope for is finding a decently populated server where some good samaritan will donate a basic set of arms and armor to you, allowing you to participate in fights sooner. Oh, and you die fairly quickly. If everything else is useless and the only point is fighting, why not make a pure fighting game?Finally, yes, I only played the game for 1.1 hours. I don't have a problem with that. It isn't my responsibility to figure out how to like a game, it's the developers responsibility to sell me on their game. They failed to win me over in the alotted time and I feel other, like minded gamers should know about it. I agree with others, it's a little disappointing that the review from the guy who played for 1.1 hours is currently "the most helpful", but my intention was just to throw in my thoughts. That being said, those who've played for a few dozen hours have walked away with similar impressions. Regardless, I had watched a few hours of Let's Plays, but because it takes so long to do anything in the game and the videos tended to be heavily edited, I thought it would be worth trying the game out. My dream game is where I can live in a medieval world. Be a tavern owner making ale and attracting all the adventurers in town as we discuss the latest war and get buffs from my ale. Be a farmer and cower as I run from the most recent raid by a neighboring fiefdom. Be a merchant and sell goods from city to city. Be a guard-for-hire and assist caravans as they travel the sands. Be a part of a political movement as we overthrow the current government. Be a rogue group of hedge knights that fights for the freedom of noobs all folk, giving each new soul a fair shot in the harsh world. This game is not that game. That's all I'm saying.
