content:
Posted: September 15, 2016
Product received for free
												Let me begin by saying that I hardly take the time to write reviews. Not even on games that I adore heart and soul. This game, however, has forced me to give fair warning to anyone who may be interested, because it can be hard to find clear answers around both the love and hate this game has. I'm no authority, and this is no expert critique, but it is my opinion.In truth...I liked this game quite a bit. As both a roleplayer, history buff, and all around nerd, the concept of this game instantly had allure. It also didn't help that me and my gaming group are all seasoned veterans of Warband's PW modification, so it was destiny that we would end up playing this game. My friend bought me a copy (#poor) so that I could join them on this game. At the time, I had been on the fence about getting it, as the reviews were mixed and I had heard many bad things. I was convinced because the friends who had been playing had already enjoyed it immensely.So why can I not recommend this game if I liked it? Well, I have seen many complain about the time it takes to do something worthwhile, or about the combat system. My issue is with none of these, but insteads sits with the developers and overall state of the game itself. When I started playing, the game was a buggy mess, albeit a fun buggy mess. Over half a year later... it's STILL a buggy mess. Furthermore, the game lacked many requested features and felt a bit bare. It is still lacking a vast majority of these features and feels bare. Back when the first of my friends started playing, it might surprise you to learn that the game was actually a bare, buggy mess!You get the point. The game has issues, but the problem is that so little of those issues are being actively resolved by the developers. To add insult to injury, they have decided to go ahead and release a new game. Clearly, we can see where their time and effort has gone the last year or so...and it wasn't towards this highly unfinished product. They have for a long time planned and talked and announced news towards an MMO, apparently the intended version of this game. Many are excited for this. However, I'm not sure how they can pull of a successful MMO when they have yet to get anywhere near finishing a game that still costs 40$. Now, there is talk (albeit rumors) that they have partnered up with a company that specializes in micro-transactions.I could go into more detail, but the bottom line is that the progress and work put forth towards this relatively expensive beta (mind you the game is labeled 'fully released') has been nothing but disappointing, and I do not see it getting any better. As we get further and further on, it seems more or less like a cash-grab by the devs, or at the very least a passion that has died down. Really, this is just another case of a larger disease plagueing our recent gaming world, but it unfortunately claimed such a fantastic idea as it's victim.Save your money: wait for Bannerlord or splurge on CKII DLC. You'll avoid the sadness of a great idea unfinished.

number of helpful: 40 of 52 people (77%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 1, 2015
Early Access Review
								This is my first review, because I feel that I have to recommend this game, but also warn you:Life is Feudal is still in Early Access, but currently offers a lot of different mechanics. Finding yourself washed ashore on an big island with nothing on your body except for something to eat and some rags, you have to create everything in the game from scratch. You build your own tools from branches and stones, find some roots to eat and create your first Tiny Shack. All this building, crafting and planning (terrain flattening alone is an art/skill) takes unbelievably long time, which may annoy some people. If you are extremely impatient just skip this game - it's nothing for you.On the other hand it is extremely satisfying to create your own buildings. Until I had a forge (which is needed for nails, for example - so a rather basic building), I spent around 20 hours in the game. When the forge was finally done, I was just proud of myself.One reason it takes so long to achieve process, is that many activities take a lot of time: snapping a branch from a tree? Around 2 seconds. You need 20 branches for a building? Click 20 times on the same tree and simply wait each time 2 seconds. This can be annoying with the time, so better get used to it and watch TV on a second screen.Having friends that play with you is not only nice, but highly recommended. With on character you aren't able to succeed in the various skill trees (or if you try you end up as a bad jack-of-all-trades, who is able to some jobs a little, but nothing really good). The strange server structure (everyone can host a server) leads to a huge variety of servers, leaving the "public" servers rather deserted, so don't count on meeting many people around there.As already mentioned, there are several skill trees, like Herbalism, Carpentry, Smithing, Hunting and so on. Each of them uses different mechanics, so it is fun to try them all out. Some of them are extremly fun (building, carpentry), some of them are okay/highly repetitive (mining takes literally hours...) and some of them are simply boring and stupid (especially herbalism). At a later point you need high level material (like steel and mortar) so called Flux which can only be gathered by Herbalism people, who have to search for hours one small area of herbs and then combine them in an annoying mini-game and hope for some luck.The second rather bad mechanic is the whole fighting module. Right now you can hunt animals, some agressive like wolves or boars and some peaceful like sheep or deer. The AI of these animals is simply stupid, you have to shoot them with around 10-15 bullets of your sling to kill them. During this annoying process they do not move a bit (or run away like 5 squares then stay still again). Even the dangerous species try to attack you only once, after you land one successful shot, they stand still like all the others. Even achieving higher levels of weapons (you have to learn Throwing Weapons, then get hit with Leather Armor on, then learn Crossbows and THEN you are able to use Bows) does not significantly lower the time you need to hunt an animal. This is truely unsatisfying and outright bad right now. If the fighting against other players should feel the same like fighting against animals, this would be desastrous.TL,DR:++ Extremely satisfying to build structures+ Great when playing in small communities+ Different mechanics to learn with each job-- Huge effort of time neccessary to achieve something- Long waiting times during processes- Difficult to learn (Wiki helps a great deal)- Combat Module isn't any funAll in all I can recommend this game if you are looking for a challenging medieval-crafting-simulation. If you are impatient or believe that this game is all about building forts and playing knight, go away. You will be disappointed. But if you like grinding for ressources and want to build a small village with your friends - this is your game (Early Access and all).

												+Physics based combat that affects melee, ranged, and even siege weapons!+Great graphics. Some graphics glitches currently however.+Morality system that discourages killing pretty decently so that issues like "bandits" in DayZ are less common. Or at least less lethal =P+Mostly good interface. (Which you can customize to your liking pretty extensively.)+Most realistic medieval "life" game I have ever seen in my entire life. Every aspect of it is realistic in terms of difficulty.-+The realism makes this game hard to play alone, it's very community-based, but playing alone CAN be a viable option. Keep this in mind if the game interests you.+Fully sandbox. Build, do, or don't! The world is there to be shaped and molded by you! From the terraforming, to the building, to the ruins of villages you've left in your wake.+Can build a band of mercenaries, a friendly village, or a mighty kingdom.+Every skill has its importance in the creation and maintenence of a town. Making any choice of "career" viable and rewarding.In its current state I'd give this an 8.5/10. Definitely worth a try if you like building, medieval times, or kingdom ruling.

content:
Posted: January 17
												TLDR: The game is Great. Give it a shot, but only if it's the type of game you really want to be playing, do some research, and don't expect something it's not.Life is Feudal is a fantastic game, if you understand what you are going to be playing.  You can tell from the reviews that many people enter this world expecting a survival experience or something they can play solo.  That's just not the case, and don't buy this if that is what you are looking for.  Unless you have a large group (6-10 active people is awesome) progress is slooowwww... and you can play it with less, but you have to exhibit some patience and find some people to enjoy the grind with. The game is mostly about building and being a part of the community, whether that means being a bandit, farmer, knight, or peasant.  This game is going to bore the ever-loving-hell out of most people if you can't find a way to socialize at least a bit.  Get to know your neighbors, do some trading and a bit of role-play, and work your way into a bit of conflict while you build yourself up, and you'll find the true LiF experience.PvP is prevalent, and is the main focus for some.  This can be quite frustrating for those that want to enjoy a peaceful life in-game, and are not used to dying in the games they play.  However, what you'll need to learn is that dying is nothing to fear.  Just be smart and don't keep your best gear on you while laboring, and the times you may die now and again shouldn't bother you in the least.Combat is fun, but takes some getting used to.  Similar to the Mount and Blade series, and War of the Roses for those that know those, but quite a bit less fluid at times.  Nonetheless, once you get the hang of it, a good scrap will always be interesting.City/castle building is where this game shines in my opinion.  You can make some pretty impressive and cool looking stuff if you have the mind to do it, and patience to complete it.  If you are just starting out, remember to start small, if you get too ambitious with your builds, you will quickly find that you will never finish and most likely burn yourself out.The UI is bad, but gets better/easier to use as you grow accustomed to it.Basically, LiF has been in and out of my life for a great deal of time during the period that I have owned it, and I woudn't trade my many hours in it for anything.  I've met a good deal of great people who I have continued to game with until this day.

content:
Posted: November 10, 2014
												EDIT: Haven't looked at this review in awhile, I decided to go back and look at it to evalutate how accurate is in now that the review is a year+ old. I decided it's not even worth changing because everything is pretty much still persistant as it was when I wrote it and also I noticed what I once thought was a 'fanboy' or maybe a server owner/admin is actually a DEVELOPER. So obviously they had people creating low level, private accounts to argue with critics about their game and to downvote negative reviews. This makes me question to validity of their postive reviews, which were a much higher precentage when the game was release on steam. Now the reviews are mixed and some light in finally being shed on these shoddy developers.. but too late as a lot of people have purchased this game due to bias.One perpetrator 'Neolog' had battled my opinions of the game, trying to be underhanded.. unfortunately I deleted most the comments he made because of his attitude. He wasn't a Developer when he was doing this criticism.. so not only did I receive an official response from Saxxon.. he has his little henchmen going around and debating peoples reviews, be warned if you are looking at the upvotes/downvotes for reviews, as they are obviously manipulated.Quote from the comments of my review:"Neolog  [developer] Dec 9, 2014 @ 12:37am  DeleteI dare to add my comment, hope you won't feel bad:-The graphics are pretty horrible (Think Asheron's Call with some realistic photo textures for SOME things, ick)Well, it's open world game with full terramorphing. You wouldn't say, that bad graphics is a CON of Minecraft, would you?-Many have problems getting it to load and be stable-A lot of strange lag and bugsAlpha, EA. You can copypast this comments to any EA game, and they'd still be true.-It's over 3 years old and still early accessIt's been early access for couple of months. Development took almost 3 years, sooooo? It's indie, dude, they don't have 2000 developers to release a game per year.-Lack of end game contentThe fact, that you're using "end-game content" for a sandbox game tells much about your understanding of a sandbox concept.I honestly don't understand why you bought this game in the first place, but given your quantity of bought games, it seems like you're just buying every game you see =)"End quote...of course he isn't being blatantly rude or anything in this comment, though he is obviously trying to incite a response that will make me - the reviewer, seem less credible.. the other posts he made, which I had deleted spiraled downward into near trollism.My orginal review:This game has potential, yes, potential. It's an evil word that is thrown about and often the ones who spring forty dollars on a game are quick to adopt it.It's fun to play, for sure, especially when there are more people working in sync to alleviate the artificial wait times. The wait times are a mix of a blessing and a curse, they give the feeling of accomplishment when you are finally able to see your hard work pay off, but this is all a ruse when you realize that there isn't really an end to a means since the endgame comes down to pvp which is still a work in progress and from my experience a long ways from being substantial. (I.E. Horses and almost all the weapon skills are not implemented.)The real reason I am NOT recommending this game is the lack of updates. YES I KNOW THIS IS EARLY ACCESS. They have been working on this game for over THREE YEARS before it got greenlit, Do yourself a favor and research it yourself, their PR will gladly say that they are working diligently on the game, but the fact is there hasn't been any substatial updates for years. That is not a good track record, especially concerning the core mechanics of the game which are not even implemented.PROS-Combat is not like Mount and Blade-Crafting system is detailed and involving-Fun to work with others towards a common goal-Open charachter development-Open world developmentCONS-Combat is not like Mount and Blade (Yes, it's a pro and a con)-Artificial wait times-The graphics are pretty horrible (Think Asheron's Call with some realistic photo textures for SOME things, ick)-Many have problems getting it to load and be stable-A lot of strange lag and bugs-It's over 3 years old and still early access-Lack of end game content-Not much freedom when constructing things (Prefab building, etc)I suggest you read over their official website, especially concerning their progress before you purchase, I also recommend researching other games that are close in genre and half as expensive.5/10

content:
Posted: January 20, 2015
Early Access Review
								I do not recommend this game, because it can actually be very fun. Odd reason to not recommend a game right! See the problem is... Enjoying it means obnoxious lenghts of time doing things. Oh want to make a farm, clear an area, teraform area, plow the ground, plant seeds, and harvest crops! Sounds easy, but each step is its own huge grind. On top of that, crops take (usually, but depending on server settings) a real life 24 hours to be able to harvest them. Worse yet if you arent online when they are harvestable, they wither. Fighting is fun enough, its laggy and glitchy but fun. It feels like a bad connection mount and blade, but dumbed down extremely. The hit detection is off, but not too bad. Combat is absolutely just spam click, however some things like shield bash knock you over and stun you. You can chain this with multiple people. The combat needs a lot of work, its geared for bad players in droves.Its also not really a solo game, you must find a group. Now several people will argue this, but understand that these are adults who can commit 10+ hours a day to a video game. Are you able to do that? Exactly, me either because we arent shut ins. The game takes huge huge gaps of time, splitting the time load with other players is the only way to survive. Unless you play on a PvE server I guess, but I cant imagine doing that.It was extremely fun for 4 or 5 days, playing with 3 RL buddies, then it kept getting more and more lame. Building weapons and armor takes REAL LIFE gaps if time. Like 24 hours for flax to grow, then 24 more hours to turn it into rope fibers... Oops not enough to make a full rope, 24 more hours to grow more, 24 more hours to turn that into rope fibers. I wish this was an exaggeration, but this will happen to you. You have outrageous time sinks to get skills to the level to do the next thing, like plant certain seeds, make rope or tan leather. All the while there is inevitably some huge 20 person group of euros who is pretending they are back in their countries hayday, griefing everyone mostly when they are offline. Its so weird and socially awkward.Short story long... Its just simply not ready yet, its a fun little medieval simulator, but im not willing to grind on an alpha game, maybe you are who knows. Try it, its not the worst game ever, its just currently a hot mess.

content:
Posted: December 8, 2016
												Man..where top begin:When I bought this game, I fell in love immediately. No zombies, no spaceships, nothing to pull you out of feeling totally immersed in a dark-ages survival experience. Things were rough in the dark ages. They were DARK. The game follows suit. It was nigh unplayable solo. It has only gotten harder in my opinion. You need a group to survive unless you have 24/7 to grind away on things.The game play is great. Targeting is real..not tab BS. They got SO MANY THINGS RIGHT. Damned fine work guys!!! A+ in many many categories.Realistic? Hell yes. Too much so, though I think.A game has to be FUN. I find it relaxing as all get out to flatten the land and plant crops solo. But I have taken a massive short cut and created my own server, The Shadowlands, and allowed GM console commands for myself.This both made the game playable solo for me and it has now ruined it for me as it did with ARK: SEOnce you are GOD, what's left to strive for?Now there is an MMO version out. Initially I thought "OUSTANDING"!! A persistant world where the rules aren't dictated by some drunken numbnut. I shall no longer plant my fields alone.....Then I found out that those of us who had already shelled out $40 bucks were going to have to PAY for said MMO.Whoa whoa...what?We have essentially paid to play what has effectively been a testing ground all along for this MMO. This game was never meant to be a standalone .. I see that now.Give the MMO to those who already paid for your R & D. Don't be THOSE guys who milkmilkmilk until we freakfreakfreak.That's my advice.Do I recommend this game? Sure...its amazing. Just bring friends or spend a day finding a non douchbag polluted server. They exist...in theory. But our current situation leads me to questions of integrity. I still hold my thumb up but it is leaning....

content:
Posted: December 19, 2015
												The best game I've played in a long time, and about the only title of hundreds that didn't make me quit the game after a short while because I've went "*sigh* I've done this before." It's a realistic medieval sim, and a very time-demanding, rewarding one at that. It takes time to do stuff in the game, which has this amazing rewarding feeling when you actually accomplish things. Games nowadays have lost that feel. The game has quite a steep learning curve, and to even be able to kill a creature for its meat and pelt, it might take fifteen to twenty minutes killing it. But when you finally hit your target with that last stone and it falls to its death, I caught myself in jumping up and down in my chair, singing random celebratory songs! Amazing feeling. Many people would dislike this game. It takes time, and it IS hard. You'd have to like challenges to like the game. I've seen many people rate this game poorly, stating the reason behind it was that it was too hard and time demanding, criticizing it for not being like other survival games before it. I say thumbs up! Best game I've played in many, many years.

content:
Posted: April 5, 2015
Early Access Review
								I honestly think that a lot of the negative reviews towards this game were written without considering the game's spiritual predecessors: Wurm Online, Haven & Hearth, and whichever others gave way to inspire the mechanics in LiF. This game maintains the same level of grind as Wurm, assuming a 1.0 skillgain multiplier, while making every last accomplishment feel wonderful. When I got my first tunnel dug to ore, it was a great feeling, and then smelting the ore, and so on.The only agonies I face in this game really come from trying to play solo, terraforming (even with other people I imagine it's dreadful to flatten out a cliff face, as it really should be.) the occasional bug and probably loss of life and items from PvP encounters. I don't quite appreciate the way the skills work, with the prerequisite skills and all that, due to the fact that A: there's a(n) (adjustable) skillcap, and B: some of the sequencing doesn't make sense. IIRC, use of chainmail is restricted to after you reach level 30 in warhorse training, and other armor skills are thrown after other random combat skills. It just doesn't feel right. Lastly, if you're playing alone, just absolutely forget about making real progression with the skillcap at its default settings, because nearly every skill is required to make a nicely functioning settlement.Is this game worth the price tag? That's debatable. At this state, I'd personally say yeah, but I understand others that aren't as seasoned to the type of game this is might want to hold out for a sale or for more content to be ironed out and implemented. At the time of writing I've had ~40 hours in the past few days, and I've got to say, nothing feels more satisfying than seeing what all I've managed to accomplish on my own.

												I initially wrote the following in response to a post on the community page about why people dislike the game:It gets bad reviews because it is bad. The devs are EXTREMELY slow in getting updates out. There are lots of gamebreaking bugs. (gotta love tubs and racks still not working) Performance is still pretty poor for lots of folks. Good servers are hard to come by as they are community ran. Good servers fill up and you can't get in due to 64 person limit. The animal AI is atrocious. Its not a survival game because its insanely easy to find some apples. Fighting is rather counter-intuitive and if you don't like it its only because 'you aren't any good' which really just means you haven't taken the time to learn how to exploit certain weapons. The MMO can solve some of these issues, but first it actually has to get out of beta wave 0 which its been in for what, 6 months now? Not to mention the low skill cap and low skill multiplier make it a total grind fest. They announced that partnership with the microtransaction company like it was some crowning achievement which means milking us for every penny seems to be highest on the priority list. The concept of clans battling on some neutral outside the world battlefield also seems insanely stupid as well. I have nearly 1000 hours in the game and regret most all of them. If it wasn't for my addictive personality and the crafting system I would have given up much sooner. The one positive is that I can write reviews without the trolls complaining that I don't have enough game hours to have an opinion.

content:
Posted: May 4, 2016
												TL;DR AT THE BOTTOMLife is Feudal is an extremely grindy game (on non-boosted servers at least). If you can handle the grind, however, it has to be one of the most rewarding, fun, and interesting games out there. It puts other medieval survival games (looking at you, Reign of Kings) to shame. Still very unfinished but, in my opinion, it is definitely worth the money.Pros:- The game is very rewarding later on. If you can get past the first difficult cliff then you'll be set for a while. It's not like Rust or Ark in that you can wake up one day with everything gone.- If you have a large group of friends it's a ton of fun. 10 friends in a group could create an entire empire if you work together.- Very in depth skills. You can level just about any skill you can think of.- Many, many paths to build your kingdom. If you want to build an underground kingdom, you can. If you'd rather a castle with massive, indestructible walls, you got it. There are infinite numbers of ways to play this game.- Roleplay potential is crazy. I don't mean roleplay like Skyrim where you level up skills and talk to NPCs. I mean roleplay like SAMP or Project Reality. If you want to get very immersed as the king you are, you certainly can. Check out Mr Moon on YouTube for good examples of Life is Feudal roleplay.Neutral- Takes a ton of time to get into. You can put 50 hours into the game without getting anywhere if you swap servers frequently. On games such as Rust, you can get a decent establishment up and running within a day. On Life is Feudal, you need a good 5-6 hours of gameplay for 5 days straight to get something resembling a base.Cons- The combat is still pretty meh. It was significantly worse when the game was launched. It's not as good as other medieval combat in games such as Chivalry, but it gets the job done.- Weird protection systems. In order to protect your items you must make some kind of totem/idol thing and give it frequent sacrifices of herbs. It takes 1-1.5 hours of farming in the first place to make it however if you miss one day of sacrifices then it gets destroyed and your stuff is gone.- Playing solo is impossible. Well, not technically, but you can't expect to get anywhere in any reasonable amount of time if you dont have a few friends to help you out. Hell, at least one friend will make a huge different.Please note that quite a few of my personal issues with the game (time investment, mainly) is made null by servers with increased farming rates.I will edit this review with more pros/cons as I play the game more.TL;DR - The game is very in depth, tons of fun, and very time consuming. Bring your friends. If you don't have a lot of free time play on an increased rates server. Over all, I'd give it a 8/10 based on my personal enjoyment.

												The best game I've played in a long time, and about the only title of hundreds that didn't make me quit the game after a short while because I've went "*sigh* I've done this before." It's a realistic medieval sim, and a very time-demanding, rewarding one at that. It takes time to do stuff in the game, which has this amazing rewarding feeling when you actually accomplish things. Games nowadays have lost that feel. The game has quite a steep learning curve, and to even be able to kill a creature for its meat and pelt, it might take fifteen to twenty minutes killing it. But when you finally hit your target with that last stone and it falls to its death, I caught myself in jumping up and down in my chair, singing random celebratory songs! Amazing feeling. Many people would dislike this game. It takes time, and it IS hard. You'd have to like challenges to like the game. I've seen many people rate this game poorly, stating the reason behind it was that it was too hard and time demanding, criticizing it for not being like other survival games before it. I say thumbs up! Best game I've played in many, many years.

content:
Posted: November 8, 2014
Early Access Review
								LiF is one of the games I've been playing since starting my break from a different game earlier this year so I'd like to share my views on LiF as well. Overall:As others have said, it will not be for everyone, and the MMO version (LiF) vs the private server version (LiF:YO) are two rather different beasts.  Having been in the alpha for LiF, the biggest difference between the MMO and personal server versions is simply the size of the map, the lack of the "claims" mechanic (think of this system as a combination deed and guild/nation mechanics in Wurm Online), and the server owner's ability to mod the server.  This includes going so far as to restructure the skill trees, the exp rates, recipe requirements, and even the animations/models, they just need to provide the modified client files for you to use. Map Size(s)Looking at map sizes, for the LiF:YO map, if you are familiar with Wurm Online, it is roughly the size of Cele and shaped like a mini-Indy (big mountain in the middle, various terrain types between the mountain and the waterline).  On the MMO map, the LiF:YO equates to about 1 map "grid" in size (map was something like 12-15 by the same if I remember correctly). Skill/Character ProgressionSkills are capped by server settings, which is an option the server owner can configure and can allow for your character to actually master all skills if the cap is set correctly.  There are a few servers with reduced skill gains very similar to Wurm's progression pacing, but again it is up to the server owner.Like UO, on servers with anything less than max skills set, you can choose to lock any skill you want to not progress/gain exp in that "line", you can choose to have a skill reduce if you hit cap.Crafting, "General", and Combat skills are all separate skill pools, so the cap applies to each pool separately.Stats are their own pool and have their own "cap" appliedCombatPVE and PVP use the same combat systemAttacks are modified by skill, the weapon used, and target's armorYou can target specific areas for different outcomesEndurance matters, different weapons and attacks have different endurance costs, and the armor you're wearing adds to this cost.Different armors have different endurance costs, but also have strong/weak protection stats making a situational need/use for all armors (i.e. there is no best armor for every use where padding can be just as valuable as plate, sometimes more so, depending on who is using it and why)You don't have to kill your opponent to defeat them and you still get to loot themDeath system applies a small skill loss upon death (not defeat), which can be a larger or smaller impact depending on the server settingsTrade/CommerceIn the personal servers, since there are no kingdoms, there are no coin of the realm.  Each group is free to determine what they want to use as their basis of exchange.In the MMO plans (as per the FAQ) each 1*1km kingdom will have a "pool" of coin introduced by way of the trader posts (think of the trader system in Wurm)Building/Construction/StructuresGeneral housing/structures are templates (i.e. cookie cutter), but you can rotate the structure when placing it to provide at least some control on appearanceCastles/Cities are modular and built item by itemThe requirements for each structure vary greatly, and will require a player to learn/use a couple different skills to build even the smallest/easiest houseModsI've actually been playing mostly on a modded server for the last few days, the admin/modder has been keeping in-step with the developer and releasing updates the same day as the official client files.  Currently there are only 3 truly modded servers (actually requiring modded client files) accessible to the public.  Custom server configurations for exp gains, number of animals, etc... do not require modded client files*Updated* After having played on modded servers since the initial review, I continue to find that the modding community is full of very talented people.  The core system is not for the faint of heart, and these people not only keep their modded server (and client) files up to date almost in-step with the dev team, they tend to share their knowledge with others to improve everyone's gameplay experience by adjusting those elements important to their server's players. Personal Opinion(s)Honestly, I'm enjoying LiF about as much as I when I started playing Wurm full time a couple of years ago.  Like Wurm Online a few years ago, there are a lot of things that are still in the early development process, and more than a few things that are just fun when taken as part of the overall system.  To me, it really does feel like Wurm Online back when Golden Valley (GV) was the starter town and the mainland was premium only. The two biggest things that I think players coming from games like Wurm Online specifically need to keep in mind is that in LiF:YO there is a built in need to interact with people unless the server has the skill cap set high enough (3000+ skill points), and there is a progression dependency to all skill progression.  If you want to build castles, you need to learn to terraform->refine construction materials->construction->masonry->architecture, you cannot simply jump into one skill to hit the next skill unlock and then forget about the base skill. As with any other game, you'll either like it or you won't, but either way, it's a personal opinion/preference that only you can decide on.

number of helpful: 26 of 34 people (76%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 23, 2015
Title: Life is Feudal: Your OwnGenre: Action, Indie, RPG, Simulation, Early AccessDeveloper: Bitbox Ltd. Publisher: Bitbox Ltd.“Realistic medieval multiplayer sandbox with terraforming, free preset and modular building construction, rich crafting (smelting, forging, farming, animals breeding etc.), survival, no target physics based combat, original combat formation system and numerous other features.”**Do note that this is an Early Access game, things will still change.**Overall Experience:My first impression when I tried the game is that the way the game is presented is very good. It's set in a medieval environment, your character starts off in a woodland area, the land is a mix of untamed forests, grass and water. The buildings and tools represent this era very well, a lot of effort has gone into the background. I like the realism behind the crafting system too, like if you go to fish, you won't always catch a fish. It's relaxing as well when you're not getting attacked every five seconds by the wildlife, which gives you time to do things. The game starts off with you having to explore, forage and prospect the land to find and gather materials. From these materials you craft primitive items that allow you to fish, chop trees, dig for ore, and from then on you can choose what you want to specialise in as well. There is a limited number of points you can pour your points into, which means you will end up focusing on one or two skills more than the others. For example you may choose to build a farm, and learn to cook and tend to animals. Or maybe you want to learn how to build a house and design it with different architectural styles. Perhaps you want to create potions. Or learn to forge armour and weapons. So you choose to focus on the desired skill tree until you are able to make the higher end materials. This is good because with each player specialising in an skill tree, it means there is more chance of cooperation happening, for players contributing to build a village or a working clan, rather than running around killing people straight away. You can adjust the max learning points from server to server, but limiting it persuades people to work together for the greater good. Gameplay: This is one of the things that lacks, and I feel the need to say it. The learning curve in my opinion is really hard, and it's difficult to get into the game if you don't have any friends that play it, who can help you to learn it. I liked the fact that the game requires you to be patient. It's not the kind of game where you can mindlessly run around and get everything you need in less than an hour. It's the kind of game that will require a lot of time for you to be able to get even some of the things you need. It's a slow paced game, but things are sped up when you do it with people - which means once again the game is encouraging cooperation.Controls: The controls are ok, but the main problem is that you need to tab for virtually everything, which gets pretty annoying. I would prefer the viewing and gathering to be different than needing to tab for it each time. The screen freezes with wherever you tabbed so there isn't much free roaming/observing. The movement of the character is good and quite smooth, but the rest is clunky. Sound: I really liked the music in the game. The game is very slow paced, and the music fits in perfectly in the background, nice and relaxing for something that you will end up spending a lot of time on. It changes when you go into combat as well. Learning Curve:I think the learning curve is really hard, and this needs to be mentioned for players who may not have so much patience with this. There's a lot of things you need to do, with your inventory you need to point and click for everything, and each action takes time to process. With the character creation menu as well there is no explanation of the skills you'll be putting your points into, which is a shame because these will affect the outcome of what you do in the game. For example one of the skill trees just says "Forestry", but with no detail as to what this means. What will forestry allow you to do and craft and how you can do it within the game. This would benefit enormously from having a small description underneath for each skill and talent. Verdict: The game itself has a LOT of potential. The game is well detailed, and the crafting system is very in depth and gives you a lot of options. However the game will take a long time to learn - it isn't for anyone who doesn't have the patience to keep at something. 6.5/10Why 6.5? Because this game has potential, however it has not reached the potential I think it can. But then again that is what Early Access is for.Want moar? Click here to join my steam group and Click here to follow my curator page!

number of helpful: 28 of 38 people (74%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 13, 2015
Early Access Review
								Seeing as I have 500+ hours and this game is about to release I should put my opinions and experiences out thereWe'll begin with the learning curve of the game. Personally, it took me and a few friends a week or two to actually get into the "mid-game" of Life Is Feudal. Through lots of struggling and crashes we eventually became the strongest and best on the server, we were addicted. For new players, this game is extremely difficult but very immersive. I can not stress enough to new players to push through the beginning grind so they can experience the rest of the game. I feel as if more stuff should be added to the beginning of the game to make it more fun for newer players, however.The skills tree is very well thought out, however it features some bottlenecks that must be overcome. I very rarely say this, but I enjoy how this game forces you to play with friends to make the game a little easier. In saying this, roles come into play. Whenever we play, we usually designate a farmer, blacksmith and builder, as these are the roles needed to quickly surpass the early game. I almost always play the farming role at the start as I enjoy seeing how a few seeds that you scraped up from the ground begin to become a vast farm that surrounds your town. Most of the other skill trees in the game also flourish in a similiar way, such as going from constructing chicken coops and shacks to beautiful multi-story houses and towering walls.During our time in Life Is Feudal, we rather quickly noticed the older aged community. We made many friends with people 20 or even 30 years older than us. The only major problem we had with the community was that some of the older folks (a lot, actually) disliked PvP and stuck to strictly PvE. This anti-PvP community here in Australia at least is quite worrying for the future of the game, as removing one of the main elements to a game like this makes it ever more boring. My group and I all enjoyed the threat of having some armed dudes try and take us down because they were worried that we would become powerful, and it would be great if one day we came across a server that didn't shun it. On the topic of PvP, the weapons and fighting in the game have come a far way, however I hope they do fix some little things in time for the MMO to avoid♥♥♥♥♥♥♥running about with no armor and bows just to get some easier kills.Overall I look forward to the MMO and would recommend that you buy this game when it goes on sale for the release, and remember, life is feudal..

number of helpful: 34 of 49 people (69%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 29, 2014
Early Access Review
								Is this game worth 40 dollars? No. Not quite, will it be? Yes, without a doubt. This game is very addicting, it is so fun, you will wonder why you find it so fun; and consider that something may be wrong with you. Primarily because you stare at things for hours on end.First you look at grass, then trees, then ground that you flatten, then you look at ground you are digging into, then you look at ore you are mining, then the furnace you are smelting it in, then the leather crafting equipment, then the forge, and finally; you look at people running away from you, before you catch up to them and kill them with weapons and armor.11/10 Would fail to communicate with peasant thief because of Alpha Build, then kill him and take all his rocks, rags and apples.EDIT - There seems to be a LOT of confusion about combat in this game, rightfully so. People say it is broken because they attempt PVP VERY EARLY INTO THEIR PLAYTHROUGHS, and try to beat each other to death with tools mostly, iron and primitive.However, that is not true, you take a major penalty when fighting with tools that can be reduced (Although never fully) by leveling a skill called "Militia Service," which attaches to a penalty free weapon, the familiar pitchfork! The pitchfork is effective, as you are unarmored and agile, you can also outmaneuver them with your speed. A peasant not to be trifled with to say the least.Additionally, "real" combat features a not visually impressive, but still very immersive and fun combat system. You will find yourself strategizing against your opponent, anticipating his moves and stamina, spotting weak points in his armor. You will want to duel your cohorts almost constantly, when facing Hank, the fully armored Zweihander♥♥♥♥♥♥victim in the comments. I found myself circling with him in a defensive posture and thinking, "First, he'll aim to parry, strike, backpedal and swing, then disengage and recover." You will feel A LOT of satisfaction when your opponent executes precisely as you anticipated before you press the attack. It will drive you to almost never want to make things in the game again, only steal and kill from those who do.

content:

												I always thought Life is Feudal looked pretty crappy and seemed like a bad game with a terrible UI where you walk around with big tree-trunks on your back and hunt for invisible ingredients off of the ground and trees...While some of it is actually still true (harvesting of ingredients and carrying things on your back - though the tools look much better now), the upgraded graphics, new weather and season changes, etc. has made this into something utterly different from what I first perceived. If you've ever wanted to build your own house and live a simple life, where all your necessities come from nature and your own hard work, this is the game you've been looking for. - If nothing else, you can simply take in the beauty of the living nature with many different species of trees and wildlife co-existing in a world that's (yet) to be touched by human influence.P.S. Sean Bean made me buy this game.

number of helpful: 40 of 60 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 25, 2014
Early Access Review
								I really enjoyed learning and testing Life is Feudal: Your Own. Even though it's current content is limited, this game has absolutely AMAZING potential. The concept is truly awesome. However, there are some pretty serious issues with the game. Aside from exploiters and trolls, the engine the game runs on is utterly terrible. The engine cannot currently support 64 people (or even 20 very active players) without a substantial amount of serverside lag. This isn't something that can be fixed. It has to do with a memory limitation of the 32 bit process that the engine uses. Until they remake the game on another engine, an MMO with 10,000 people per world will be entirely unplayable (no matter how much they break up the world into individual areas with their own server).Secondly, the combat system, while very interesting in concept, is horrible. I understand what the developers were going for, but what they designed is too clunky to be enjoyed. Lastly, the developers are doing an excellent job smashing bugs and fixing other errors. Even if they can fix the exploits and remaining game-breaking bugs, it is still difficult to recommend LiF:YO for $40. The server and engine issues cannot be fixed without using a different engine. The only exception would be if someone has ten to twenty friends to play with and are willing to wait a few months for more content.

content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
												Life is Feudal: Your Own is a very grueling, arduous, exausting game at first, it took me almost 15-20 hours of gameplay just to understand the BASICS (playing while listening to a youtube guide), and with more than 100h of gameplay i still doesn't know how to do ALOT of things ingame.Pros: Crazy variety of skills and its improvemants (artisan -> carpentry -> contruction -> masonry -> engineering/architecture | artisan -> mining -> smelting -> forging/armorsmithing/jewelry | nature's lore -> farming -> forestry -> advanced farming -> brewing/cooking/alchemy, etc etc) Outstanding medieval atmosphere, graphics plus soundtrack. Realistic Combat Theory, an audacious step by the devs, physics-inspired body control, special attacks following intuitive parry (the game even takes weapon's weight into account here) and blocking, combos and the legendary pounce to take the edge of a fencing battle, it's all there. Character progression is rewarding as anything, but it's a double-edged sword, cuz one of the things that makes that progression so rewarding is the constant feeling that you can lose everything upon death.Cons: This game is still in Early Access despite they took EA status away, unfinished in so many ways. Tiny variety of fauna and flora. Combat Theory is amazing but there's almost none opportunity to learn and improve it besides PvP (i tend to dislike PvP in survival games), cuz there's so few distinct wild animals (wolfs, boars and bears for the most part) which gets you bored/tired easily. Annoying character movement overall at first, but you get used to it. Almost none interaction with other players besides PvP and "crafting together". Death Penalty is the only thing that keeps me away from this game (normally i find this a pro but since i don't have much free time nowadays).Concluding Remarks:I often compare Life is Feudal with Wurm Online/Wurm Unlimited, they are almost the same game with the big difference of graphics ofc, same essence, but it's like you have much more purpose in investing time in Wurm, very few itens to craft overall in comparison, because of limited fauna you don't have much variety in the Animal Lore skill-tree (catch, breed and tame animals), because of limited flora you don't have much variety in the Nature's Lore skill-tree (herbalism, forestry, farming and alchemy), the list goes on and on in almost every aspect of the game, as i said LiF is still an Early Access game in my opinion.Finally, i would say LiF:YO is a game for people who have time to invest, because it's a very time-consuming game and it's learning curve is kinda grueling, and i must say (even that i know i'm giving a thumbs up) don't buy this game YET, let it improve, i would recommend you to buy Wurm Unlimited here (on a sale haha) to get used to this type of game, if you "master" Wurm Unlimited by the time you play LiF, it wouldn't be that time-consuming.

content:
Posted: February 21, 2015
Early Access Review
								Definately a great game in it's current state already :)I often compare it to Minecraft. I know that comparisation is overused, but in the case of Life is Feudal it's not too far away. I remember my friends and me talking about the "downsides" of Minecraft, and what we would want in a "Minecraft 2": More crafting, better engine, better graphics, some sort of a combat system other than LMB spam and again, more crafting.Life is Feudal pretty much is exactly that. It's not blocky at all and doesn't feat creepers, but that's it :PThe crafting variety is very large, the chains can be HUGE (Growing chickens to make dung to fertilize soil to grow flax to make fibres to make yarn to make ropes to make an arbalest etc). The price is high for an early access, but in my view it's worth it.HOWEVER the game is very slow paced, which actually is a good thing. Just keep this in mind when thinking about buying the game: If you only "casually play a little", LiF might be too time intensive for that.Also you need some kind of technological expertise when trying to play on your own. If you dont have it you should play on another server. "Single player" works fine  for a week but then usually crashes, leaving your save corrupted and you unable to play without setting it all up again (21.02.15). I hope this is a priority issue because I'm really tired of all the database work just to avoid that my savegames are gone ;)This kind of "big" issue still doesn't keep me from spending most of my time with this game, therefor I can only recommend it in all ways :P Not perfect, but going to be ;)

content:
Posted: January 23
												First: Ignore the negative reviews of players with less than 100h negativating over being attacked, because they don't have any experience in the game or are doing something wrong, it take some and you need some friends to know everything, players who try to play alone that barely can do it in High cap/progress servers, you can be attacked by groups and it can be really annoying to loners.Second: This game is slow, have it in mind, it isnt like rust where you set up you base in hours and wipes every month, you need time, pacience and people to play with you, doing everything alone is boring, so have some friends to chat and distract over the repetitive tasks. Third: For combat, it is like mount & blade, sort off... It's tricky to be a decent fighter, but if you play with friends, you can train your way to be a proficient fighter. Don't think this game can be played without combat, only with you want to play HappyFarm on a PvE server.  If you dont have too much time to play this game, no problem! You dont need to play all day, it is just important what you do while you play... lots of groups would like to have a extra pair of hands to help, even for just a few momments/day. And if you are buying this game to play the MMO when it releases, YOU MUST play this game AT LEAST ONCE in a LOW progress and LOW skillcap server, you need to be used to the grind. Play in a high progress to learn how to play but go in a low cap/progress and get used to it. ------ Mensagem especial para os brasileiros (ou portugueses que nao se importam com ping): Se você deseja jogar no MMO e não gosta de trolls e quer ter um grupo grande e amigavel, só me adicionar na steam ou procurar o grupo "Meia Lua MMO", jogaremos no servidor norte-americano. E se você for um não-brasileiro que traduziu essa mensagem no google, você pode participar tambem, lembre-se que o grupo tem o nome em portugues! :D

number of helpful: 49 of 77 people (64%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 20, 2014
Early Access Review
								Type of Game:First person or Third Person Multiplayer Medieval Survival Sandbox Open World SimulationVersion Played:Early Access PC version through SteamSimilar Games:DayZ, Rust, and to a lesser degree the Mount & Blade seriesThe Good:An epic game world filled to the brim with content, whether it be things to craft or items to use, the game world has no limits on what you can do.Everything you see is reachable and harvestable.A very strong medieval aesthetic, which makes the game stand out more so than the competition (i.e. DayZ, Rust, etc…).Multiplayer is this game’s strong suit with a great enjoyment to be had by exploring the medieval landscape with a buddy or two.The crafting, building, and surviving aspects of the game are much more exciting when experienced with a friendThere is a level progression system, which you typically won’t find in games of this nature.I only say this because a progression system is much more fun in a survival type game and brings with it a sense of urgency that you would find in a PDL genre-type.The map is always present, which usually isn’t the case for these games. This makes coordinating a rendezvous with your friends much easier and drastically improves the multiplayer experience. As you’ll find with other game’s of this type, the relationships with other players is a fascinating experience. For the most part other players typically pursue a Lord of the Flies mentality and will often exert their power over those that have a weak footing in the game’s hierarchy. However, when you encounter other players that are helpful it makes the game much easier to digest and enjoy.The Bad:Life is Feudal is very clunky and not polished at the moment. Menu and interface options aren’t intuitive and present themselves as overly complex. Complete lack of a tutorial, which is understandable for an “Early Access” title, but you should be aware none-the-less.Single-player is difficult to swallow as most other players will just grief you over and over again. Playing with your friends is the only way to currently guarantee a good time.Outside of the medieval aspects, this game is more of the same if you’ve played Rust or DayZ. I would argue that the features are much deeper than what Rust has to offer and Rust is Life is Feudal’s closest likeness.Can you play it while the children are awake?Due to the nature of multiplayer shenanigans, I often had to play without my sound on. Other players are often rude and mean, which can lead to profane language and crude lingo. There is also combat and violence, but I felt as though the graphics weren’t grand enough to matter in that regard. Did I make time to complete it?As a multiplayer game there is no completion per say. I did build a number of structures and survived for a number of hours.Redlight or Greenlight?This game is currently at a redlight.The content that is currently offered is just not worth the asking price of $39.99. If you were a gamer that REALLY enjoyed Rust, then you will be getting your money’s worth in this title as the content is better. Outside of that demographic, I just don’t see the appeal of paying a large amount of money to experience a lesson in human nature (i.e. griefing) and confusing gameplay (lack of tutorial). This may change as the game updates, so please check back here for any changes in my preview.Reviewer:MisterS42A Quick Look at Those Games You Might Buy:http://www.gamersglance.com

content:
Posted: November 10, 2014
Early Access Review
								I really want to recommend this game.  As a longtime fan of open sandbox games going back to MUDs I love hardcore sandbox action.  However good the idea though, don't think this one is going to be the next Ultima Online or EvE:online sans spaceships. You can read alot about the gameplay and unfinished state, but really the developer is small and needs funds to make anything happen.  I won't knock that.  I for one was willing to invest a few dollars in the idea.  However upon playing for quite a long time it’s my honest opinion the game is structurally flawed.  Read that as I do not think their current engine and code is capable of being ported to an MMO framework and from what I have seen so far, I'm skeptical that it will even be stable as a Minecraft style dedicated server game - EVER. Many others have detailed problems so far, but I can say that this game currently (NOV2014) does not support most video cards and you will spend around 5-10 minutes loading into most servers only to have no sound and quite probably crash within 1 minute of dropping in.  This has something to do with the terraforming and other stuff I know nothing about. This is not the review I want to leave.  I love the idea.  Hope this company can make it happen, or another larger developer can buy it and make it what it should be.  There is a demand for hardcore sandbox action in this environment and as an MMO it can be profitable for decades, just look at the EVE:Online model that has thrived even with internet spaceships which turns alot of hardcore RPG'rs off.  But cannot recommend this game now and unlikely will for quite some time going forward.

content:
Posted: October 30, 2015
Early Access Review
								Life is Feudal... indeed! The amount of time you can spend to build a single house is.... horrendeous. You need building logs? ok go chop trees, easy! you need windows? go melt some sand to make glass, easy! you need doors? even better, you can get wood planks from the trees you just chopped. A lock for the door? oh ok I'll just smelt some iron... wait it has to be steel? how the F do I do this?? oh you need Flux, a compound found in plants, and you can acces it via Herbalism skill. Wait I just reached my skill cap? oh jeez. I'm out of this game......Someone comes to help you build your village? They want to be a part of this? Great!! they get the flux then!This is an example of the complexity of the game and how dependent you have to other players. It might be scary for newbies but if you get into it with 2 or 3 friends, you can really achieve something marvelous, or at least so I have seen. Minecraft is for kids, Rust is for teens, LiF is for adults who want to achieve something.At your own risk.

content:
Posted: April 11
												This is probably the most counterintuitive, addicting game I've ever had the chance to play. It's probably due to the amazing community I've found in the server I play in, because without the Wikia this game is nearly impossible.It's basically a life simulator. You spawn with nothing but your clothes and a piece of bread in your inventory and you climb the ladder from there. You learn as you go, gaining new skills as you work to build your refuge that could, with some effort, turn into a walled city. The PVE is fun and gratifying, frustrating at times but when you finally cut that last three and saw that last building log and see your house or warehouse or blacksmith workshop rise, it's great. The PVP is tough to master but it can be done. One good thing is that it runs smoothly even on older computers. It's a light-weight game, but it gets the job done very well, it's quite pleasing to the eye, expecially in spring and summer.

content:
Posted: November 1, 2015
												Life is Feudal is a medieval fantasy MMORPG set in a sandbox environment. The world is massive and immersive, allowing players to control almost every aspect of the physical environment. Build everything from huts to homes, to outposts and even villages. Or, if you’re feeling ambitious, you can create your own mega-castle! Work the land for natural resources, craft weapons and armor, and gain valuable player skills in order to stay alive. Life Is Feudal is an excellent game, it's in a early stage with obvious bugs but highly playable and already has a lot of content to offer. Devs have been tackling the bugs and fixing things as they arrive, and are very active on the community.So far this has to be one of my all time favorite Sandbox game.

content:

Early Access Review
Life is Feudal: Your Own is a incredibly interesting game, in particular in regards to gameplay and multiplayer. This is something personal, but in my eyes it is the most promising indie game for all of 2014 and the first half of 2015.However, everyone who is thinking about purchasing this game should weigh pro's and con's and decide for himself/herself if he/she really wants to have this game, since the complexity of some game mechanics and the large amount of time you need to devote to achieve a decent understanding of the game, probably scare a lot of people off only after a few minutes of playing the game.For those who absolutely adore games that need some time to get used to and to get started, this is for you. Unlike in a few other games, such as the infamous 'The Stomping Land', the building is not restricted to only a few buildings and objects, but it takes quite some time to reach the stage of actually constructing something big, so if you look for a game where you can build a castle within ten hours, then you are wrong with LiF:YO.I would also highly recommend only to play with a few friends, the more the better, as the unique skill system prevents one individual from learning all the skills that are out there, meaning that specializing on a skill tree (e.g. logging or terraforming), as the max cap of skill point will only be enough to absolutely maximize one skill tree.In general this game is great fun when you are with other people, but it is only a glimpse at the size and massiveness that LiF:MMO will bring in the third quarter of 2015.

content:
Posted: June 19, 2016
Product received for free
												Okay, so my friend decided to gift me this game because we were moving from Reign of Kings to Life is Feudal and it was my birthday at the time. Let's start with the general idea of the game, you are living in a medieval era and you need to survive which will require making many friends and joining up with small to large factions. If you're wondering why you need to do this, it's because the game is so time consuming that you need multiple people to do certain things (this is a pro and con depending on how you look at it) it's rather realistic to a degree that you can't just cut down a tree and store 5000 wood in your inventory, you must carry the log back to where you are stationed and then cut it into what you need (logs, boards ect).The game has amazing seasons, it's changing from winter, summer, spring and autumn constantly which makes the game constantly feel refreshing and you'll get a kick out of playing in the snow with your medieval bretheren by making snowballs or snowmen (snowwomen for all you feminists). Each season lasts a pretty long time varying from 2-3 weeks in real life time, this is immersive and allows you to really get into the game and interact with other people. As far as I can tell, the roleplaying in this game is amazing and the people I'm currently playing with are awesome and took me into their guild when I was by myself. I'm currently roleplaying as a Herbalist who specializes in selling explosions and potions, and managed to my♥♥♥♥♥whooped by someone who calls themselves "Witch of the Forest" as she slaughtered tons of my men on her own.You're capable of taming, breeding and capturing animals which you can use for numerous things like Milk, Eggs ect and horses which you are able to ride into combat, or just in general to get around easier. I had a horse named Snow, I rode her into combat and then she vanished never to be seen again (clearly she was stolen because of her natural beauty) but no one is owning up to it, ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s. Once you've managed to build your house, which is going to be stressful at first since it's kinda grindy (very on normal servers) you'll be able to actually build and put furniture inside which is part of the Carpentry skill I believe. You're also able to own shops, and perhaps even open up a trade route which other players will ride along in order to purchase your fine wares.You have no fall damage, this has to be addressed and while some may see it as a pro for how fun it can be to jump off mountains, it's really a con since it can kill immersion and really dull the mood a tad bit. Items don't seem to automatically stack sometimes, so you'll find yourself having to drag them onto each other in order to stack them up which is annoying. Sometimes you may find that you don't hit the target you're attacking, some think the hitbox is a little messy but this can be fixed by swinging just before you reach the target. You'll probably find yourself using a cart a lot since you'll be carrying large shipments of items from one place to another (from mining rocks and storing them in a cart to your base ect) and this'll be a tad annoying since it's rather slow, although you wouldn't see someone doing mach 10 while pulling a cart so just relax and try not to get annoyed by it. This game isn't supposed to be something where you build an empire in a day, it takes weeks upon weeks of gathering and interacting with other players so enjoy the experience and don't get too annoyed by the smaller things.Does this game have a friendly community? I've only played on one server, it's a big RP server and everyone on there is rather friendly assuming you are as well.Is this game worth buying? Indeed, you'll no doubt spend countless hours on this game If you have a love for survival games, roleplaying and medieval type games.WARNING:If you do not meet the minimum requirements for this game, chances are it won't allow you to start up so don't bother getting the game If you don't meet them. You'll be extremely disappointed.

Early Access Review
								Ignore all the bad reviews. People have no idea what they are talking about.1. Game developers are very active and interact with the community constantly.2. Each patch makes massive strides forward towards full release.3. The game mechanics are spot on. Gathering, crafting, mining and combat feels great.4. The game LOOKS and SOUNDS beautiful. This is quality.5. It takes me a minute to load into a game. People are not looking at server ping when connecting. It's not the game that sucks, it is their ISP.6. Learning curve is not steep -- game-play is very logical, just requires time and dedication.7. I can see this game being out of Early Access by the end of year for sure.I've spent MANY hours playing this game and can honestly say this is one of the best games on Steam. But, a lot of these negative reviews are coming from people who have no idea what they purchased. Here are a few helpful hints and tips about Life is Feudal: Your Own!1. Gather plant fibres from the ground. Useful flint front the mountains/hills, and branches from the trees.2. Craft primitive tools be right clicking on a branch. A primite shovel and axe and you are well on your way.3. Find a fairly flat piece of land and terraform just enough to build a little hut (4 x 4). Do this until your terraforming is at 60; then you can make a primitive pick-axe and use it to dig tunnels.4. This is not Minecraft.5. You can not enter a terrority that is claimed by someone else unless it is judgement hour.Buy this game. Especially now since it is on discount. WELL WORTH IT!!

content:
Posted: November 13, 2015
												Great sand-box multiplayer game. With a overall great community and interesting and engaging building/ crafting mechanics. Easy to learn and very hard to master. If you like medieval times, and working for what you get I recommend this game. If you are the type of player that wants to run around killing people without putting any time in, I would recommend you look else were. Not to say your play style is not welcomed, but game mechanics make players wait days, and weeks before they can craft their first sword. After that you have to wait a few weeks before you can actually use any good gear. Simply put if you want things to be done instantaneous you will not enjoy this game. It is very slow paced, but personally I like that aspect.If you enjoy making friends, and working together with other people, or to role-play heavily then I would recommend this game. The game mechanics forces players to work together to create any mid to end game buildings or gear. All skill trades intersect with each other, and all of them need each other's help. Because of this set up you will have to group up or trade if you want to create end game gear.devs are very good about updates (even if they fall behind) and are constantly listening to feed back and improving the core mechanics. The game is a bit expensive but I believe that it is worth every dollar.Update after relise. Nothing much changed

								The game is clearly still in early alpha but even so there are a lot of solid game mechanics. I don't really understand that to be perfectly honest. If it wasn't for one of my friends being a tanner then I'd never be able to become a Archer.Overall, the game has a long way to go before it meets it's goal but with buying this game in early access, you're supporting the devs in reaching that goal.

content:
Posted: December 25, 2014
Early Access Review
								For those too lazy to read my full review, this about sums it up:http://i1279.photobucket.com/albums/y532/aceskipper1/howlifreallyis_zps32bee31f.jpgThis game is increasingly difficult to review when you take into account certain factors that have affected it. Firstly, something I must of course say, the game is early-access alpha. It is still in development and so I appreaciate this and will not comment on the large amount of bugs and other "early-access" esque issues that the game has.I think that the paramount issue with Life is Feudal: YO is the simple fact that the advertisement for the game is misleading. Not on purpose mind, I simply feel as though the developers struggled to catagorize the game they have begun to produce and so consumers who stumble across it are not entirely sure what they are purchasing. I myself am very much into the Mount & Blade franchise and when I stumbled across this game I (and friends from my gaming community) expected it to be like a much larger open world RPG version of the mod for Mount & Blade: Warband, Persisitent World. The game showed pictures of an adventurer moving throughout a completely player made land. This gave me and my friends the misconception that the game was a Skyrim meets Mount & Blade meets Runescape/LOTR Online - what sounded like a perfect compliation.In actual fact the game is rust meets minecraft. It focuses on the survival aspect far more than the roleplaying rpg medieval aspect. This should be advertised FAR more clearly as survival game fans would appreciate it much more than Medieval role-play fans. Let me try to explain in a DayZ way, the server owners and their friends run around in full armour (like bandits/heroes) whilst everyone else hops from server to server with a few rags, they try to do something but every time they leave the server are forced to try again thanks to a lack of server favouriting implementation. This is fine, particularly in Alpha, but not what I thought when I was buying it.Good game for what it is in its current stage, but misleading in its advertisement and so that is forcing me to give it a negative review.Buy the game if you want a Rust esque survival, not a medieval RP RPG MMO sandbox game.

content:
Posted: February 15, 2015
Early Access Review
								Remember:- life is feudal!Positives:- LiF:YO caters to a wide range of interests.  Ever wanted to be a town planner in medieval Europe?  Love farming simulation but kinda feel like a cheat sitting in a John Deere?  Fascinated by the history of feudal times and want to live it just a little?  Know the theories of Marx, Durkheim, and Weber and are interested in the sociological concepts of individualism and collectivism and want to try living in an age with a whole other mindset?  Or just love gearing up in metal stuff and hitting people with swords?  You will enjoy this game.Negatives:- This is where it gets hard.  Having played over 1000 hours before making this review.  just about all the things that I would have seen as a negative have improved or been fixed altogether.  The dev team has been brilliant, and if they keep delivering like they have, LiF:YO will go from being a great Alpha to a fantastic release.  Anyone who wrote a review not recommending the game essentially because it is Alpha should do the honest thing and try the game out again, then adjust their review if the problems they experienced have lessened or gone away.Gameplay:-  The most important thing to get right playing this game is to play it with other people.  Seriously.  If I had a thin leather for every player I've seen try to solo this game, and after a day or three depart forever leaving nothing but a tiny plaster shack, a furnace, and some unfinished wattle fencing, I'd have enough to armor 100 novice archers.  Remember, life is feudal.  In feudal times the average serf lived within spitting distance of at least a dozen other average serfs.  "Ah!" I hear you say; "serfing isn't for me, I'll be a Lord or at least someone rich enough to own flanged mace!".  Sure, in which case you'll need to be around even more people.  Coz heres the thing ok, Life is Feudal is about feudal life.  You ain't going to build any legends or awesome stories on your own.  Join a community, build a community, invite your friends, make new ones, whatever it takes, play this game with as many other people as you can.What could be improved:-  We're still waiting on a number of important features to be added, but LiF developers have been consistent in delivering updates and have issued a time frame for key updates to come.  In terms of adding to gameplay, all I'd suggest is added variation to life events.  Given there is no specific end game, interest in the game comes through experiencing different things.  Therefore the game is improved through increased variation of features and of random events.  Weather could have more influence on a range of gameplay aspects, illness (and alchemical medicines) could be introduced, random OP animals, NPCs in distress, custom weapons crafting, random disasters, and above all anything that enhances group-oriented and co-dependent play.  Why is there no specific end game?  Because this is about life... is... feudal, remember?

content:
Posted: February 24, 2016
												I was reading some of the negative reviews for this game at first and after playing it wondered why it's received enough bad reviews to get the "Mixed" designation on steam. As you continue to play the game it becomes apparent though. Most of the "survival" genre fanbase is looking for something they can call "realistic" without having to put in the effort this game requires. Most gamers these days are all about instant gratification with minimal effort. Everything in the game takes time to build and to become proficient at. Couple that with a fanbase where 1/2 or more of the players come from games like DayZ or Minecraft, where important items are found at random on the ground and crafting is simple, and it shouldnt come to anyone's surprise that there would be enough bad reviews on steam to turn heads.All that being said, this game is a community effort that is made more enjoyable by either a small group of dedicated players or a larger one all pitching in for a specific goal. For me, its been a great experience with very few things to complain about. I have put a good chunk of time into it so far and plan to continue doing so. To be honest, it would be a disservice to the devs not to give them credit for what they have accomplished with this game, which is why i felt the need to write this in the first place. Hope this is helpful to some fans of the survival genre on the fence about buying the game!

number of helpful: 19 of 26 people (73%) found this review helpful6 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 2, 2016
												To think that this game has "Recent: Mixed, Overall: Mixed" is madness. If I hadn't already bought and played this game (albeit for cheaper from a Humble Bundle), I probably would already have left the store page. Don't.This game is amazing. This game is so amazing. The crafting system is deep. The world in which you live is vast. Ok, so the combat system is hard, and is a little bit like mount & blade except you can't just swing your sword around and expect to kill everything -- you have to learn IRL how to do it, making sure that the correct part of your weapon hits the correct part of your oponent. But, this game is so fun, it's worth it.When you join a server, be careful, because if the GMs (that's the admins) are abusing their power, you may find a server that is two weeks old yet the GMs and their friends just happen to have stone castles. Yeah right. But there are some decent servers you can find by browsing the LiF forums, and if you want my advice, go for an RP PVP server.The RP is important in a game like this because it improves immersion. When someone rides up to you on a horse and hails you, and you're just a dirty little peasant with soil in your fingernails like a 9 year old boy who has been eating worms all morning, it's better to say HAIL MY LORD, I AM JUST PASSING THROUGH I MEAN NO HARM, than it is to go 'orite gr8 game isnt it'. When you turn up at the capital to trade and everyone is in RP, it's kind of like when you retired on World of Warcraft to an RP server so you could relax. It's all very cool.The crafting system is immense and I'm only at the wooden wall level, getting thin leather from hares. I don't even own sheep yet and a pig tried to gore me and I hadn't even drank any wine. There are lots of weapons. The armour is cool. But there is something even cooler, a really cool concept. You better still be reading this you peasant.Claims.So claims are these really cool things. A big sword sticking out of the ground, but it is how you create a guild. The best thing is that it gives you ownership of the land in a (to begin with) 10 tile radius. This goes up to 20 tiles, but you'll have to upgrade it if you want it to go further, up to 150 tiles (that's big (that's what she said)).This game has so much to offer. If it goes on sale, just buy it.One last thing, be prepared. It's one of "them games". One of the achievements is "just 5 more minutes" which is to play for 12 hours without disconnecting. Yeah hit that a few times. Another is "my second life" which is played for > 100 hours. I'll be there soon. Be prepared to be totally immersed, totally humbled, and totally awed.And if you need a server that is free from GM abuse or sophomoric peasant-hunting, message me.Now I gotta go cut trees down.
