content:
Posted: October 2, 2014
Early Access Review
								First, you've got to understand this is an early alpha version of the game.  With that said, it's in a pretty advanced state and a lot of fun already. But here are a few key things to keep in mind: - Some things are not yet implemented. Actually a lot of things, but there is still a ton to do in the game. - This is not a quick action crafting/building game like Minecraft.  It takes hours (real time) to build a small mine looking for metal ores.  As you mine out a tunnel, you collect the rocks, you have to take those rocks and dump them somewhere or craft them into shaped stones (which are just as heavy as the rocks) so you must store them somewhere, then you can go back to mining.  It's a slow process...not for those who lack patience. For me it is relaxing, but your results may vary.- In fact getting your skills up to the point where you can even mine takes a long time.  On the default settings, it takes hours of using your skills to raise them to the point where you learn new things.  The settings are customizable so each server can adjust them to speed things (even to the point of the rediculous). - Single Player: There is essentially no single player (at least not in the normal PvE sense).  You can start a local server, make it private and no one else can join, then experiment all you want, but it will be a big lonely world.  I've split my time between experimenting on a solo local server and playing public servers.  Both are fun for me...  - Community: The server you join will make all the difference in terms of your enjoyment.  I've been servers where I was welcomed into a community, given a house, invited in to start working on my skills to be a productive member of that village.  And I've been on servers where people have been complete jerks.  There are hundreds of servers, find one that suits you.TL;DR: If you're patient and looking for a slow paced, realistic game that is still in development, then this may be your game.  If you're looking for something with wall-to-wall action, keep looking, this ain't it.

Early Access Review
								It's not often that I get super psyched by an alpha release. This is one of those magical exceptions.It's from Russia, and I love it. Life is Feudal is the sandbox I've been waiting for. Even in its alpha stage it has a load of content, and runs fairly well. That's saying something for me having an old laptop for a rig. The building is complex, you can sculpt every inch of the terrain, and there's more on the horizon. This version, "LiF: Your Own," is the small-scale version of the planned MMO. This map is a few KM across, the eventual will be massive. This map holds 64 players. The eventual will hold thousands.I'm already super into this game, and I imagine I'll be unemployed once the MMO drops.

												I had this game for a long time but only recently I decided to rent my own server for myself and friends to play.Now this is like my virtual home.At first I did play it as survival game, looking for food and some primitive instruments.Then settled on the lakeside and mined some copper to craft some tools.Then enabled Admin mode to play around and test a blueprint for my future settlements.Leveling ground for the keep takes time even in GM/Admin mode but placing down and walking around it is a lot of fun.Not sure I am going to keep it, because it does not seem to be very practical.Summer solstice is coming, so I created place to celebrate it. content:
Posted: April 17, 2016
												Where to begin?Life is Feudal should ideally be played with a group.This game is entirely playable for a solo player, but your enjoyment will likely suffer greatly alone.Most complex building tasks are entirely too grindy when attempted solo, but servers are full of cooperative people willing to show you the ropes. I reccomend either buying this game to play with friends, or searching out a group to join asap once you get started.While I am not a roleplayer, this game has a vast potential for roleplaying, and skill caps can be setup to create an economy where every character is forced to specialize rather than max every skill. The social aspect of this game is what makes the grind feel worthwile.The grind can be partially mitigated by server customization as well. Servers with XP settings between 25-100x the default are common. The learning curve is a bit steep, and crafting can be complex.This game has a significant PvP component, and allows players to beseige each others lands. This means potentially looting and burning weeks of work in one day, but creates real risk, and winning a battle feels significant.The times and dates for this can be customized, and PvE servers exist as well for the feint of heart.In all likelyhood you will either love this game or uninstall it in under 2 hours. Most of this depends on your choice to play alone or with others.

content:
Posted: September 27, 2014
Early Access Review
ALPHA REVIEW: I understand the game is in Alpha, but I'm just pointing on my thoughts on the current state of the game. I would recommend this game to help support the developers as I really like the game and it looks as though is has a bright future with a lot of playablility, especially when enjoyed with a group of friends.A few people have asked for my opinions on this game, so here they are.The Good:1. The visuals of the game are really nice. The whole thing looks atmospheric, deep forests, rich villages and nice vistas give the player a nice experience from just walking around. 8/102. The Ideas that the game portrays are very good. There's a very in-depth crafting system and a good building placement system which have little floors but there could be a bit more done to liven them up a bit. 7/103. The general gameplay is very nice. Being able to enjoy it with your friends is great and the contact currently in the game is brilliant! There's a lot of fun to be had here!The bad:1. Performance. I run this game with a 3.4GHz i5 processor and a GTX780 NVIDIA graphics card. If I bump the settings up a bit from the defaults, maybe I increase the tree/terrain detail a bit, my FPS drops a large amount, heading down towards 20FPS. But the game is ENTIRELY playable on the default settings and still looks really good, I'm just not sure how it will run on lower processors/cards.2. Terrain interaction. The way that you interact with terrain/rocks/trees in this game is very bulky. You look at a tree/terrain segment and are faced with about a dozen options, which for a new player is quite overwhelming. Everything is based on: "Look down at terrain" -> "Click" -> "Select option" -> "Animation plays" -> "You get things". There is currently no real player interaction with the environment around you.The Ugly:1. The UI. Some elements of the UI, mainly linked with the terrain interaction above don't look or feel very nice. But this is an Alpha and that can change VERY easily.I will certainly be playing more of this game with a few friends of mine. If you think this game has a bright future like I do then grab a copy, test the bejeebus out of it and send those bug reports flying in!

content:
Posted: July 22, 2016
												Good concept, bad execution. The game is built on an old 32 bit engine that limits its use of RAM, resulting in server crashes, and loads of buggy features. There are many combat bugs in the game that the devs dont fix. You can be decked out in the best of the best, then some guy, naked with just his fists, can use a combat bug to one shot you nonstop. Arrows have ghosting problems, Game is overwhelmingly grindy. The most recent patch even reduced the amount of resource you get for a particular proffession by 75%, making the game even grindier. No optomization at all,things break nonstop, corrupt fils force server restarts to happen often, resulting in all your hard work being lost. Is this game worth its price? No.  Avoid the headache and pick up a better optomized game that isnt plauged by game breaking bugs.

content:
Posted: October 14, 2014
Early Access Review
								Grown men chopping wood, cleaning out chicken coops, leveling ground, making soup and hunting moose sound like fun?  Well, it is in Life is Feudal!  Actions build skills, skills are necessary to aquire the ability to do more.  Castles need building, you don't just get to walk up to your own pre-built structure.  There are dangers in the forest and apples to find to keep you alive.  The resource and tech tree in this game is perhaps the most detailed I have ever seen in a game.  There is drudge work, but the reward is seeing a castle that you are building come to life.  With enough armor, weapons, skills and friends, it will then be time to find a few serfs to do the drudge work for you.My best wishes to the developers of this game to work out the bugs, create an ingame economy, an inplement all the cool features that are still in development.  This game has ALL the potential to be one of the all time great ones!

number of helpful: 12 of 21 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 24, 2014
Early Access Review
								Read before you buy!First off, this game has mixed reviews. So I would just like to remind those reading, that this game is still in very early access. With the engine the game uses, it's advancements, and everything the devs are trying to do, it will take time for full release, possibly even a year or 2. With that in mind, don't judge this game based on everything currently in it, things can and will change.Now that that's out of the way, let me start by saying yes, this game is a grind (as of now). Why? Because this game was built for realism. Rome wasn't built in a day, nor will you build your small shack in one. This game is realistic in almost every aspect, between it's physics based combat system which doesn't require you to aim at someone, to its resource gathering, and construction system. Even its mining system requires you to use supports otherwise you risk a cave in. And while it may be a graphics hog, that's because it's still not very optimized, but as I have said it's only an alpha. However, you can't deny that the game looks really good. Can you guys imagine on the full release, with around 1000 people on one world, what the game will look like in a month? Think about it, you start in an area with nothing but trees and such, along with 999 other people. One month later, you have huge medieval cities with giant walls, lined with trebuchets and ballistas. Huge wars going on between player factions. We can literally recreate historical events in this game with how well it's been designed and planned. So, if you're still reading, then you know this game is a very realistic game. So please, don't judge this game just because it's realistic. Judge it for it's aspects, judge it for it's gameplay. If you don't like realism, don't judge it at all. Besides, if you don't like realism, why would you be playing a game like this? What it all boils down to is if you like realism like I do, and billions of others do as well, then this game may just be for you. However that depends on what degree of realism you like. If you don't like the grind (which may or may not be fixed later on and shortened) then you may not like this. So TL;DR, if you like realism, but don't like a grind, this isn't for you. If you like realism, it might be for you. This game is highly based on realism, so if you don't like realism at all, why are you here? It's still alpha, so don't judge based on how the game works now, base your reviews and judgements off of the actual gameplay.

content:
Posted: February 9, 2015
												This game is truly a masterpiece when it comes to sandbox survival games.It is all there needs to be to make a successful game of the genre. For one i would say the best feature is the hardcoreness and the complexity of the mechanics and how the game works. Sure the game could be even more complex which developers are working hard to deliver (new features etc), sure it could have NPCs and better AI but in its current state it's truly worth the price.If you have been let down by the multitude of early access medieval survival games spamming this overcrowded market, you should get this one and stick to it until the end. The game has close to no bugs at the moment, the developers are close to the community, the road map is respected by days or even hours, this is not a hit and run like many other early access games.The graphics are astonishing, the game runs well on any PC (the only issue which is not really an issue are loading screens when joining a server taking too long if you don't run the game in windowed mode).All in all, i recommend this game fully, if you are looking for some fun and rewarding experience. Disclaimer : If you are looking for a spoon fed baby's first minecraft-like experience this game is not for you.

content:
Posted: January 18, 2016
												Right. So, this one is a bit conditional, i can't just say "Yes or No."Ok, do you like rust style gameplay?Do you like combat similar-ish to Chivalry/Mount&Blade?Do you have a lot of free time?Do you have at LEAST two other people to play with, or are you willing to join a random group on a server? (3 other people or more recommended)If you answered YES to at elast three out of the four questions, you'll love it. Just like I did. Sadly my group got bored and i sort of ell off. You CAN NOT solo this game. You can not be a jack of all trades. Think of it as medieval rust, but much more serious feeling; more realistic, more time consuming, etc. Again, in rust you find a blueprint, and you can build it. In LiF, you have all the blueprints, but you need the skills to use them. You chop trees, you become a better lumber jack. You cut wood, you become a better carpenter. You mold stone, you become a better mason. You CAN NOT be a jack of all trades. The more you specialize, the better, but you have to fill all roles to prosper. So, the beauty of other players comes in. If you have a person for each role, you can all fully excel - OR you can spread yourselves among two or three trades, lowering your specialization and skill in each, but making up for the lack of people. In other words, the main limiting factor is the number of people you need. if a few people get bored, its over for all of you unless you can replace them. So, if you can get a group of people you trust to commit, or if you can join a server and are willing to ask in chat to join someone long term (wouldnt recommend, the early game was my favorite, watching your mud huts evolve to cabins, to outposts, to pallisades, to castles is an amazing thing and joining late game when they're fully militarized robs you of that joy... however it is useful for learning the ropes.)But as much as the intensive human cost is a con, it is also a pro for the game. Playing with friends in it is amazing, as you're all working together for a common long term goal. the interactions are great, and there's a nice social aspect.Speaking of such, i would love to get back into the game. If a group of people needs an extra sword at your side, feel free to message me, be you a group of friends jsut getting the game, or just people that need to replace someone or expand.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 13, 2016
												I got this game from the Humble Bundle, at a friend's recommendation, and I'm very happy that I did. (I'd definitely recommend that you wait until it's on sale before purchase, but that's just because of the state of the game. It's constantly being patched though, which is nice.)It's a very complicated game, and if you don't like to ask for advice or use the Wiki to get an idea of what you should be doing, then this game isn't for you (YET) - keep in mind that most servers have a very helpful playerbase, though, as they all started where you are! Skill caps can be painful (though some servers have it set at 3000, which means with time you can do everything yourself if you want to keep busy), but do encourage a grouping mentality and specialisation, which is nice. I've made some good friends on the game already.If you're playing on a server where Judgement Hour and Decay are in effect, suit up and claim up respectively. I've found that PVPers enjoy using JH as an excuse to grief or troll, as it doesn't reduce your alignment to 'commit crimes' during this time; if you're a bandit outside of it, your alignment decreases and your name changes from white, to orange and then to red below -50. It does, however, encourage tactics and teamwork, whether offensive or defensive, amongst your guild.Decay is what keeps each server clean. Items off-claim decay and are destroyed at a pre-assigned (by the GM) rate, or not at all on some servers. It's easy to tell because damage effects are applied, and it's just better to make even a tier-1 monument claim and store all your stuff on it, than to lose it all the time.Server Wipes are done on many servers every few months; I've avoided servers with server wipes, so I can't really judge, but I'd rather avoid my hours of hard work being put to the torch!Best Advice: If you want to travel fast and ride horses eventually, set Warhorse Handling to 60 at character creation. It is by FAR the most painful skill to level otherwise!

												I really enjoyed the pace of Life is Feudal. This game makes you feel accomplished for everything you build. Just leveling the ground takes hours, and gathering materials makes the game feel genuine. Me and 3 of my friends spent 80+ hours making our small out of the way village.  Hauling lumber up to our encampment was an all day task. One friend collected ore, and another smithed it. While me and my other friend leveled ground, and built structures. Our base was finally coming together and then it happened...the server we were on got restarted because only like 5-10 people were coming on anymore. We haven't played together since. The biggest issue I had when I played was that when the new day started the whole server would lag for a minute.

content:
Posted: June 28, 2016
												I'm gonna keep this short and sweet.This game is very in depth, almost punishingly so. But that sense of pure ecstatic euphoria when you hold that freshly forged Zweihandler ready to meet out medieval Punisher style justice on banditry and peasantry alike is indescribable.This game does not hand you the world, you scrap, scratch, claw and punch for dear life.It is difficult to get a grip on the games crafting and mechanics. But in the end, after several hours mining, more hours smelting, multiple hours forging as you don you're meticulously crafted helm ready to protect the home you scratched together from rocks and twigs in the begining.If you want 'ease' and a peaceful medieval fantasy to kick back in and live a second life, redirect yourself to Wurm: Unlimited, just as rewarding but not as punishing. But if you want a harsh, unforgiving and brutality brutal world to rise in, Life Is Feudal is the choice for you.

content:
Posted: March 22, 2016
												If you've ever wanted a simulation of what it's like to live in a medieval world, look no further. Life is Feudal brings the best aspects of several other games and mixes them together for a product that is on the mark. Despite being in development stages and with a limited team, they've continually improved the game and brought out new features. It's a game that's true to its form, brutal, unforgiving, and immersive. It's what you make of it...and in a generation of gaming that's handing everything to everyone, that's as appealing as the rest.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 25, 2016
												Don't be fooled by all the negative reviews. Life is Feudal is a really wonderful game.It is not an EASY game by any means. I do not reccomend playing it alone. Get four or five good friends to play with you or join a server. Life is Feudal is a cooperative game. You can scrape by on your own, sure, but you won't advance past the Stone Age. If you think you can log on, build a castle in two hours, and log off, you've got another thing coming. LiF doesn't hand you goodies on a silver platter. If you've got a hardworking team of people, though, you can accomplish some really awesome stuff. For example: my boyfriend and I joined a server and started working toward building a house of our own. We felt insanely accomplished when we managed to build two hovels and kill a stag. It was an enormous rush! LiF makes you work for every single thing you get. As a result, the rewards matter a lot more. We eventually joined up with a bigger town and became Master Armorsmiths. It was amazing to see our hard work pay off. It gave me a sense of accomplishment unlike any other game I've played.LiF is hard and can be pretty punishing. But the difficulty makes your rewards that much more awesome. You understand the value of an item because you worked hard to get it. Here are the bad parts: the games crashes frequently and load times are awful. Except to spend 5-10 minutes per load screen. Plus, it's a memory hog. Buyer beware if you're running it on a laptop or an older PC.

								This game is probably the best survival based multiplayer game I've ever played. It takes a lot of elements from really good survival games like Day Z, Rust, and many others. Combines them and makes the perfect survival game. The main thing about this game that I love is the focus on community. To be able to get far in this game you need other people, plain and simple. The only thing I don't like about this game is the combat tree parts of it really don't make sense, but hey it's in alpha so I'm sure they'll tweak it here and there before release. If you're considering buying life is feudal do it and make sure you get some friends to do it as well.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 10, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game is not fun, but you still play it. When you're in a community its like your duty to play this game. After mining for 3 days, mining for gold it clicked... this sucks. ....but they need this gold!! I must continue. You constantly stare at a green progress bar, everything you do you must stare at that green bar. You can't make macros either, no simple ones anyways. Before you invest your money into this fairly expensive early access game you'll need to know a few things. Don't plan to play this alone, this game is definitely for you and at least 2 other people if you want to get anywhere. It is a great game and most of its current features are solid, but as you play you'll realise that even to build the smallest house you'll need a few different professions first. With limited skill points you must specialize and so will your friends all depending on each other. I recommend this game as a temporary thing for a big group of friend. Minimum 3 people to play this game. If you play alone don't buy this game.

content:
Posted: October 11, 2014
Early Access Review
								Life is feudal is way to early in development to give any accurate fullscale ''review''.However I can give it my thoughts, and in the end Ill only recommend it or not.So pros;An amazingly detailed crafting system(imo) Non targetting combatVisuals are satisfying Gameplay*SoundtrackCons;Sounds, (not all of them, but alot of them)Crafting system will limit your progress when you are playing soloHalf of the skills not Implemented yetAlot of time will be spent looking at a progress barAlpha feel to the game (chunky, some stuff dont work, a few bugs and crashes)Conclusion;So if you can get your friends together, and you can get past the alpha feel of the game, and dont care to much about progress bar. If you punch through those cons you will be greeted by some great settings and if you got your friends to come along with you, then youll have hours after hours of gameplay. Personally I have to recommend this early alpha to fans of the genre, its not amazing, not claiming that, however there certainly are some great potential.For more info about the game features, see, ''Life is Feudal'' website

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 9, 2014
Early Access Review
								When I first saw this game (I forget where) I thought it was the game of dreams. An open world sandbox MMORPG set in a a medeival setting. Then I noticed the steep price of £25 (or your regional equivalent). However after seeing the trailer and some streams of the game in action I was convinced. For an alpha it runs quite well with the expected bug here and there but hey, its an alpha. Most the the games terraforming and building mechanics are pretty much to point but could do with some polishing. With frequent updates and bug fixes it gives me a good reason to trust the devs behind this game.After playing for hours alone I realised I needed to either find some friends to join me on my adventure though the world and increase chances of survival. Or find a friendly group of players who will accept me into their community. (Dont expect everyone to be friendly, this is the medeival ages). As I mentioned after hours of play with friends we finally have a little lake side village which is progressing nicely. A farm, some houses and soon to be a forge.We hope to gain some weapons soon and either :TAX THE PEASANTS (other players)orHunt down criminals (Bad rep players)However.The combat for ranged weapons is very clunky and can be unreliable. Melee is more reliable at the current moment but could really do with some work.Final opinion 8/10Pros:-Sandbox-Will soon be an MMORPG-Player driven-Strong sense of community-Highly addictiveCons:-Steep alpha price-Clucky combat in the current build

								Life is feudal is a very hard game getting into, sure there are some minor issues as it is just an alpha still but they dont hide it.This game shows you that you really need to work together or you will have to struggle to survive. You spawn naked confused and without any tools. Sure you get some commentary rags but well pretty much you are ♥♥♥♥ed. Think like you would be a prisoner and left at the beach of a uninhabitated island or stranded there cause you fell of a ship.The best part about the game is that it is realistic. Sure it is in alpha and there for needs some fixes but mostly it is goodSome other good stuffs are the amount of things you can do to change the world and how it looks. You can break things, build things and simply make it yours. Not to mention the hardship, You spawn with five cookies, in the beginning you think well this is easy I can survive long on this........ sure you can survive a few days on it and in my opinion too long. But once you are out of them and starving, crawling on all fours trying to find something eatable in the grass it is suddenly not so easy anymore. ALSO NO LEVELS ONLY SKILLS! The bads stuff then, claims! Sure you dont want anyone messing with you castle while you are away as it takes a lot of ♥♥♥♥ing time building it. But I am not talking about those claims, I am talking about claims on logs and smaller items. Try building something when you got to wait 2 minutes after someone brought you the log as it is not yours. This slow down the working speed. Also there is no option to turn off the claims as it would be nice having one for when you host a serverapart from that it is just stuff that can be cause of the alpha. The skill trees are weird and almost random what you need to do something, The are hard to understand and well once you do they are just so simple. You dont have sub catagories or much selection of them, it would be nice seeing a bigger skill tree with a more logical design. Cause building a wooden shack is not under carpentry which is like ehm okay, But instead it is in the tree that builds stuff out of clay and bricks. Which makes little sense, Their wiki is also kind of hard to use as it speaks off ideas of the game not the actual game also lacking in contextOver all it is a good game just remember it is in Alpha and not a easy game to get into

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 24, 2014
Early Access Review
								I have approximatley 30 hours of actual gameplay, and I love this game! Its a great sandbox/terraform game. It has an awesome military mix in with it.Pros-You can make the game more difficult or easier based on the skill leveling multiplier. You can also change how fast things grow, smelt etc. The terrain when terraforming has a great reaction based on a more real life scale. The weapons and armors are a harder thing to make so it takes a lot of time for a group of people to turn in to pvp maniacs.Cons- The BIGGEST con right now is the launcher. It needs a lot of work. If I leave a server or want to change characters I actually consider not playing, because the launcher is incredibly slow and there are times it doesn't want to cooperate at all. I also have had a hard time hosting a server. There are some small bugs related to it being a new game, i.e. some terrain issues where you can see through the map or trees look like they hover.Conclusion- I would give this game in total a 6.8/10. For a BRAND new game I would give it a 8.8/10. The game has GREAT potential! I would highly recommend giving it a try, right now I think its worth the $40 and with the reaction we have seen fromt he developers I think in a couple months it would be worth more!

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 28, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game is everything I wanted in a Medieval game. The creativity it allows is amazing, It truly is a sandbox inwhich anything is possible. This is very early days for this game and so it has its bugs and issues but that was expected. The game itself plays well and looks reasonable. You begin with absolutely nothing except the clothes on your back and you have to start from scratch to make a name for yourself. It gives you no hints and just throws you out there to work it out on your own which I feel is great. Everything is done logically so you just have to think what you would need to do IRL and it is likely how you do it in game.Words cannot describe how happy I am that this game is being developed and I have high hopes for its future. Definetly worth the buy.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 24, 2014
Early Access Review
								So far, so awesome.I went out on a limb getting this game and do not regret it at all. It's as if minecraft and Skyrim were mushed in to one incredible sandbox experience. I could take quite a while extolling the virtues of the game but I'll break it down to pro's vs cons. Pros:-Totally sandbox. You can do practically anything given the proper skills. -No "levelling" in the traditional sense. Your skills accrue as you use them, just like Elder Scrolls or Mount and Blade.-(opinion) Mounta and blade style combat system. If you don't know what I'm talking about, check it out, it's really cool.-Friendly community. With few exceptions I have not seen nor experienced greifing by other players, and everybody if pretty helpful when possible (not any "experienced" players yet, since the game is in development still)-The crafting and building system is very intuitive, but there are some guidelines built in so you know what you need to get to make stuff.-There's a huge variety of things to do and make in the game, despite it being in early stages, you won't get bored.Con's-The server screen is fairly buggy, and takes a while to get situated, so be patient with it. -It can be hard on graphics, but with a game like this that is par for the course.-(this can go the other way for some) The learning curve can get pretty crazy, and there aren't many guides out there. But doesn't that just make getting things right more rewarding? Once you get the hang of things it will go much more smoothly-Fairly regular crashes. Just today I had three crashes and a few server time-outs, that's going to happen a bit as many servers are privately run. Of course, my internet is not the most stable, either. -No single player. This game is larger than one person is supposed to deal with, anyway. If you want to be on your own, you're gonna have some problems. but you can try if you want. Overall, this game has 10/10 potential but currently rests around an 8.If you're feeling adventurous and want to be part of something new and exciting, get this game.

Early Access Review
								Fun game, everything is still being worked on but one of the best prospects I've seen in a while. $40 price tag on steam or $35 at the devs website, I know it seems high to some people but I've spent more on less to be honest most of us gamers have. The combat seems alot like Mortal Online except the hit detection and character movement is much better. It feels like a polished version of MO in alot of ways though the game is in its early alpha. With an inventory system like Darkfall, some of the stuff I've read makes it sound like seiges will be an event similiar to Darkfall (This guess comes from reading the skills under Piety).  Would I recommend buying this game? If you have rent payed with the rest of your bills, Absolutly! I see no reason not to drop a couple bucks on an eager developer, with a great concept, and a good start.

content:
Posted: September 25, 2014
Early Access Review
								I've tried a lot of survival games. So many that I hesitate to buy them when they come out. Nether was a terrible mistake, and I paid 40 for it as well. I was telling my friend about it and he bought it for me. Bad♥♥♥♥♥ I logged on and it was hard getting in the server, but what drew me right away was the music, very Celtic like, I like that a lot. So learning how to craft is hard, and trying to figure out the mechanics of the game was hard. But once I learned how to play, I was immediately hooked. This game is AWESOME. There is no zone in and get shot like in games like Rust, where the call of duty crowd come in and make it a shoot on sight game. I had people helping me, working together, making new friends right away. Because the crafting isn't "instant" like in a lot of these crafting games. You have to put work in. When I leveled my ground and built my first shack...it is amazing. There is so much more you can accomplish. I'm still living in the stone age right now, moving toward getting iron. This is worth every cent you pay. If you like crafting, open world sandbox, making new friends....and eventually enemies that have what you want you will love this game. Patience though is needed, I don't feel like this is a "casual game". You have to dedicate some time to build up. Join a community or go at it alone it is your decision.

content:
Posted: September 27, 2014
Early Access Review
								medival survival game ( realistic! ) thats total hardcore in it base ... the graphics are not the world best.. but there are more than ok .. you over see the graphical quality realy fast when you get into the game ...at this early stage the game isent easy with you .. no form of telling you how and what to do ... some bugs here and there .. but nothing major i have discoverd yet ( tho my friends complain over usb audio devices wont work for them .. i have a g930 wireless headset that works perfect )  but its early access so be prepared for BUGS  =) This game is quite hard to learn .. its already a big puzzel on  finding out why you cant do this or this .. the game lacks good feedback .. lacks aym anny way of telling you how it works ( you should watch youtube videos to learn the basics of the game !!!) therefor this game is as hard to learn as eve online is ... but it has hardcore gaming mecanics like eve too....first of is it worth the mony? it realy depents on the developer .. well he complete his game? ( have seen many project stop latly after a short while ) will they improve on how things work and maybe change some gaming mekanics here and there to make the game easyer?will they expand content? fix console commands and so on ?(for admins and gms)if the awnser is eas to most of my question ... then yes its worth every penny you pay.let me start off with .. survival gamesa are quite in atm .. most of them have zombies and monsters that fight you almost nonstop .. this game says ♥♥♥♥ that ... lets make a realistic survival game ... and thats good .( ofcourse you need to like this type of a game) the game evolves around players on the enviroment. you make your own story .. faction? and so on you say what happens. it takes a♥♥♥♥♥♥amount of time to even build your first house ..  the look of like its now you use at least a year befor you have a castle ... the skill system is realy good and simple .. tho as mentiont the crafting system is hard to understand from one time to a nother becouse of the lac of feedback and information ( som minor bugs don make it easyer ) i love tho how you can play together and build .. work as a team and so on ..so i recoment this game if you like medival faction coop based( there is no faction system in the game... so this is kind of role play !) dont care about fancy graphics , fancy voxel system like minecraft and so on .. the game has is own quality the way id does stuff =) build an empire out of dirt  =)

content:
Posted: January 12, 2015
Early Access Review
								Damn... This is a role playing paradise. I've sunken thirty hours into this game and I already have the reputation of Okravaaz Draaf the revolutionist. Wow... Off to the review :D!====================================================================================Gameplay: The gameplay is not molded by the developers but rather the community. My most memorable moments were of course not staring at a green bar, but they were about meeting new people and speaking to old friends. I even started a revolution against the almighty leader of the server. That was fun. (4/4)Graphics: The game doesn't look very pleasing, but it isn't terrible either. (2/4)Preformance: The game preforms almost horrible. I guess it is playable, but it certaintly isn't pleasing on the eyes. (1/4)Realism: The description of this game basicaly sums it up. The most god damn realistic mmo I have ever seen. While its graphics may not be good and it may not preform great, the game is so realistic I think I've been blinded. The game basicaly reflects on what it would ACTUALY be like in the wilderness. I would say you would need the help of five or ten people just to get new CLOTHING. (4/4)    This game scored a total of 55%. I know you think that's a terrible score, because it is, but the only real downsides to this are its graphics and preformance. So as long as you have relatively strong eyes and a decent computer, you should be able to enjoy this game.-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------NOTES*The game is relatively slow moving, and you're going to want a day or two of free time to actualy enjoy the game.-SharkTurd, C.E.O. SharlBird Inc.

content:
Posted: September 22, 2014
Early Access Review
								Badass game. If you're looking for an open world survival MMO, this is it. This is my first experience on a new server with everything brand new. You start off this game with basically a handful of cookies. Your first job, build a tool. So you walk over to a tree, snap off a twig. Alright now I got my base, let's find a rock and some string to put this thing together. Gather stone from a stone surface randomly on the ground and make some twine from grass. Sweet got my axe crafted. Eventually I get all my tools and started looking for a couple of people to group with. All the reviews said there were friendly people and to my surprise, there were♥♥♥♥♥♥tons of them. I play a lot of Rust so I'm use to the Kill on sight attitude, but I felt guilty trying to smack someone with my axe and they couldn't even techically fight. Without a tool you have nothing, you can't even punch. I don't know if that will be fixed, but I like it. There is never a reason to kill one unless you're an♥♥♥♥♥ really. So I tagged up with that guy and we got a campfire going. Started talking to people in global to see who had a base. Turns out no one really even had a settlement, we were in the very beginning of the game. So we sent out the word where we were and people started flooding into our group. We had a couple lumberjacks cutting down trees, two guys fishing for food, another two looking for berrys and gubs, and a handful of guys up the the mountain mining some ore. Then we started to build up a town. Eventually I had to log out, but it was pretty awesome that we all came together to get a base going. We heard of other big settlements popping up on the other end of the island. Already we were planning war.  8/10. I would say 10/10, but plenty of bugs still. It is early access so I'm sure my score will change.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 4, 2014
Early Access Review
								Very promising - There is a surprising amount of content to explore given that this is an early access game. PROS:- Many of the complex systems are already in place (such as terraforming, construction, logging, etc.) which is good as this is a crafting game at  heart. - The huge crafting and skill systems require specialization as you have a finite number of skill points to allocate (on most servers). - This is great for encouraging player interaction and community building. The idea of having a town blacksmith that you need to go to for swords and armor, a logger to cut your trees, etc. is a lot of fun and not something a lot of games like to encourage. You're not a god, you can't do everything on your own.CONS:- Combat is promising and deep but not very satisfying at the moment.- Long server load times (seriously, be patient).- The engine needs optimization. This isn't up to the Life is Feudal dev team but it does affect their game.- Occasional bugs and some people experience frequent crashing.CONCLUSION:If the dev team can continue building on what they have without falling into the typical early access pitfalls then this game will be the next big thing. All it will need is a promotion from a YouTuber to blow up.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 5, 2014
Early Access Review
								Early Access Alpha, People, ALPHA!I love this game, I've been looking for an off-line Wurm for some time, and this doesn't disappoint. I host my own server, just for me, with x2 skill gain and am really enjoying building up my little 'community' bit by bit, a potters house, a miners house, a farmers house, a ranchers house, and so on.It is an early access game, in Alpha - that is it is un-optimised (optimisation would ideally be finished in beta stress testing), it is not full of content yet (there is content but it's more to test the mechanics) and even not all the mechanics are in game yet (an alpha should start with the core mechanics, test them through content, then add more content/mechanics, test those, and so forst). If this is not the sort of game you want to play, with possible roll-backs, world-breaking bugs, crashes - then don't buy this game. Certainly don't buy it, then whinge about the state of it - the fact that it is Alpha is smeared everywhere! If you want to play the game, but not in the alpha state, then buy the game to support the developers to finish it then go away for a year!

content:
Posted: September 28, 2014
Early Access Review
								Imagine Wurm Online (or Haven & Hearth) with a working and modern interface, combined with Mount & Blade style combat and Ultima Online's skill system. That is essentially what this game is.This is a stand-alone alpha version of Life is Feudal, and is *not* the MMO that is planned to come out sometime next year, though buying this means you will have a free copy of the MMO when it does come out. What this means is that you are limited to 64 player privately hosted servers and a 1 km square island instead of 10,000 players on a 32 km square continent, and that none of the guild territory control stuff is activated.That said, it's still a blast, and is worth your time and money.

content:
Posted: October 4, 2014
Early Access Review
								I have played just over 10 hours of this game and from what i have gathered i find this a very enjoyable game.So i will start with the settings for the sanbox mode.The setting can change from how many animals spawn,the time smelting/logs you need to use to smelt Iron Copper Gold or Silver.There are also time set on how long trees grow and many more it is a bit weird to use when you jump in but is quick to work out.The User-Interface is very hard to understand but i have figured out the basics to what most do.You have the stamina bar which is the green bar,The purple bar which im am pretty sure is the health bar and a small bar that is your hunger bar.hunger is a task in its self to do. You can search the floor for food and eat what you can find but if you dont want to do that you can go the farming root and make carrots onions wheat and more.I have made my character more of a miner so i have not did much in farming.but the small part i took in was very easiy to understand. Construction is very easy to do collet a certain amount of items and build with the tools you need.I will state that this game if played with the standerd settings will take you around 5-6 hours just to build your first house.When you figure things out the game is much simpler and faster.I could go on for hours about this game but what i will leave here is my final score.I give this game a  8.5/10  -ArranGaming

content:

Early Access Review
								I've logged some time both in multiplayer and single player and I've definitely had some fun with this. I personally love the sandbox high-realism gameplay and the slow pacing of everything makes the game a real marathon to achieve what you want, but it's extremely fun to see all the progress you've made as you build your first shack and then an actual home and tools.This game, like most in this style, really depends on outside sources to learn the mechanics. I spent hours trying to flatten terrain for a house only to realise that I didn't understand how the flatten action worked. Prospecting for minerals makes my brain hurt, and tracking confused the heck out of me for quite awhile, but once you know the rules, it's all accessible.

content:
Posted: January 20, 2015
Early Access Review
								With only 46 hours total, i'll give a review of what i think so far. This game is outstanding, with only a plaster shack build and a kiln to keep me company, i'm completely subdued in the environment. The mechanics of the game are good for it's state, the animal AI is good and the crafting is brilliant.More on the crafting. The mining aspect of the game is realistic, not Minecraft like where you can dig a mineshaft 300 blocks long in the space of half an hour, in this it would take you weeks. Hell it would take you months. The Buildings are realistic to every detail, they also take much longer compared to other crafting/building MMOs. I cant realy comment on the PvP as i've only fought a tree with an axe so far. The skills are in-depth and have a promising future.All in all. If you are a hardcore survivalist that loves PvP, survival and building. This game is the one.

content:
Posted: September 28, 2014
Early Access Review
								Yes it is early access, but advertisement and and screenshots make this game look alot more developed than it really is.  After purchase you find the graphic quality and overall smoothness is horrible, and it takes a huge toll on your computers performance even at low graphic settings..., and the overall direction of going about game life is confusing and tedious.  At the games current state, it is almost pointless to play due to servers going up and down on a constant basis, so you lose all of your production on a daily basis and have to start over.  For the hefty price tag, and mis-leading state of the game, I currently cannot recommend this game to my fellow steam-mates.Edit:After a few months I decided to give Life is Feudal a try again to see if any improvments have been made.  And to my surprise this was in fact the case.  The game runs very smooth now even with the graphics quality turned up to max.  I have enjoyed playing the last few days and frankly have become somewhat addicted to its game play.  I think it would do some good if they implimented a better beginers tutorial though, as it get can confusing on how and what to start doing, but with thier online wiki things are manage-able and can be figured out.  Find a good server to play on and you may find yourself having some fun.  At this time I will be changing my rating to positive.

content:

												I really enjoyed the pace of Life is Feudal. This game makes you feel accomplished for everything you build. Just leveling the ground takes hours, and gathering materials makes the game feel genuine. Me and 3 of my friends spent 80+ hours making our small out of the way village.  Hauling lumber up to our encampment was an all day task. One friend collected ore, and another smithed it. While me and my other friend leveled ground, and built structures. Our base was finally coming together and then it happened...the server we were on got restarted because only like 5-10 people were coming on anymore. We haven't played together since. The biggest issue I had when I played was that when the new day started the whole server would lag for a minute.

Also the cells system which is used for the land (you terafforming single cells) doesn't seems  like good sollution. It's not working on 100% and that cube mining holes looks really ugly.There is single map for this first small realease and even this one single small map has lot of holes in textures. Realy its one small map, can't they put some love into it and give us world without possiblity to see beneath textures?? Shame on you devs! I did see ther only two animals, wolf and some deer and they alwasy stay on one place, side by side like ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. Thas all what they do. Yeah, maybe wolf will attack if you want kiss his beloved deer, I did't try, because I saw video where two guys vere killing one deer like 30 mins. There are spots where the same sounds of wildernes are repeated every one second. So its for example never ending loop of eagle scream. It will force you to move from your already claimed property to somewhere else. If those guys have technical skills like for example Trion or Funcom, that woudl be awesome, but what I did see right now, it's just another cheap looking, like hell bugging, forever in beta never really polished game. But part of pvp crowd would be satisfied for sure.And about "early access and beta" ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t. In todays language, that means realeased, money making game. So spare it for someone who cares.. When MO was in beta, people were excited like hell, is the same with this game. But I think this will do probably better then Mortal Online, it looks little bit better.I don't want refund, it was my decision to buy, am not in hate. I will check the huge map when they will release it. But am realy sad that it is always like this :( I would  say, that all these junior developers just use us like university of game making. They probably will one day join some real company and would do some reall games.

content:
Posted: October 3, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game at current (Sep 3) is very playable and lots of fun. However, some of the tasks do feel very repetitive and grindish. But this is a very good game still. If you find it too grindish, you just find a new server to play on.  Figuring out how to do things and progress isn't too hard and most people are willing to help you along. There's not too much of the kill on sight people and if you find that and don't like it, agian, find a new server. I found that at some points the game flattens out and there isn't too much else that can be done. Though there are many hours of playing to get there. All in all, this is a great game for those who like realisim and town building. PvP isn't too big, yet, but it likely will get there. Worth the money now though!

This is indeed your second life!as the achievement said.I only played this game for a couple days as I have many games to play. But it is essentially Beautiful I love the quality and the feel you get to it, more of the gameplay is you need to get item B to get to item A.FULL COOPERATION NEEDED. You cant be Jack of All Trades in this game, you need friends. You just need them, You cant build a village alone neither can you craft all items alone, I recommend 3 friends. You being skilled in A the others in B and C. If you want you can run around and search for people to work for. Realism in this game is 8/10 many skills when I first play is useless but i think more updates and content will come. The Hours you need to complete a house, the help, and people needed! Its not like Minecraft or other survival game, you cant finish it under 10 hours you need like a full day even with friends for just a few items.Buy it? Yes. But needs help on the first few days

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 14, 2015
Early Access Review
								Reasons why you should buy this gameIf the idea of building and fighting to survive in a cruel unforgiving world populated by people who want murder you and steal your flux to finish their warehouse appeals to you then this is probably the game for you. Your story will most likely go as follows. You start as a confused peasant and spend the first day playing the mud. Slowly you learn about the world and eventually you craft primative stone age tools to aid your struggle. After much patience you learn how to build a shelter to shield you from the cold and even learn the secrets to smelting and while using your neighbor's forge while they aren't looking, the art of crafting. Finally after what seems like an eternity you finally have iron tools after which a naked man appears with a stick and promptly beats the♥♥♥♥♥♥out of you, taking that shiny new iron hammer and shovel just in spite of you. Doubling back you will forge new tools - weapons. With your humble pitchfork in hand you go to the forest in search of bandits. Unfortunately, you find them. They laugh at you and watch as their buddy beats your♥♥♥♥♥once more with a stick as you haven't the slightest clue how to fight. The next day in exploration you come across a great stone castle populated by several intimidating warriors. You ask to be let in as a laborer and they accept. After days of working on their stone keep they offer to teach you to fight. With stick in hand they kick your♥♥♥♥♥over and over again until the secrets of combat begin to unfold. Eventually you are able to hold your own though you are clearly still an inexperienced fighter. The next day you and your companions go together into the woods in search of adventure. After hours of exploration you come across a populated camp in a clearing. You recognize their faces of the occupants and rush out of the clearing ready to fight. You knew exactly which weapon you would use - the one that had caused you so much pain in the past. Your friends quickly follow eager not to miss out on the fight and the bandits scatter in all directions once they become aware of the unfavorable odds. You give chase and corner one deep in the woods. He quickly pulls out a familiar pitchfork in to defend himself with. Stick in hand you fight him. Although you were once terrified of him you now realize that his experience at hunting mud farmers hasn't taught him to fight. For every hit he makes on you, your weapon lands five on him. He panics and attempts to flee but your last hit staggered him. The following hit ends him. You stand victorious. The circle is complete and now you are the one beating people's asses with a stick.Reasons why you shouldn't buy this gameI would not buy this game expecting it to fund the plan of the MMO as while it is an epic idea, I do not think that it is a realistic goal for this dev team at the present. From an outside look anyone can see that development is moving sluggishly for a game that is in early access. I get the feeling that a few of their programmers are a little green as I have seen them do stuff like use reserve words as variable names and set the default render range to a rediculous amount causing the entire map to be rendered reducing frame rates of even good computers below 30 (Thankfully has been fixed with a simple edit of a text file). Also for the longest time you could crash the server on command by inviting someone to your group who wasn't in the game. If this team with their present proficiency tried release this as an early access MMO the servers would be empty in weeks from technical deficiencies alone as this team has not demonstrated an ability to swiftly address critical issues like a certain well known crash-the-server-on-command bug(See below).As time goes on I hope the team improves from experience (doesn't always happen) and expands to include more experienced members. Then and only then will the idea of a MMO be a realistic oneDo not buy this game expecting to get a finished product. This game has a long way to go so don't buy it expecting to get a mostly finished game. This game has MAJOR problems. For instance, once every month or so servers have to wipe because the world doesn't repair damage done to it by players. Buildings like that ♥♥♥♥♥♥ mud hut you made do not decay over time even when unused for weeks. Also every single mine on the map remains there until the server is wiped with no way to remove them. Both of these cumulatively cause server lag and the eventual reset of the server causing you to lose dozens of man-hours of work. The game is also troll infested as is any sandbox game with things like spawn camping and glitching over walls and into houses (to steal valuables) both being common place. Also don't be suprised if you log in and find that someone made a bunch of unremovable mine tunnels in your base right where you planned to put that keep. There are good servers out there that are good at policing such behavior but it's up to you to find them.

content:
Posted: October 1, 2014
Early Access Review
								I would write a deep and truly inspiring review of this game but I will let the numbers speak for me. 85.2 hours of Life is Feudal: Your Own. It's an ambitious game and still needs some refinement but if the vision of what Bobik has planned comes to fruition this game could shake some things up in the gaming world. Pro's: *Rich crafting system even in this early access stage.           *There isn't a KOS fest everywhere.           *Good Community. People actually banding together and working on villages.          *Immersive. Even in this early stage of the game it is highly immersive.           *GM Mode: This allows you to toy with all of the buildings and also console in items. Con's:*The combat system is bit off at the moment.           *Some crashes but much less since the recent patch.          *No character customization currently. It's a great game already I say help the game get furthered and get it.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 25, 2014
Early Access Review
								Life is Feudal: Your Own is well done game, despite the bugs and lack of optimization. Yeah there's bugs here and there like freezing in place and not being able to move (well at least for me) and that the game takes a large amount of RAM. But those are minor in just how in depth and amazing this game is, and it's only in Early Access! Life is Feudal is a medieval sandbox game that likes to be like DayZ, but it does it so much better. Instead of mindlessly killing people (where you lose alignment and lose more skill points upon death), the game tries a more peaceful approach with the implementation of a yield command that gives all your stuff to the combatant, but you get to live on. This would be more like the Codes of Chivalry in being that you protect the honor of another knight. I love that this game does things so well and I cannot wait to see what it's like in the full release, which is by no means close to even being finished.  All in All, this game does an excellent job, despite the problems it has.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 26, 2014
Early Access Review
								Life is Feudal... Life is Short, especially in the medieval times. Also in modern times too. Currently, as I am writing this I have about 8 hours logged. About Two of those eight hours are actually playing time.Rant aside, this game has super potential, and yes, I know, its in Alpha.What I will add to give the review some diffrence to other reviews is --Mentioning that whenever you play on a diffrent server you have to restart. From scratch. (Try and stay on the same server)-There is NO offline mode (the Mines of Moria have better internet than myself) so you can play without server crashing then re-logging and losing another half hour of your life)-Primitive weapons are useless. I used my primitive axe  (Made from a snapped tree branch, some plant fiber from the ground and a piece of flint picked up from a rocky patch)  to attack a Wild Grouse, as my charecter was on the verge of starvation  (I had eaten all 5 of my free cookies, and apples only add 5 to your hunger bar, and the ground roots, once you find them, your pretty much back to the hunger you started on)  So, axe in hand, i approached from behind, axed raise expecting a kill... WHAM!... it survived. And fluttered off and nestled a few yards away. It carried on squaking. I ran up again after letting it settle in.. Whack!! It ran again. Two hits with an axe and it still lives? Hopefully theres no Dragons here. As it took 15 hits to eventually slay the mighty Grouse of Fedual times. Each hit registering 1.5 damage - 2.5 for a head shot.Finally i skin my pray. Collect the one feather from it. Carry it to my nearby camp fire like its some heavy tree trunk. But wait.. i cant do anything with this object. WHY??? IM STARVING HERE!!! Are my skills to low? What have I done wrong??So i give up and gather more apples. Make a fishing rod.. and try to catch fish on an empty stomach. Where are the fish??? I fished for ten minuits... not a bite. More apples. Apples... Their driving me mad!!! Then.. You cant find any apple trees.. or have over harvested them.. So you revert to a dirt digger, looking for roots to eat. Its a negative frustrating cycle. Somewhat feudal.-When you meet someone new, they're likely new to the game too. They boast how they have made a primitive axe also. You made one half an hour ago. and thier bragging makes you want to show them your own axe up close to their face. Yet, you are a good patient person and give them a simple "well done" keeping your penalty bar neutral. (Penalty bar is a bar which kinda measures your deeds. Basically if it goes into the minus side, you will be a criminal and if you die, when you respawn itll make you loose more skill points than normal, so if you pray everyday, and be "Nice" youll be in the positive. Or stuck on neutral.) - Your new fround companions decide to build next to the large lake on the big island, or on the coast... you start logging trees. Not quiet sure what to do next.. plus you need to work on your construction skill, as you cna only build a furnace.. A furnace??? What use is that..??!! But wait, you gotta learn to walk before you can run. So to build a furnace, i need to collect water and clay and sticks... ok. I can find every thing, but cant pick up water?? ( I actually logged into another server and found a massive village - with no inhabitants. But there was a well. It would let me collect water and it had a container allready) so how do i get water??As you can see, this game frustrates, soome times makes no sense. The wiki for the game isnt the best. You watch online you-tube videos and most people who make them, you can hear the frustration in their voice aswell. But then again, thats part of the feudal life. You want to tame the wild beast. Make it your own.Id give this 6/10. I would love to see a single player version with NPC's, raids by NPC etc. Or at least with an allready established town, where you can go up to established carpenter workshops and ask for work etc.Anyway, ill still keep logging in, wasting my time looking at "Conecting to server & Loading World" screens, just to see if there is progress because like I said earlier the potential... its amense. (Even though that can be said about a lot of alphas/betas) So stay tuned folks.

Basically if it goes into the minus side, you will be a criminal and if you die, when you respawn itll make you loose more skill points than normal, so if you pray everyday, and be "Nice" youll be in the positive. Or stuck on neutral.) - Your new fround companions decide to build next to the large lake on the big island, or on the coast... you start logging trees. Not quiet sure what to do next.. plus you need to work on your construction skill, as you cna only build a furnace.. A furnace??? What use is that..??!! But wait, you gotta learn to walk before you can run. So to build a furnace, i need to collect water and clay and sticks... ok. I can find every thing, but cant pick up water?? ( I actually logged into another server and found a massive village - with no inhabitants. But there was a well. It would let me collect water and it had a container allready) so how do i get water??As you can see, this game frustrates, soome times makes no sense. The wiki for the game isnt the best. You watch online you-tube videos and most people who make them, you can hear the frustration in their voice aswell. But then again, thats part of the feudal life. You want to tame the wild beast. Make it your own.Id give this 6/10. I would love to see a single player version with NPC's, raids by NPC etc. Or at least with an allready established town, where you can go up to established carpenter workshops and ask for work etc.Anyway, ill still keep logging in, wasting my time looking at "Conecting to server & Loading World" screens, just to see if there is progress because like I said earlier the potential... its amense. (Even though that can be said about a lot of alphas/betas) So stay tuned folks.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 3, 2015
Early Access Review
								If you are looking for a hardcore medieval experience...this is it! I spent at least 4 Hours in the game before I was even able to build my first Shack...Terraforming, Gathering Materials. etc. takes a really long time if you are playing on your own, but I wanted to learn the basics of LiF first before I join any servers. Once you've built your own Shack then you can craft furniture to fill it with, which of course requires new Materials and Tools. So, even though this is a early Alpha you will always  have stuff to do because everything takes so much time (like I said, this game is Hardcore!). With better Carpentery and Logging skills you will be able to make better and bigger Houses and Buildings which will even take more of your free-time :D I only played the game for like 12-13 hours at this moment where I'm writing this review, but I'm already addicted. So If you like Medieval themed games and are looking for a Minecraft-like experience you should give LiF:Your Own a try!

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 19, 2014
Early Access Review
								I'm giving some faith to the devs for my recommended status. It's a beautiful game, but after 9 hours I'm bored. Crafting system is in depth but the controls... THE CONTROLS! Want to build something? Don't look to anything in game to guide you through even the most simplistic of tasks. I chose the private server route as I wanted to see what the game has to offer without having to watch my back. That was fun to set up, you will need additional downloads if you run into the non responsive (private) server. I think 8 of my 9 hours I spent hacking away at trees, watching a crafting bar run it's meandering course, and alt-tabbing to try and find a user made youtube video while I ground my teeth in frustration. I wanted to do something that looks really cool in game and having no clue how to even start. I should add that I only knew something cool was there because of said walkthroughs.  The desolation was incredible as well, I felt like I should have run accross a few peasants on the road to harass, maybe a highway robber, but alas nothing was there to even make me worry about obtaining a decent weapon. I even cranked up the animal population to max and it took me a half hour (real time) to wander my lonely island till I found what appeared to be a deer and wolf grunting in the bushes doing god knows what. 4 slingshot projectiles later (after firing 20 shots at close range) I watched my preys back side dissapear into the woods, I gave chase but tripped on the wolf and was promptly devoured as I tried to switch my weapons (STUPID G DAM ANIMATION) because the sling takes one weapon slot and the shots sit in the other.Pros: Sweet idea, excellent presentation, the game of my dreams. Controls are responsive.Cons: Nothing to do, and the things you can do are too complicated and not really a big payoff after grinding for hours. Controls are confusing. The Island is disturbing and lonely in it's beauty. I'd rather be a part of a continent cut off by a mountain range, that would feel immersive. I could keep going, but this is an ALPHA build and I want to see it make it to completion. My recommendation is to support the Dev, maybe wait for it to go on sale if you can't drop the $40 (really? Why is it so much?) but I would at some point pick up this game because it looks like good things will be coming.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 5, 2015
Early Access Review
								Pros:-Looks Good graphically-It doesn't feel like a grind, there is a genuine feeling of getting more and more advanced and accomplishment-The Developers are very active and know what they are doing, and w/ enough, no, PLENTY of staff members-Community is good (For the most part people are friendly not too much KoS) -In depth crafting, gathering, and interesting hunting system. -It's just fun to play! And you can play in any way you like, for the most partCons:-BUGS!!! (for the most part its in your favor like a bear won't attack you back and you basically get free thick leather instead of a face full of claw, but other bugs can be frustrating like tracks not showing under hilly terrain)-Optimization issues (for the most part people can run the game w/ decent pc's like for instance i'm on a laptop and run the game well on medium graphics! but it is early so every now and then it can be unplayable for some people but the devs DO fix the bugs, the problem is that when theres 1 new content patch theres probably a need for 2 new optimization patches, but the devs do well with keeping up with things, just saying if you don't have the patience to wait, do not spend ur money for the next few months) ALSO SERVERS optimizations. This is the big issue esentially the more buildings, mines, and tree stumps that acquire on a server, the closer and closer it comes to its impending doom and the server needs a wipe, which is a tad bit too short imho.-Some key content not in yet, like horses, and ♥♥♥♥ING BLOCKING, as a veterened M+B player I was dissapointed to find out blocking was not working whatsover with the exeption of (maybe) shields. -The mmo version is not even close to here yet. The MMO version is what the devs really want, and wether you know it or not its what YOU should/do want. HOWEVER if you buy the game now you get free acess to the mmo also sooo its not that much of a downside.TL;DR Its a fun game, if you have the passion and patience for the game and its genre buy it, otherwise come back later!

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 20, 2014
Early Access Review
								Life is Feudal: Your Own is definitely a product of our ongoing craze and love for the survival, sandboxy, constructive and destructive genre, while taking another step towards its logical extremes. The game is a beautiful one, the graphics and the lighting do not fail to impress, which helps bring life to a vast world filled with trees, mountains, swamps, beaches and the ocean itself. Although at the time of writing the game is clearly an Early Access one with plenty of missing features, what's there is evidently plenty to hook people in.The game gives you plenty of options on how you'd like to play it. You can set how fast or how slow your skills level up, from a glacial crawl to rocketing into masteries. You can set skill caps, either letting the player master every profession, or give them just enough to master one and dabble in one or two others. The latter adds an incredible amount of flavour, where you see farmers who are actual farmers, carpenters who are actual carpenters. They've specialized, they've mastered their trade, and although they may have the ability to help out here and there, they'll never become the town's second blacksmith. To some this may sound bad, but look at it this way: this is Life is Feudal. You're building a town, and in this town everyone, every player, has a purpose. They become gears in a grander machine, where everyone relies on everyone else.In that kind of game, on that kind of server, you won't find that one guy that's a master blacksmith, carpenter, architect, herbalist, and so on. You won't find a massive castle built by a single person, vast and full of every imaginable thing, but equally lonely. During my play I was invited to join a town. A small one, admittedly, but immediately the community became evident and clear. You had farmers with their plots outside the walls. You had the blacksmith with his shop, a herbalist with another. I was lucky enough to be apprenticed as a carpenter, witnessing wood cutters at work, hauling timber to their newest farmhouse.That doesn't mean it has to be though. If you're the kind of person that prefers the Minecraft approach, worry not! As I mentioned before, the skill rates are completely up to you. If you want to master the art of logging from peeling the bark off a tree, you can set those settings up and just jump in. You'll be able to master every skill and build your own little kingdom. This goes in multiplayer as well, meaning you can have a small group on a high skill rate server that'll be able to rival a low skill rate server's larger community.Nothing is perfect however, and this goes doubly for early access. I don't fault the game for any of its bugs or glitches, but it helps that I honestly didn't run into many. The only thing that actually showed up was that sometimes items wouldn't load in and I had to restart the game. No crashes, no memory leaks, no massive frame drops out of nowhere. The frame rate, admittedly, was pretty awful even on the lowest settings, but that's par for the course during early development. It can only get better. Yet this doesn't leave me with a lot of complaints! The UI is a little clunky, but that tends to be cleaned up during development. Wolves are a bit deadly when you're starting off as well, making running into one early on a deadly affair -- and honestly, that's about it.There's already a good selection of servers out there with a modest but dedicated population, too. For anyone who's been seeking a game like this, I find it easy to recommend. Just be warned; this may be a little too hardcore for a jump directly from Minecraft, at least for some players. For the rest, that's most definitely a good thing!

The latter adds an incredible amount of flavour, where you see farmers who are actual farmers, carpenters who are actual carpenters. They've specialized, they've mastered their trade, and although they may have the ability to help out here and there, they'll never become the town's second blacksmith. To some this may sound bad, but look at it this way: this is Life is Feudal. You're building a town, and in this town everyone, every player, has a purpose. They become gears in a grander machine, where everyone relies on everyone else.In that kind of game, on that kind of server, you won't find that one guy that's a master blacksmith, carpenter, architect, herbalist, and so on. You won't find a massive castle built by a single person, vast and full of every imaginable thing, but equally lonely. During my play I was invited to join a town. A small one, admittedly, but immediately the community became evident and clear. You had farmers with their plots outside the walls. You had the blacksmith with his shop, a herbalist with another. I was lucky enough to be apprenticed as a carpenter, witnessing wood cutters at work, hauling timber to their newest farmhouse.That doesn't mean it has to be though. If you're the kind of person that prefers the Minecraft approach, worry not! As I mentioned before, the skill rates are completely up to you. If you want to master the art of logging from peeling the bark off a tree, you can set those settings up and just jump in. You'll be able to master every skill and build your own little kingdom. This goes in multiplayer as well, meaning you can have a small group on a high skill rate server that'll be able to rival a low skill rate server's larger community.Nothing is perfect however, and this goes doubly for early access. I don't fault the game for any of its bugs or glitches, but it helps that I honestly didn't run into many. The only thing that actually showed up was that sometimes items wouldn't load in and I had to restart the game. No crashes, no memory leaks, no massive frame drops out of nowhere. The frame rate, admittedly, was pretty awful even on the lowest settings, but that's par for the course during early development. It can only get better. Yet this doesn't leave me with a lot of complaints! The UI is a little clunky, but that tends to be cleaned up during development. Wolves are a bit deadly when you're starting off as well, making running into one early on a deadly affair -- and honestly, that's about it.There's already a good selection of servers out there with a modest but dedicated population, too. For anyone who's been seeking a game like this, I find it easy to recommend. Just be warned; this may be a little too hardcore for a jump directly from Minecraft, at least for some players. For the rest, that's most definitely a good thing!
