number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 18, 2016
												I am obsessed with this game. Normally i get bored easily and will buy a game, play it for 30-50 hours and then move on to the next thing. Not this one. I have put 100 hours into it so far over the past 3 weeks and am more obsessed than ever. I am constantly surprised i still love this game since it seems very grindy, but the strange thing is that i rarely notice the grind when i actually play. Even the seemingly grindy tasks like flattening the earth or fishing for food don't seem to be as tedious because you are constantly thinking about what you will be able to do next once you complete that task. Things to be prepared for/know up front:--This game is not quick. You will not build everything in the game in a matter of days. Even seemingly simple things such build a small wodden house will take 30-40 man hours (longer if you have to do everything yourself). If the thought of always having something new to build or something to improve appeals to you, then you will like this game.--This game should not be played alone in my opinion. I don't mean you have to start the game with a friend, but you better find someone else in game (or more than one person preferably) if you want to have any success. Everything just takes too darn long and never ending if you aren't able to divide up tasks.--Many servers are heavy RP so if that's not your cup of tea, make sure to find a server that isn't.Recommendations for enjoying the game: --Research the available servers thoroughly and pick one you think you might like. Nothing ruins this game quicker than joining a dead server or a server that enforces rules that will ruin your fun (like deleting your character if you die)--If you are first starting, run around the whole map visiting the towns. Dont just join the first one you see. You will be spending a lot of time with these people so you have to determine what their goals/time commitments/ etc are. I played on 2 servers and the enjoyment i had on one is immensely more simply cuz that one contained people more willing to help, and more people on at the same time i would play. --Do not play alone. I have already said this, but i cant stress it enough. This game becomes 100x more fun if you are working on something with a group of people and can pass the time chatting with them rather than working by your lonesome in total silence.Conclusion:This game deserves more credit than it seems to get, but in the end it all comes down to the server you join. Join a good server and you will love it. join a bad server, and you will play this for 10 hours and never come back.

content:
Posted: January 20, 2015
Early Access Review
								If you're like me, you're going to love this game. It's like Harvest Moon for grownups - you fish, mine, forage, chop down trees, build a home and farm. It's definitely grindy, and of course as early access there's a lot that either isn't implemented or doesn't work or is just a bit weird. I was surprised by how playable it was, though, and by how addicted I came to it: just gotta log on and tend to my flax plantation, check on those hides I have curing, make sure the livestock has food and isn't drowning in poop (this does tend to become an issue if you don't keep on top of it).If you're like my brother you'll be bored, especially with the current state of the game - it is repetitive, not especially dramatic or exciting, and jumping off the mountain doesn't kill you. You have to learn a chain of skills before you can do a lot of things - such as mining before you can actually smelt ore - and some of it can take quite a while. It also requires a degree of teamwork if you want to progress at anything other than a snail's pace. All in all I sincerely hope the development continues and the game does get a full, stable release - it's always a risk to buy something like this but I personally don't regret the purchase.

content:
Posted: December 29, 2014
Early Access Review
								To some of the other reviews, which I feel have been unfair in some respects:The game can be grindy, yes... But it does not take 30 real-life hours to build a shack.All you need is skill in terraforming and construction (which are in the same line and unlocked almost instantly) and some primitive tools. If you know what you're doing (and it takes no time at all to know, if you youtube it), you can get a 3x4 plot of land flattened and build a shack in an hour, if even that.Unless you're building on an extreme incline like a mountain side - which will of course be tons of work.The game is kind of lame for a solo person unless you love to basically do nothing but build and survive - but that's not the true aim of the game, from what Iv'e seen and experienced. You can be a lone wolf, yes, but on a server with a decent population it is often much easier to go it in a group.The point of the game is to build a town/kingdom that is populated by real people that are ready to defend it, and real people that are ready to raid and conquer it. Teamwork is the key here, especially on servers that set the skill cap lower than maximum.If you want a solo experience, you should go for a "themepark" MMO or a casual single-player voxel game such as Minecraft.This game - a full-loot, free pvp crafting game with hunger mechanics, complex stats and a no-target combat system, is *not* a casual single-player experience. Don't fool yourself.Would I enjoy more agressive NPC's that would give a real need to build defenses? Absolutely. But this is just not that kind of game, and there is honestly little need for it outside of a private, single-person server.Between honorless theives, merciless raiders that want nothing more than to make you bleed and take your land and crafted items, and the ever-present possibility of betrayal from your own neighbors... This game utilizes the same hostile threat that so many others capitalize on - the most powerful, cunning, monstrous and challenging enemies of them all; other people.   And that is more than enough reason to build tall walls and secure storage buildings.If you absolutely cannot wait for the MMO, buy the "Your Own" version now and get in a good server with decent admins. But be prepared for spurts of lag on higher populated and more developed servers, until they fix tree growth rates and tunnel lag. This current version is more of an isolated testing version in a smaller continent with smaller public and private servers, in which many people and guilds are using for training purposes to prepare for the release of the much larger MMO version.But all in all, I reccomend this game for its unique and satisfying experience. Think "Wurm Online" with much more fun and heart-pounding combat, and way better graphics.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 3, 2015
Early Access Review
								This game is great for people who feel rewarded by their hard work rather than by awards and adolations in-game. It is quite in-depth and a good alternative to Wum Online if you don't like monthly fees or slave labor for benefactors. Do significant research before buying though, it is not a game for everyone... not even really a game for many. Also, if you plan on playing with the default rules come to grips with the fact that you will have to lose levels in some skills in order to gain more levels in a skill that you need. You may even need to re-level up a skill which you sacrificed levels in hours earlier. This is becaus there is a maximum number of levels that can be distributed to all of your skills and the level of your skill determines what actions you can take. This creates a web of skills which makes it difficult to survive alone. For instance: if you are trying to cook you need a pot. To make a pot you have to be level 60 in terraforming. To get the logs for the fire you have to be level ~60 in logging. Only then can you start to cook and level up your chef skills. But now you have taken up 120 of your ~640 total skill levels just to begin cooking and there are SO many more skills that you are likely interested in. My suggestion is to do one or both of two things: Make sure you have other players who are dedicated to the game and will play with you. They can keep skills up which you will totally ignore and do all of that kind of work for you and you can do the same for them. This emulates real life which I believe was the intention of the developers. OR you can play in a world where the total skill cap is higher. I wouldn't make it a ton higher because that would make the game more about grinding to max level and becoming a god instead of intelligently mastering your skills and developing a lifestyle. Overrall a fun game, you should just really know what you are getting into before you buy it.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 2, 2014
Early Access Review
								Life is Feudal! This is the game of my dreams. Freedom to build, explore, craft, and work as a co-operative team in any way you wish.  It's really important to note that this is not a solo player game. I shudder to think of how long it would take to do anything by yourself, but it's got really great potential for co-operative play. Unfortunately, I've not had the experience of playing with others..my PC doesn't run the game well so I need it on a lower res, which pushes the chat UI off screen so I can only play with people I have on teamspeak or mumble. If you don't have a graphics card, I don't recommend this to you unless you can deal with really bad graphics, or are going to get a graphics card soon.Negatives of this game that I struggle to overcome...it takes forever to do stuff. There's a lot of grinding for skills, and the time it takes to do certain things, or for crops/trees to grow don't always make sense. It takes half the time to erect a house as it does to uproot a tree stump. Fishing takes 30 seconds and you almost never catch anything. I guess this is stuff that will be ironed out in future updates, but if you can't deal with strange logics and bugs and unfinishedness then I wouldn't recommend this to you.Positives...if you DO have a graphics card this game is gorgeous. Watching the sun go down over the lakes and mountains really is something to see. It's immersive, and exciting to see your settlement develop. If you have a big bunch of friends, or friendly people on a server you frequent, it'll be great for you. You can get stuff done fast and I imagine it feels a lot more fulfilling than slogging over your tunnel for 4 hours with one other person.In conclusion....it's a lot of money for an alpha but if you have the money to spare (and excessive amounts of time) then I'd definitely recommend it to you. It has a huge amount of potential for the future, which is really exciting!

[this needs to be added please]6. no horses which they will be here soon but need to be made more of a priority.7. bows and xbows are broken and need major adjustment8. wolf is extremly over powered. i understand its the only aggresive animal but it should be not as strong.9. no bridges/drop down bridges or anyway to make a moat [ not a priority just hope to see]10. in game voice chat starts turned off and you have to go into audio settings and turn it on. (fix this)[these player cons are seen more to me as the major priority items that need to be worked on.]Onto the GM i will only be listing cons since all the other GM abilities are fine in my opinion:cons-1. GM needs a faster terraforming tool. [make it use the same size grid as the observe mode on terraforming but have a way to increase or decrease all of the squares at once]2. a GM should not be able to ban another GM. you removed the ban hammer from a GM from banning themselves but you should also remove the ban hammer on anyother GM logged in.3. when logged into GM all skills should be unlocked aswell as anything to build or use.4. GM shouldnt need tools to forge or anything else (you have it this way for terraforming and building but not forging)5. GM or server owner should be able to set a higher player stat max than 150/150the gm powers overall are great how they are these are just a few i think would be nice to have.Things with the map that i beleive need to be improved/added:1. something more than apple trees for food at first. something like bushes with berries, or vines with grapes on them.[basically a slightly easier or more realistic way to find food and survive at first]2. more animals. i know this is coming but it should be a high priority item.3. the map should be atleast double the size it is now. with servers having a population cap of 64 the map is too small simple as that.using a simple rating system with 10 being the best i will rate the game below-overall gameplay 9/10combat gameplay 7/10 (needs work)crafting and creating 10/10 (some of the best ive seen)survival gameplay 7/10 (needs more aggresive wildlife and a water meter to go with the food meter)weather 2/10 (would like to see changes such as rain, snow and day/night cycling needs work)graphics 7/10 (could use overall more detail and design to most items other than that pretty good)map 7/10 (nothing special but it is a nice terrain)This is a great game and i would recommend to anyone who enjoys mmorpg games. with the pvp and soon to be better pve this game gives you endless amounts of things to build, create, and do. Cant wait to see this game advance here in the future, as of now i would still say BUY this game because if your interested in the Lif:YO your going to want to play the MMO and buying this will get you 1 charector key for free for the MMO version. excellent developers working on this game with there great communication to the community and there hard work this will be an excellent finished product in the end and is a sure buy that you wont regret. Early Access Review
								This game is perfect for my taste with just a few small things I dislike.The crafting system is epic and so interwoven that you need to work with other players to be able to build and craft. I really like it.The combat is really fun although it needs some polishing and reworking of the combat skill trees (that's what an alpha is for, I know) and I can't say I've had this much fun in a game since I played mount and blade for the first time.The few bad things:It's not hard to survive, food is plentifull even if you've just started and animals are easily killed, even bears.Food doesn't go bad, so gather 10000 apples and you're set for a long while.No environmental effects. Like freezing to death in the cold, damp weather or drowning or fall damage.Overall it's a great game even though it is in alpha. 9/10 as it is.

content:
Posted: October 13, 2014
Early Access Review
								I'm writing this review as of 10/12/14, for future reference. I'm assuming/hoping I can post more than one review for the game, because it's currently in Alpha so the game will evolve, as will my opinion.In summary: a lot of awesome concepts with the potential for a very collaborative-feeling multiplayer experience, or a somewhat hardcore, and therefore enjoyably challenging, single-player experience; marred by a terrible UI.Now, the rest. If you're currently thinking of buying the game, here's what (I think) you need to know. Yes, it's $40, and that's kind of pricey for what we've come to expect from an Early Access game. In this case, from what I've played of the game *so far*, and ASSUMING the things I *don't* like are addressed, the finished game should be worth it. I realize that's like saying "Assuming the chassis of this unbuilt car belongs to a Prius and not a Hummer, the finished vehicle should have great fuel economy", but...that's my best assessment of the price vs. game quality ratio so far.The game is very detail-oriented, so if you're expecting Minecraft, with "punch some trees, get wood", you'll likely be significantly disappointed. Actually, the best analogy I can think of is like a first/third-person version of "Banished". To chop down a tree (the first thing you'd probably do in a fresh Minecraft game, to stick with the analogy), here's what you need to do after spawning in LiF: Hit "tab" (which takes you out of mousey-menu-y mode, and into regular FPS navigation mode), and find a tree (some trees are hardwoods, some are softwoods, but that doesn't matter for now). Right-click on the tree, mouse over the "Forestry" submenu, and choose "Get a branch" (you might need to do this a few times, I can't remember how many branches you need for your first basic axe), Now walk around until you find an empty patch of grass (just empty of trees or other objects, really), right-click on it (you may have to move around a little for the game to recognize the patch as being highlighted), mouse over the "Nature Lore" submenu, and choose the "Find wild plant fiber option". You'll also need to do this a few times, as you need more than one plant fiber (I think) for your axe, and you don't always get it every time. After you've got your plant fiber (5, maybe), find a square of ground that has a rocky-looking texture (i.e. - not "regular" grass or "forest" grass or "regular" dirt or "plowed" dirt or...etc.). Right-click on it, mouse over the "Prospecting" submenu, choose "Find a likely flint stone", and repeat as necessary (like the plant fiber thing) until you have a couple (again, can't remember exactly how many you need). Once you've got a few flint stones, open your inventory with "I", right-click on the branch, and choose "Craft Primitive Tool". Then from the resulting UI pop-up, click on the craft menu, choose "Primitive Axe", and then click "Craft". This will take a little while while you flail your hands about wildly in front of you (character animations are a little generic atm), but at the end of it, bam! Now you have a shiny new axe. Open up your character screen with "T", and drag the axe from your inventory to one of the four tool/weapon slots on your character. Wait again while you flail your hands around (yes, equipping gear/items takes time). Now that that's done, go back over to your tree, right-click on it, mouse over the "Logging" submenu, and choose "Cut Down". Congratulations, you've now chopped down your first tree. In Minecraft, you'd already have a dirt hut, furnace, crafting table, and complete set of stone tools built by now.This is not to say that LiF's system is *bad*, just that it is incredibly detailed. Captive animals age (and die), fires burn out very quickly (no ever-burning torches), and trees take an unbelievably long time to grow after you plant an appropriate seedling. Again, NOT Minecraft. For me, I do not have a problem with that at all, it just may not be everyone's cup of tea.Unfortunately, what I do not like is the game's atrocious UI, which feels unintuitive, awkward, and unresponsive. More than once you'll find yourself in "mouse-around-menus" mode when you actually wanted to be in "regular FPS mode", because you were put into that mode because a message popped up letting you know a (possibly inaccurate) error occurred when you tried to do something. If your inventory is full, it will still attempt an action unnecessarily and then inform you that the action failed because your inventory was full, wasting some number of seconds (which do add up) unnecessarily. It will also attempt to craft things one extra time more than is possible, for example if you have the materials to make two of something, it will go through the crafting process three times and then inform you that you didn't have enough materials to make the item the third time.Depending on how much the UI stuff bothers you, you may or may not enjoy the overall Alpha experience. For me, there are a few times where the UI is so frustrating that I'll just have to stop and go play a different game for a while until I am less angry at it, but a lot of the time, the rest of the game is fun enough that I can let it slide.

content:
Posted: June 19, 2016
												Great game and definitely a grind so do not purchase if you cannot understand that!  You have options to be a one-man show or go with a community (highly-recommended).  GM's could use some rules themselves but for the most part it is good.  Community based and newbie help is always available to those who join throughout all the servers I played on.  You start with rags for clothing and can build an empire.  Crafting is very indepth and while it is a lot of work it is very rewarding when you need good armor and food.  Brewing and cooking are fun with great perks for eating high quality dishes.  Buy the game now for practice before the MMO that will be masterful!

content:
Posted: January 4, 2015
Early Access Review
								Recommended buy if you like to work really hard to accomplish a task. Don't buy if you are not looking forward to grinding. The game is one huge grind fest.  It is not a game meant to be played by yourself. The idea is to play with others and work with others in order to accomplish something huge. The crafting system so far is excellent. This game gears torwards realism. Things take time. To put things into perspective, lets take farming for example. On default settings, it takes about 6-8 hrs for the crops to be harvestable. The map is not randomly generated. It is however, a really large map. Also, there seems to be a floor level depth that you can mine past. I spent hrs locating a digging to find the iron vein just have it be not minable because of the maximum depth you can mine to. Save yourself time and only mine into hills.

content:
Posted: January 24, 2015
Early Access Review
								First time I played, I was hooked. Very realistic, brutal, exacting game. For hard core players who want a sense of satisfaction and achievment when they look at their fort and see all their hard work has paid off. However, this game is still in Alpha so very much of it doesnt work and is not implemented. Myself and three other good friends all played while on Skype for a week straight. We built a small keep, which is a monumental task as far as gathering the resources and aquiring the skill to do so. But upon completion of the keep, we found that we couldnt claim it, so the Keep provided no security and we were robbed of all our hard earned resources constantly. We then decided to seek saftey by building large stone walls around our compound, but the gate we built could not be claimed....foiled again. All the while our resources, flax, leather, iron, char coal, weapons, rope and tools were being stolen faster then we could build and/or gather them. So we built a large warehouse. We could claim that...but it got hacked and all the stuff in it was stolen. Our merchant carts kept ..."walking away" with other noob players helping them.... this game is a fantastic and engaging game. but its unplayable at the moment by hard core players....no one can expect to put any time in it if all their time keeps getting robbed. SO MUCH POTENTIAL THOUGH! Keep your eyes  on this one folks

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 5, 2014
Early Access Review
								Well where to start, If you are exspecting the game to be fully functional and not agrivating at times this is not the game for you. After several attempts and different remedies I was finally able to create my own server, though when you close the server down any memory of your charachter is lost and nothing is saved. As far as uniquness goes this game has a whole hell of alot of potential to be a kick♥♥♥♥♥game at a later date, however I will state my opinion that I feel that this will take a year or so. Graphically speaking the game requires more than the recomended specifications to play, keep in mind running your own server and the game itself will consume most basic computers physical memory and im sure with tweaks here and there they will render the graphics preformance a bit. Gameplay wise its fun when you start for about an hour or so, then you realize it now has become a farmfest which is ok because it gives you the feeling that you are living in the past. But when you adventure out even the smallest of creatures in this case a wolf have a decent health pool that basic tools and weapons are no match for. Once you die you are given a spawn timer if you can not be healed to good health or you simply respawn with a minor skill redux, also take in mind when you die your charachter will drop all of your gear leaving you with the choice to restart or endure the run back to your corpse for loot. The sandbox feel is emmersive and the music is not half bad but unless you have a groups of freinds to play with and acheive something the game will leave you feeling lonely being the only one or two on the island. Overall if you have the money to support these guys I would highly recommend it especially concidering the recent popularity of the game.

content:
Posted: September 30, 2014
Early Access Review
								Where do I begin? This game is so ambitious, so complex that it's almost mindboggling. And yet, it's extremely addictive. The potential of this game is staggering. Deep crafting (and by deep I mean very very deep), and the building is very satisfying. There are a lot of youtube videos covering the various aspects of this game, so I won't go in to too much detail. I'll just say this; If you're into open world sandbox games with immensely deep crafting and building systems then look no further! This is the game for you. Highly recommended, even in alpha state. There are of course some bugs, but the game is overall in good shape. I see some people complain about the price, but for me this is a must-buy. Worth every penny.See you in game!

content:
Posted: September 25, 2014
												I just started playing again, I will write more about the game in the future.Combat is FIXED! You can block and its even more awesome than warband, its physics based and direction based! have to test archery and mounted combat too.Beats all MMOs even though it's just Alpha.The game reminds me of Star Wars Galaxies, you actually interact with people, talk to them on TS which imo is a major aspect which makes up an MMO (massively multiplayer..)The game beats minecraft in complexity, coming updates will probably allow complete house design too.No more stupid questing or "you have to raid here every day and pay 15 $ to be decent", you are the content, your friends are the content, your achievments are not "kill 10 rats and return", your achievements are villages, objects, social interactions and wars and diplomacy.The skill tree is diverse, you are not forced to do only one thing, you can do what you want, be what you want, support the team how you want and be a success your way.Fighting will when it's fixed be fast paced and skill based like in warband.I would support this Game, there have been enough trash mmos run by big companies sucking your money straight out of your pockets for nothing.What the game lacks in Alpha state: Server stability, some bugs, things are not implemented yet but updates come every 3 days...Also, the game is very time consuming, I would not recommend to play alone, you will be frustrated quickly if your house you took a day to build get's raided as soon as wars will start, allthough so far people avoid wars unlike DayZ or Rust.

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 6, 2015
Early Access Review
								So...I also almost did not buy this game. I'll admit, this is a somewhat pricey Early Access game...but it is totally worth it. I think the devs have an excellent vision, and with the direction they're moving in, this game only gets more and more promising. I've logged nearly 200 hours in only a few weeks, and it's been nothing but a blast. Since I've been here in the few weeks I've had it, there have been two patches already, fixing little tweaks and bugs as we go. We're getting updated graphics and UI soon enough, and I can't wait to see how the game runs then.TR;DR Version:Get this game if you like RP driven sandboxes, and find a good community. (RolePlay Community Life is Feudal is awesome!) This game is totally worth the money, and if you can get it on sale, grab a two pack and play with friends. And DON'T go to a stupid server with 3000 available skill points. You're doing it wrong.

number of helpful: 6 of 10 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 4, 2014
Early Access Review
								As with any game played in it's alpha form, Life is Feudal: Your own! has a few kinks to work out. The crafting system is rather genius and the over all ability to do as you please during game play shows how much you will be getting in this game and their future game Life is Feudal: MMO. As to the kinks I mentioned before, the servers tend to lock up often and puts a damper on the fun one would have. The idea of making this game completely community based is the greatest Idea I have ever heard, but what if you wanted to play by yourself or with only a few friends, this makes community play less then desireable. The requirements to run the game are rather high, understandable so, and that makes it hard for some of the monatery impaired able to play with current systems. The RPG you can do with friends makes this game worth the minor bugs and glitches, I did fall through the earth and drown once. The Tunneling system should be improved. Allow for tunnel collapse if possible, or be able to just fill in unwanted tunnels.Over all I see great promise in this game and look forward on the edge of my seat for the MMO to come out. With it's great new ideas and it's overall style of play I give Life is Feudal: Your Own! A 9.5 out of 10. And recommend it to all who enjoy RPG and building games.

content:
Posted: November 18, 2015
												I've been playing this game since the release of the alpha version. While the dx9 alpha version certainly had its bugs, it was actually playable. I love the game and want it to work. Love the concept and it has a lot of potential. That being said, please wait a few patches as the full dx11 release currently is LOADED with bugs and I cannot recommend the game. Gameplay, Day1 release... 


YouTube™ Video: Life is Feudal  Your Own Release Day1 

			Views: 2,082		

			Worst full release of a game ever. This was a clean install. I uninstalled the alpha version, deleted LiF folder from Steam directory, and reinstalled the full release for clean install.		

EDIT: Less than a day after the release a hotfix was out and fixed all major bugs. The game is now running great and looks utterly amazing! I highly recommend the game now. It is definitely not a game for people who like simple and easy games. It can take a very long time to craft even the simplest of items. It can be a difficult and tedious game so for anyone who likes easy-mode games, stay away.The physics-based combat system is amazing. You really have to learn the range of your weapons. Being too close will do little to no damage.The crafting and building in this game is very in depth; Better than any building/crafting game I've played by far. Again, it may not be suitable for those who want eveything handed to them quickly and easily.This is a game definitely designed for co-op play. Playing solo is possible, but it will be a long hard road for you. Much better and easier with a group of friends. 9/10

content:
Posted: December 4, 2016
												Sandbox games are my genre of choice and LiF:YO is one of my favorites.  While I do recommend this game understand that I do so with this advice:1)  Worth it if $20 USD or less.  It is still being developed.  The MMO is still in beta.  There is not enough content for most people that I would recommend the game if it was more expensive.2)  This is a slow, involved game.  By slow I mean that it will take several RL days to build most structures and some you will almost have to have help if you want to complete it.  And it is very involved.  Down to crops you grow, animals you raise, what industry you want to focus on (mining, carpentry, building, weaving, farming, etc), what weapon(s) you like to fight with - the game has depth.  At times, especially if you are playing solo, many of these things can become tedious tasks to take care of (such as cleaning the coop so animals don't die in their own feces) before you move on to things you want to do. 3)  Watch youtube gameplay videos (look for more current ones).  I can talk about the gameplay, slowness, combat, and other aspects but the videos will do a far better job showing.  I have had this game for a long time now and it is one of the better early access investments I've made.  The dev team is still plugging away at it, working on the MMO portion, supporting the player community, and trying changes to improve the game.  While the game will continue being tweaked and worked for months (years?) to come, it is very playable and can be quite enjoyable.

content:
Posted: April 16, 2016
To start I want to say that I honestly feel that this is a good game and that people should buy it to support it.Firstly the concept is amazing, an mmo set in medieval times where there are no pre-made buildings and no NPC enemy's, just you and the players with you, stuck on mammoth sized island thats covered in a forest filled thick with trees and a bounty of food. Now i will admit it, from the getgo this game is hard as hell, you'll spened hours doing things that range from chopping a mount everest amount of trees down to running arfter a boar with a makeshift knife, but it's really all in an attempt to make you feel that you are the person in the game, that you are this person stuck on an island in a medieval time period, where there are no complex tool and where a task (e.g. building a house) is somthing that takes days to do and stack load of skills to be already known. Now this is where I'll give you a tip, it is imperative that you play this game with other people, I'm not say that you need to get your friends to buy a copy because there are tons of people on servers to makes friends with, but you need someone else with you if you're ever going to get past having a stick hut and stone tools, and here's why. This game has a incredibly complex skill system, but to put it short every skill is esential for your survival, however there is the option that you can "Master" a skill such as smithing or alchemy and this has huge positive effect like allowing you to make new and special items, that in most cases will be rare because you'll have been the only person on a server to have spent time mastering that skill (Making you unique, somthing not many MMO games do). However doing so will decrease the amount of skill points you can use and as a result lower the amount of other skills you can have, this is why having a community or even just 2 or 3 friends is so important in this game, because you all need to devote yourself's and stick to a different skill in order for yourself and your friends to progress to something like a huge settlement, instead of you being by yourself spending hours apon hours and getting no were becuse playing that way was only ever surposed to get you so far in this game.Secondly it's absolutly beautiful, this game has some of the best graphics that any game which has come from early access on steam has ever had, the water looks stunning and the forests actually look like forests, by which I mean there is more than just two grass and two tree models and that if you were to enter one you'd be waist high in grass completely covered in shadow by the thick conopy of the oak trees that suround you. Now the forests actually have alot more detail in them than I just described such as mushrooms, fungi on the trees and also a variation in plant type such as flowers and wild crops, all these things actually come together to make an incredibly immersive expirence in the forest and make you feel like you really could be in an norwegian forest. Now other than the enviroment the buildings in this game are so life like and historically accurate, the stone walls and gates have moss covering the lower part of the model, the stone chipped and rough and the wallway's looking warn from guards walking up and down them, the houses with thier walls made from daub (which is a matterial made form basically anything on the ground that they could throw together), have mud and marks on them and even the balconys have flora draping down them, this is all rendered beautifully in the games engine. However this is where the visuals become a hardware problem, if you're not running a rig with at least a high end i5 processor, 8GB of ram and a Navidia GeForce 970 with 4GB of memory or equivalent, you're only ever going to see the game in below high graphic settings and if you have ever seen the game in Low settings you'll know that it is truly unplayable. Of course the devs are trying to fix this by lowering the tessellation calculations of the trees and other models within the game, which may or may not increase your graphic settings from Low to Medium but even then the game is still not worth visually playing for many reasons. But of course if you're not in it for the beautiful scenic forests in full detail with bambi running by perfectly rendered in 4k and you're running a rig below the minimum standard, then you're nothingly like me and you should have no problem at all playing this game in Medium settings.To conclude, this game can immerse you into a fully realistic feeling medieval setting, where surviving is hard and cruel but can be mastered by you and your friends if you band together. It contains an immense amount content such as the skill system and can entertain for hundreds of hours, but dosen't just have to be about resource gathering if you don't want it to be (e.g. Banditry, RolePlaying, Becoming a role in a community). Apart from this the game is pleasing to the eye and make you really feel medieval while you run through it's player made city's and castles, looking at the beautiful detail that has been put into every aspect of it. But to sum all these point up I do recommend that people buy this game only if they enjoy this type of genre and also only if they can fully explore it's visuals with the appropriate hardware on hand, don't be disappointed if the visual aren't up to scratch because you can't run High settings, that's also your fault not just the developers.

												Sandbox games are my genre of choice and LiF:YO is one of my favorites.  While I do recommend this game understand that I do so with this advice:1)  Worth it if $20 USD or less. Down to crops you grow, animals you raise, what industry you want to focus on (mining, carpentry, building, weaving, farming, etc), what weapon(s) you like to fight with - the game has depth.  At times, especially if you are playing solo, many of these things can become tedious tasks to take care of (such as cleaning the coop so animals don't die in their own feces) before you move on to things you want to do. 3)  Watch youtube gameplay videos (look for more current ones).  I can talk about the gameplay, slowness, combat, and other aspects but the videos will do a far better job showing.  I have had this game for a long time now and it is one of the better early access investments I've made.  The dev team is still plugging away at it, working on the MMO portion, supporting the player community, and trying changes to improve the game.  While the game will continue being tweaked and worked for months (years?) to come, it is very playable and can be quite enjoyable.

content:
Posted: December 10, 2016
												Based on only a few evenings of playing Life is Feudal: Your Own, or LisF, I can start to see where it shines over similar games that I would prefer, but more importantly where it does not. For a sandbox game with 'realistic' crafting, Wurm Unlimited/Wurm Online have the same 'realistic' appeal but, if you start your attempts to make second-tier tools immediately, it takes days longer to accomplish in LisF. I did not see anything as innovative as 'improvement' on things you create neither, so the 'quality' listed on materials for new players just seem like random nunbers without meaning. Also, you start with nothing, akin to Rust or Ark, but almost anything you want to build you cannot even gather the materials for from right in front of you since you need to be a master in a skill in order to become proficient in another skill and only then does the option to collect some resources appear in a context menu under the right conditions. The graphics are better than some of the sandbox games I still like to play so that's nice, but it's still so much worse than other games with 'some' sandbox building mechanics like Fallout 4. I have only seen it in videos since the servers I've played on were just not that populated, but fighting seems a bit more skill-based than other sandbox games, which is good; however, if you want great skill-based fighting in a sandbox world with 'full loot', the original Darkfall Online was so much better (and it's back again in New Dawn and Rise of Agon remake games). Overall, I don't really find anything which is new or innovative about LisF to make it worth the gruelling slowness. I would only recommend this game to those who want to role play their characters and hate every other fantasy game solely because their avatar's outfits don't look realistic enough for them...if you also have something specifically against Mortal Online.

number of helpful: 7 of 12 people (58%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 10, 2016
												I was a bit uncertain when I was deciding whether or not to buy this game. I saw there were some mixed reviews and some confused gameplay videos, however I'm glad I did, and this has been a very rewarding experience. Below I elaborate on but a few positive and negative aspects of Life Is feudal, I hope this helps you get an idea of how it plays.Pros:-Firstly, I love the medieval setting, the world looks great and it seems that the devs and really aiming for realism in the game design. The graphics are not as great as say, GTA V, but they are good enough to craft a very emmersive environment for the player.-The crafting system is VERY in depth and rewarding. You don't just find an iron colored rock and throw it into the asociated machine, you must prospect 'till you find signs of that mineral, dig around till you locate a vein underground, wait for the furnace to get hot enough to melt the ore, turn it into bars or ingots, then combine those with other raw materials to craft a variety of weapons, armor, tools and trinkets. Now I know this sounds daunting, and it can be, but because of that it feels oh so rewarding to craft something even as simple as your basic sword.-The skill system is also well constructed. For nearly every action that can be performed there is an asociated skill that must be leveled in order to become more proficient, there are many RPG games with these elements, but where Life Is Feudal differs is that there is a set skill cap that varies from server to server, but essentially means that no one person can do everything. You MUST work with other players and friends if you want to accomplish anything meaningful in the world, which makes a great addition to the game and provides even more immersion into the world.-Combat in Life is Feudal does have its issues, but overall i'm pleased with it. It's not like an MMO where you stand in one spot hitting hotkeys to launch different spells or attacks at your foes, it is based on contextual swings, combos, and weapon proficiency. Aim right as you click to swing that way, up to stab, and so on, meaning that combat is an active task, requiring the player to pay attention to his opponent and surroundings. In addition, you must ACTUALLY hit the  player or beast with the sharp end of your weapon to deal any damage. This may sound obvious, but in fact many games do not take this into account so strictly.-Due to the nature of the game, many servers gravitate towards roleplaying, to varying degrees. I feel this adds wonderful possibilities and immersion as meeting other players becomes both tense and exciting, leaving me uncertain whether I will end up in a forced labor camp, or with a new trade partner and ally. This is certainly the best way to play the game and I highly recommend you try it out. There are of course servers that aren't RP based if that's more your speed.Cons:-Though the game has come quite far since it was first released, there are still issues with optimization. Some low end PCs may have trouble running the game at higher settings. Though I experience a steady 50-60 FPS at a pleasant medium setting with my mid-range PC.-Crashes are still a bit too frequent in my opinion. I don't feel they are game-breaking, but they can be quite annoying. On average, I'd estimate I get a crash every 4 or 5 hours, be it runetime errors, game glitches, or a crash of the server itself.-I feel that the current price of $40 is a bit too much given some of the flaws still present in the game. Although I still greatly enjoy playing despite them, a lower price could help to ease the annoyance of it. I say this not based on the quality of the gameplay or core mechanics, but because of crashes and glitches. If you see it in a Steam sale, pick it up for sure.In conclusion, even though Life Is Feudal does have its issues, I still believe it's a good buy, and a great time. Boot it up and delve into the medieval era, carefully craft your gear, painstakingly construct your castle, and ruthlessly eliminate your foes.

content:
Posted: June 8, 2015
Early Access Review
								As a person that rarely trusts paying for something still in development, LiF has turned out to be the best chance I've ever taken in gaming, and is quickly becoming one of my all time favorite titles. The gameplay really fosters teamwork and a social community. The game scratches several itches. If you like Minecraft, you'll like this. If you like Mount & Blade, you'll like this. If you like traditional MMO's, you'll probably like this too.Pros A hunger mechanic that actually matters. Fatigue can leave your character stranded. A complex and robust crafting system  PvP - lots of potential. Meaningful time element - a new tool or building feels like a huge accomplishment. What's more, is everything you build serves a functional purpose.   Land ownership mechanic - extremely cool.  Nice environment. (They did a fantastic job on water, as well.)Cons It's not finished. There will be bugs. The UI takes some getting use to. There is a learning curve. It's not as steep as some are saying, but you'll need to use the wiki and other resources to build an understanding at first.  I consider this a pro, but list it as a con for others sake.

content:
Posted: November 16, 2014
Early Access Review
								-Early access review-This game is super realistic...Focuses Largely on teamwork, Takes a few dozen hours just to create a basic mud hut by yourself. Giveing you an idea how hard it was to live back in the feudal era, and the importance of living with a organized group.For being in early access, It has so much content, you cannot possibly get through it all. Its too slow paced for me, so I will wait for some added features that will make the game more appealing for solo players who just like to survive. Pros: 1.This is the closest thing you will get to a mutiplayer/realism medieval simulator. (Aside from Kingdom Come:Diliverance that is more single player and much much better looking)2. buildings are beautiful, for such a large world with lots of content and with a big enough group of friends anything is possible starting as a bunch of mud hut savages who kill people on sight to building a wall to keep up other savages, and then thriving as a huge kingdom who still kill people on sight but with more deadly weapons and fully tanked out armor.3. Loads of content...for being in a alpha stage...it feels more like a beta, best part is they are adding more.even though I am taking a long break from the game. Cons: 1.You need a group to surivive or have any fun with it, your best chance is to wander around like a naked pleb and find a group. To know if they are friendly, make sure you have the mic setup...or people will kill you on sight for not communicating since banditry/stealing/murder is very common and penalties for doing so are spirit breaking.2. Its a very time consuming game. This is a double edged sword *no pun inteded* I find myself in the middle with this, If the game could make it exciting from the start to the end game as well, I would be putting much more time into the game. But leveling and many of the RPG elements are useless if you find yourself constantly starving searching for food (this is why you need lots, and lots, and lots, of peasants to farm for you- thus teamwork is the cornerstone of survival)3. Make sure you are on a server with good ping, this is obvious...Don't be that BR guy that joins a Canada server/US server with 300+ ping...you will get rekt unlike most shooters where its the otherway around. Also communcation is delayed on high ping servers for you, so having crisp ping pong conversations makes the game much more enjoyable...as well not watching people rubber band..I recommend this game because the concept is very good, Its worth keeping an eye on and see this becoming a very successful game even if its for a nitchy group of people -like myself-

number of helpful: 8 of 14 people (57%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 1, 2016
												The fact that this game has mixed reviews says more about the people writing the reviews than the game itself. This game is a concept that you have to buy into to properly enjoy it and once you do it can be the most fun, rewarding and challenging game you can play. if you come into this game with a history exclusively of playing CoD and your prerequisite of fun is immediately gaining the title of super-army-soldier-squad-leader-fighter-man where the learning curve last less time than losing your virginity...you probably won't be a fan. Two main complaints I have read are excessive grinding and abusive server GMs. Again, this game is a concept you have to buy in to. If you were one man trying to build a huge keep, it would take you a long time, so yes, going alone in CoD mode #killstreak #lonewolf is going to get very tedious, especially if you have a low attention span. There are options to deal with this, play with friends, or join a collective of players on any of the many volunteer run servers with real RP elements. Which moves to the next complaint, abusive GM's. it's been sad to see how many people I have seen go onto servers (run by volunteers), get kicked for behaving like spoilt children when they break server rules and then come on steam and give the game a bad review, like it's the game devs fault that they couldn't muster the mental wherewithal to do or say anything amounting the more than "lol xd i burn ur howse" and then throwing themselves into the sea in a state of perpetual confusion. Felt a bit like a rant, but it annoys me because this game does deserve a higher positivity in it's reviews. Hats off to the dev team. tl;dr: Great game, for slightly more discerning gamers. patience and imagination required.

												After playing as many hours as I have on this game between my own servers and public ones... this is one of the few games that I regret purchasing. Where to start? The combat is very lacking. The game mechanics are buggy. The leveling progression is grindy and so time consuming as if a mobile app game for phones. The controls are not adjustable. Very few mods exist that improve the overall feel and play. Plenty of bugs and graphical issues if you want to play it on the ultra settings (playing on an 8-core CPU w/ 970GTX yields crap). The music never changes. The learning curve is pretty harsh for any new players or any new player to a server. Good luck getting anywhere on your own if you decide to solo it. I do not recommend this game. Pass on it and look elsewhere.

number of helpful: 10 of 18 people (56%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 14
												This is a single player review only ( for what should be only a multi-player game)Have you ever wondered what it would be like to start a life in the middle ages from scratch as a normal person? The answer to this question is.......it's a grind. An unbelievable, mind numbingly slow, boring, repetitive grind. This is though probably what life was like for Joe Bloggs average peasant 1000 years ago - you work hard, got nowhere then you died (of boredom).The problem for LIF:YO is it's not realistic enough to be a true medieval simulation (thank the gods) but it is realistic enough to be an abhorrent experience as a game.So a few good points:1. Stable, smooth, good FPS even on high settings, no stutters, no CTDs (I have an intel i7 quad core, 8GB RAM and a GTX860M)2. The character generation, while somewhat limited with your options provides a SUPER looking (and sometimes grotesque) character to play that also looks quite good in the game world.3. The building models - all of them - everything I built looks top notch, building material textures are well represented, your first house is a hovel and it really looks the part - it almost smells rotten to look at, wooden fences are rough rickety constructions that look like they will fall over in a strong wind just as you would expect as they were built by an untrained pleb using the most base of tools. I found this part of the game faultless.4. Placement system for the things you build is simple, efficient and intuitively easy to use.5. Skill and stat development is based on doing related stuff rather than just gaining exerience points then allocating skills. Want to improve your strength and become a good miner - shovel dirt around, LOTS of dirt and your strenght goes up. Your intellect does nothing, but you get stronger.6. The number of 'workbenches' you have is enormous compared to many other games - LIF has furnaces, kilns, fires, drying racks, carpenter's benches, mortar & pestle, quern stones, beehives etc etc etc....dozens and dozens of things that each has a specialised use.7. The skill list and learnable 'technologies' is extensive and VERY rewarding when you actually gain access to some key workbench or process . The problem is the suicidal thoughts you are having from all the grinding you did to acquire that access and the knowledge you must grind a lot more to get access to the resource to put in that new bench.Now for the bad, and these are just a few typical issues:1.  Grind, grind, grind and then GRIND some more. It is truly unbelievable how bad the grinding is. I played with my development and speed settings at absolute max and after 25 hrs I have just learned how to operate a kiln and furnace....but I am still a ways off from producing my first iron nail ( I can't even identify iron ore yet) of which I need 45 to build a beehive. I haven't discovered bees yet though so  not sure what to do with an empty beehive!? I also still have no storage containers as they are far to technically advanced for me (it's the nails again you see.....). An example of the grind is branches, a common resource available from every tree. After 20 hours or so you will have an idea of how to build a wicker fence of branches.....you need 10...to get those 10 branches will take you about 1 minute of doing the repetivite 'harvest' action in front of a tree. You can tell your character to 'mass produce' so he/she will harvest branches from this tree until there are none left to take...super.....but you, the human, must sit in your chair and wait for 1 minute because your character cannot multi-task. Rinse repeat for everything. Some things are worse than others - searching for seeds to farm may require 5-6 minutes of rummaging in grassy map tiles to produce .... nothing ..... while you the player just sit and wait. If I 'mass produce' plant fibers from a tile (the character will gather fibers until he/she runs out of stamina) I literally have time to go to the kitchen, make a coffee and come back with a few seconds to spare before my character finishes with an underwhelming 15-20 fibers. GRIND-this is the game's dominant feature.2. The interface is somewhat clunky requiring endless button pushing to access benches and regain control of the camera. The worst of the UI has to be the inventory though which doesn't use a slot system (pleasantly refreshing) however it means your big bag of stuff actually looks like a big bag of stuff full of different things - a confusing mess with things overlapping and sitting on top of other thing so you can't actually see what you've got, add to this the fact that things often don't auto stack means it is a grind to manage it. You have to manually stack things together, manually move them around your bag so you can see what it is and trying to move a tiny item icon often results in you moving the inventroy pop-up window rather than the item you are trying to click on. Realistic but not fun.3. Building anything requires the proper tool and starts with 5-10 second building animation that lays the 'foundation frame' of whatever you want to build. Super. This animation plays even if you don't have the right tool equipped, after which you are told you don't have the right tool, must equip the tool and then sit through the animation again. Do this several hundred times and your will to live fades.4. The general learning curve is steep and requires great detailed information (eg . what temperature does your kiln need to be to fire clay roof tiles?) - you will spend an inordinate amount of time in the Wiki or searching for answers in Steam discussion threads for info that should be included in a pop-up for produced items.5. The game world is not great. It's a small (3kmx3km) map - that's ok in SP, you will spend all your time grinding in your immediate vicinity anyway. The map only has a couple of biomes - shorelines of beaches and lakes, flat sandy places, fine. There is a mountain, unremarkable, but again fine. Then there is forest - 90% of the map is forest with a few clearings and lots of rolling hills. It's a nice enough forest but certainly doesn't have a wow factor when you see it or walk through it. It is incredibly uniform to walk through - some parts are dominated by oak trees, some by elm, some has apple trees mixed in or pines or mulberries - a reasonable variety of trees that somehow all blur together to give you the feeling that this part of the map looks, sounds and feels exactly the same as that other part of the map I walked through 5 minutes ago which was the same as the forest on the other side of the island.6. Enviromental danger is pretty much zero unless you tread on a wild boar. There are no hostile NPC's anywhere aside from extremely rare boars, wolves and bears which don't move around much. You don't need water to live, food is abundant (you can just eat apples forever as far as I know without health issues), the weather and temperature are inconsequential. There is no sense of threat, danger or urgency, just the ever present call of the grind.7. It does some quirky frustrating things. I rage quick yesterday after spending 2 real world hours firing clay tiles in a kiln. I suddenly had a 'remove item' button appear on the kiln as one group of tiles looked like it was almost done - it was hard to see as the progress bar is miniscule - but they were still labelled as unfired clay tiles....take them out and have a look I thought. Nope, still unfired clay tiles in my inventory. Oh well, nearly finished...back in the kiln they go. Progress bar resets to zero meaning they have to be fired again for another 2+ real world hours.The negative list is longer, perhaps much of it can and will be addressed as EA progresses -but at the end of the day it's the grind. The game centres on and is built around grind. The kind of grind you come to mind because it forces you, the human, to sit and wait and wait and wait to accomplish.......squat.

content:
Posted: July 15, 2016
												If you want a game full of bugs, no dev team working on it, and a scam artist of a company, then this game is for you. If you are an informed player and do any research or reviews on games before you buy, then I strongly urge you to pump your breaks on this game. I bought this game with no thought because lots of friends were playing it at the time. The concept seemed fun and amazing and the building system and mechanics for a new player were interesting. Once you put in an hour or so, you start to notice problems right away. These problems don't go away and become only more extreme as you keep playing. Numerous bugs from getting perma stuck, buildings not working, horse getting stuck on a rock, building working but then you can't gather your resources from it; and to top this all off, not a single dev gives two ♥♥♥♥♥ about fixing anything. I've looked back at people playing this game from 2014 and these same bugs are still in the game. I've learned this company has moved on to work on another version of the game (MMO) when they haven’t even polished this turd. What respectable and informed gamer would move from one piece of♥♥♥♥♥♥by the same company to another piece of♥♥♥♥♥♥I don’t know. But more importantly, what kind of developer does this to what I can only see as a fan-base of loyal customers and testers, to only take their money and♥♥♥♥♥♥out this product. Companies such as this are a reason many people fear to back any games or buy any games in development, just so the team can pocket the money and move on.Either way my rant is over. The game is fun, but I would not recommend it due to many short comings. The Cons outweigh the Pros.DO NOT BUY!

content:
Posted: November 18, 2015
												LIF:YO is a well developed sandbox game with many of the elements we have come to enjoy from this genre. It is, as far as I have seen, a more mature game than Rust and is possibly more geared to those that enjoy more in depth crafting/building. The graphics are beautiful and enhance the experience exponentially. The devs are continuing with improving the game with weather and horse drawn carts soon to be added. If you are looking for an adult Minecraft I would say look no further.There are quite a number of negative reviews here about the game being buggy and crashing. I can honestly say I have never experienced this nor has my gf in the 100hrs plus she has logged. One thing I would say is that it is a complicated game and you will most likely have to watch YT or ask on your server how to do things at first, but once you get past these hurdles you will find the result to be very enjoyable.

content:
Posted: January 2
												After my previous review being more of a angry♥♥♥♥♥♥post and then being proven wrong, I have decided to remove it and write a real review.Life is Feudal: Your Own is not a good game. Pros to LiF: YO over other games-Decent Graphics-World playing ability is better than say Rust-Has probably the best combat out of any sort of survival rpg some such game.-Has better crafting than some games in the same genre.-Hilarious(ly bad) voice acting-Except that part where Sean Bean was the voice actor.Cons-Some crafting skills are somewhat lackluster, with a simple menu and a bar not unlike wow, whilst others are mind boggling over complicated like alchemy which requires you to discover what every ingredient does by using it, varies what each does by player so you cant share knowledge, and makes the reagents hard to find unless you turn off grass.-On most servers, skill multipliers make you a "master smith" or what have you in a matter of days, and frankly thats not super fulfilling.-Has the same allure as Rust (15 year olds try out gun boat/big stick diplomacy)-The narrative makes very little sense.-Has worse combat than say warband but tries so hard to have direction combat-Has worse world play and building stuff potential than Wurm, but sort of not really half assedly tries to be like that too.-Sean Bean didn't dieSupposedly the first two features in the cons section will be rectified in the mmo by adding crafting minigames or some such, along with skill multipliers being set to "1", but this isn't the mmo now is it?

number of helpful: 13 of 24 people (54%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 1, 2014
Early Access Review
								Hi folks. Well after many hours watching youtube videos on this game and thinking long and hard about if to buy it or not. I can say it seems so far pretty well worth the investment. Ok this is my pc spec:Intel Core2 Quad Q9550 2.83Ghz5Gb ramWindows 7 64bit proGeforce Gtx650other random tatt bits etc like a hdd as you kinda need one of them lolAnyway does it run on my older pc with low ram etc compared to all these hyper modern gaming pc'sYeah I can safely say it runs sweet. I messed with all the graphics settings inc resolution, lighting, draw distance. I set all the sliders to max and it looked much sweeter. Guess what naff all (noticable) difference to the FPS it just works fine but looks even better.No super lag in dense forests and having to stick to beaches. It runs the same everyehere on the island (great).Do I fall through the floor or walk half way in the floor? Not once.Did it crash? very few times even after 200+ hours its not enough to complain aboutIs it any good? well since I purchased it earlier I aint turned it off and all the game time on record is one long stretch from then till now. It aint that long true but its fun fishing and making basic stuff. Kinda what I wanted from a game. A survival without stupid a** zombies trashing it, in fact just no zombies at all. yay!I am very interested in medieval games so this is why I was willing to try it even with the bad reviews. So far medieval hasn't even came into the game from what I played. I mean no knights in armour and castles. That fact is simply too far away in this basic, almost naked mans mind. All I could think about was food, shelter and wood. The fact that after setting up the basics I can move on to a simple town with walls or something is just a cool goal to look forward to.Tips I found although it may just be damn ovbious to everyone else are. Instead of right clicking none stop and selecting chop tree or take bark etc simply right click the option you want as default then whenever you see a tree or target resource, the left mouse click performs that action saving all the right click context menu fiddling. Of course you need to set it back and forth occasionally but it saves a lot of agro when doing the same set of things over and over. Once I figured that bit I started liking the actual game rather than hating all the right click and find what I wanted over and over.I would say if you have purchased other games that have not lived up to your expectations. As a survival game goes so far this one seems good. No zulu warriors constantly trying to remove your head whilst you build, no zombies groaning away ruining your perfect build. It seems like it is going to be quite fun overall and worth the money.Just as a note. When I set up the game at the start. I set it up as a private game so maybe that is why it is running so smoothly on my computer but hell I dont care if thats the right way to do it. It runs great and I can actually play it peacefully and work out what the hell i'm doing and get to grips with the game.  If you like me want to just get down to some peaceful survival gaming that is what I recommend.Since then and after weeks of playing I now own two servers and they are growing fast.  Still runs fine as I said weeks ago.  Everyone keeps saying how epic the game is and how they "just love it" and how for an alpha its crazy good.  It's better on a server tbh as its meant to played multiplayer.  I don't even want to stop long to update this post cos i've got some digging to do and it wont dig itself....play it and youll know what i mean...its too addictive.....

								The trailers look really great for this game, but its really not fun in any way.  Expect to be wandering around barefoot in the dirt rummaging for sticks and rocks for the first hour.  After that, I completely lost interest.  The crafting system and UI are very clunky and unintuitive, and there really isn't a way to figure the game out short of googling mid-game for crafting recipes.  I didn't try combat at all, or village management, or even build a house.  I made a couple tools, chopped down a couple trees, stacked the logs kinda near one another, and was too exhausted after that to try and have fun. content:
Posted: September 29, 2014
Early Access Review
								I know of course this game is in early Alpha, but so far the game doesn't seem to show much potential in terms of quality of programming. In general /everything/ just feels very clunky and frustration inducing at every stage and there are tonnes of fundamental choices that just make this game feel old before it's even released (sub-par, DX9 graphics for instance). Combat is simply terrible and the engine feels awful. The default gather/skill rates also make the game a complete grindfest where progression feels dull, monotonous, glacially slow and generally unrewarding. Unfortunately I bought this game purely to join in with my friends who were too impatient and bought an unfinished game. LiF just isn't anywhere near finished or good enough currently to have fun with it despite the usual friend shenanigans, and with my group at least - that's saying something. Maybe give it a year and $20 pricetag before buying.

number of helpful: 82 of 160 people (51%) found this review helpful6 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 11, 2015
												I had fun for 60 hours, until the game stopped working completely. The devs don't seem to respond to any questions, and if you read the forums, quite a large number of people cannot play the game. The devs say it's because Steam doesn't download V++ properly, so they take zero responsibility for why their game is not compatible with Steam?? I would have recommended this game, like I said, for the first 60 hours. As a gamer, I frequentely ask myself: when I am on my death bed, will I regret all the years I spent playing games? Well, I'm pretty sure I would like the time I wasted playing Life is Feudal: Your Own. It is very unfortunate because the game was sooo fun. Then one day, my character started freezing like 3 - 4 times an hour and I would have to restart the game. Not a biggie, games can totally be frustrating and lol, hence the title of game.... Then, my character wouldn't load at all. I tried multiple things to fix it. Spent five hours last night trying various ideas from Steam forums, and from the devs themselves. However, if you're like me and not a complete computer software genious, then finding a solution to fixing the game becomes nearly impossible. If you have a computer saavy friend that is available 6 times a day to help you, then definitely take the chance wasting 40 bucks on the game. Although the game is "finished", it still feels very alpha. Every update brings more issues and you will end up frustrated and feeling ripped off. Obviously it's just one opinion and I am sure a lot of people have had more luck getting LIF:YO to play without encountering the MANY issues (graphics, gameplay, server issues, and more) such a large number of gamers have had. SO, if you are ready to invest god knows how many hours into a game, just to have it all be for nothing, then please do try this game.

number of helpful: 23 of 44 people (52%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 2, 2015
Early Access Review
								  Life is Fuedal is unique game that is sort of a hybrid of Minecraft and Mount&Blade. Scavenge, craft tools,fires, forges, armor, weapons, farm, hunt, mine, battle, build houses, and fortresses, and level up in the expansive and interesting skill progessive system. The game has plenty to do and is very entertaining, if a little slow paced.  This game would be one of my favorites of all time, if it wasnt for one thing; you rarely can get it working. You have to host your own server in order to play just by yourself. To get that working it requires most computers to download another program. Then if you get it working, wait about 10 minutes for the game to load(or wait all that time for it to tell you the local server can't be accessed, and doesnt work), and play for hours as you get immersed in the truely great game and have to go to sleep before the sun rises, so you then have to exit. Once you leave you can almost never get back to that server again and have to create your own world again. I've looked through many forums, and threads, and there are a few extremely compliated ways, submitted by users, that you may be able to fix it through downloading other programs and the command prompt. Even then the fixes don't help everyone. This has been a problem since a couple of days after I got the game, and even though multiple patches have gone through none has focused on this crippling problem.  The game it's self is well worth the price, but the inability to actually play properly ruins it. Don't get this game unless your a computer and command prompt wiz. It's a shame such a great game is unavailble to many people who have already purchased this game. Until this problem has been actually addressed and fixed don't buy it.
