number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 30, 2016
												As a server owner/operator I have decided to review LIFEYO from a game operation and maintenance standpoint. As you can see by the hours I have invested in this game, I love it. The critique I give here is out of love for the game and desire for improvements and is not meant to scare players or owners off. Consider it more of a this is what you will face as an owner statement.LIFYO is a grind both in play and in server operation. It is not for the impatient who want to get the best now, player or owner. Over the last year the Developers have made several changes to the menus of the game and the game itself so I will start with some of the menu changes.Be prepared to make several furnaces and forges. Before you are high enough level to make repairkits which need nails you will blow up many in the process. The forge and anvil used to last much longer before needing repair than it does now and in my view not much of an upgrade from the furnace in its current state. The crafting levels to make basic repair kits are too high in my opinion and should be a beginning level skill. Repair kits for a furnace that takes clay water and plant fiber to make, shouldn't need nails, so the devs should make a repair kit specific to those items or again make small repair kits a 0 level skill.Floor lamps being moved to the art crafting skill was silly. While I agree they shouldn't have been in construction, I think they should have been moved to the smelting tools menu and the skill level is too high. But that is just my take on it because I love lamps and hate the dark. The changes to torches were a blessing. Thank you Devs.The changes to raising and lowering items to combat log ladders and dirt ramps over walls. With the monument system the way it is these changes really weren't necessary in my view. They put a damper on creativity. There are not many servers for LIFYO that allow KOS or that have set judgement hours for these things to really matter.The way I see it is in a judgement hour situation if someone is making the effort to cut trees and lug logs to the walls of your claim and you aren't shooting them with every arrow you have thats on you. Same goes for dirt ramps and spirited horses. Yes, I get that most people find the jump factor of a spirited warhorse unrealistic but I find it fun and really not everything in the game has to be grindy and real life. It is a game after all. If someone is taking the time to make a ramp to my walls and im not killing them that is also on me.When I first started running the server there was a setting in the WorldID_1 file that allowed you to limit the height things could be raised. What they should have done is taken paintings and art type things off this setting and left it for the height of logs being floated. This would have solved the problems, but really anyone that didnt like the fact that you could raise and lower logs and float them like that could have fixed the problem by changing the setting in the file rather than complain.Now that the devs got rid of that option to adjust the height of things, beveled stone stairs dont stack right and clay is now nerfed making it harder to put in roads down mountain sides or build in high places. Again putting the damper on creativity in a game no new items are really coming out for.GM Mode. up until this last year gm mode as far as flight went worked great. Now dropping out of the sky in a spot you choose doesnt happen. You get dumped in the ocean. stuck above the horizon or dropped miles from where you flew to. Sometimes you now take fall damage or die from it. As a working Gm this is an annoyance especially when you get to the forest changes in the game. It has also become harder to maintain monuments for those on vacation as you can no longer feed a monument in gm mode. Having to create characters and take over a monument is a pain and eventually when there is more than 64 characters created on the server it starts throwing errors and ghosting messages in the console. I have also experienced fall damage teleporting to players.Mines, I love that they decay on their own. I wish unmonumneted settlements and unbuilt on terriforming as well as dirt piles from mines did to. Mines are killing players when they fight to get in and out of them. They throw you in the air sometimes to death. And they sometimes collapse on you while you are digging them if you aren't reinforcing from the get go.Players sometimes take fall damage getting off their horse. Horses wont go through some gates and you have to get off them and they throw you at unseen obsticles on the map. these can be as simple as a dip in the road or hillside.Decay, I don't know what happened, but it used to be that I could amp up player monuments, turn on decay at a reasonably high rate and the decay would take out terriforming, roads and unmonumented claims without burning down monumented ones. This isnt the case anymore and it doesnt seem to remove terriforming causing owners to either work like crazy fighting fires or work like crazy to undig old claims to get the grass back for new players without wiping the server.Last but not least and the biggest issue in the game is the forest algorithem. In theory this was a very nice idea to promote tree death and new growth to keep us from having to run tree scripts once or twice a month to thin the forest.In my view the tree script was less work and a better solution to the problem than what we have now. New owners beware. 220 days after server creation you will have a massive tree death in the west and south. You will lose almost all your hardwood, mullberry and apple everywhere. The description of how the algorithem works to balance trees to have lush forests with trees of all types is not factual. At 220 days in you will lose your player base because trees will die off at alarming rates leaving the west and south coasts almost barren and your players will go with them unless you edit your cm_forestry_maintenance.xml file changing that 220 rate to something in the thousands. The devs certainaly did not test this algortihem for the LIFYO map. While mass tree death may be good in the mmo on our tiny map it is devastating and a ton of work to restore things every 220 days leaving new players without hardwood to build with.Editing your xml file comes with a new set of problems. Lets say you change 220 to something like 1200. You will still experience tree death at alarming rates in 1200 ingame days If you are a no wipe kind of owner like me, which is another thing players hate, you will be fighting this issue at some point in your game no matter what you do. If you change these rates your forests will become over grown again at some point with no good tree script to help you fight the thickness of things as we were warned not to use the old scripts with the new algorithem.I think the devs need to revamp the trees on the LifYo map again making them all different ages in every map position so death and regrowth are not in huge areas at one time. The Lif Yo Map is too small for barren lands and nobody will build there. Case in point we see little building in the north because of the lack of resources and flat terrain. and speaking of resources it would be nice to have a granite source in the southern region. Lugging 180k granite from the big mountain down to the south for a castle is more than just a grind its a pain. I'm not complaing about the amount of mats needed mind you just the distance with no good rate of carry and no horse drawn carts as promised.(Sorry had to slip that in there somewhere)This is a good game, I personally love the game. I understand that the mmo was the Devs first dream but LIFYO was born and exists first and has a life of its very own and it DESERVES just as much attention as the MMO.While I recommend the game to players and owners alike I just wish the Devs would live up to their promises in the game and stop neglecting YO.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 29, 2015
Early Access Review
								The game is very special. I really mean it. I personally consider it being awesome and extremely addictive, but that's only because I accept the conception of this "ultra-hardcore mmo medieval simulator". Just be aware that it is a totally hardcore game. After approximately 50 hours in-game the only achievements I could boast with are a tiny wooden shack, a forge with an anvil,  a coop with a couple of hens and a small carrot/cabbage farm I managed to build. It took me about 30-40 hours of gameplay to make my first metal tool.  If you think you will just get into the game and start to PVP, experiencing all this “physics based combat”, you may be disappointed, because first few days in-game you will be just messing about in mud, trying to find something edible and not to die of starvation, or playing hide-and-seek with a bear, trying to avoid becoming his meal.However after realizing what the game actually is, you will start building your base..  first time it will be looking like a lonely peasant hideout, but when you get your skills raised, and maybe team up with other dirty peasants, your hideout will slowly, nail-by-nail, board-by-board, brick-by-brick, turn into a picturesque village, and then the village could be very slowly turned into a really impressive fortresses, the entire medieval city with high stone walls, towers, keeps, workshops, warehouses and safe homes.The game allows you to walk through a very rough pass from a dirty peasant to a noble lord, a dangerous thug, a brave warrior, or just whoever you want to become. All these and even more opportunities are featured in LiF, but extremely challenging to achieve.Is it worth to buy the game now you asking? Well, if you had fun playing such games as Ultima Online, Mount&Blade series, Chivalry and so on, you will probably enjoy Life is Feudal. However, you should bear in mind considering to buy it that it’s an early access game. It is pretty rough at its current state, some major features have not been implemented yet, some of them are still not working properly. But even now you could get some fun playing it, if you love the conception.What could I say about its visuals? Well, the game looks decently overall, I mean textures, the light, anti-aliasing and so, but animation really sucks at the moment – characters move pretty awkward, trees are not waving on a wind, animals do not “run” or “walk” they just “relocate themselves”, that looks ridiculous. I have to say that I am not fond of the engine, however if animation will get fixed, then it’s ok. And of course LiF is not about graphics at all, it’s all about its conception and a ton of opportunities it gives to you.

content:
Posted: February 9, 2015
Early Access Review
								This game came recommended by a friend who described as a mixture of minecraft with something else. It does remind me of minecraft: you start with nothing, need to make tools from scratch and after lots of hard work and labour you slowly build your house, furnace and other buildings that you need or want.It is clear the game is not finished yet because many features of the skill tree arent implemented yet. Yet the game as it is now is a solid base. It looks very promising toward the feature. I am curious how they will build in certain aspects into the game but that is for later updates.As stated by others, everything you do can take a lot of effort. It makes it clear this game is most enjoyable when working together with others. If everybody does a part you make faster progress. Building, fighting or hunting, all is better when teamed up with a friend or two.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 18, 2015
												11/20/2015 Edit: All the major game breaking bugs have been fixed. As long as youve got a lot of time on your hands and a friend or too. Youll have fun. Especially now that theres a lot more servers filling up.Edit: So apparently this actually getting attention and I just wanted to make it clear. I love this game. I enjoy it, its a great experience. But its in a bad state right now. Devs said theyve got a hotfix coming out today to fix some of the glitches, I'll edit it again once that comes out, but I will not change the original review, if the game is in a good state, then I will change my recommendation. But theres no need to remove the original, I feel it'll be good to see how far its come from the original release day in a few months.Tl;DR: Dont waste your time. $40 is WAY to much. $24 is still to much. Dont pay more than $15. Wait a few months, after the fixes by all means. Spend $40.Intro.. aaaaand it crashed.First off, let me say I enjoyed this game, in fact I loved it. Was loads of fun, crafting and building was great. But today on November 17th the game was "Released" and its absolutely riddled with bugs. Now that means one of 2 thingsThe testers didnt even test the game for more than 10 minutes at a time because, thats how often youll run into a game breaking bug.The devs were informed about the bugs and simply didnt have the knowledge or just couldnt fix the game before release.The bugs So you might be wondering okay what are these oh so terrible game breaking bugs? Well ones with * (supposedly) only be for those who had the early access game. And there will be a (supposed) fix at the bottom. *The UI messes up to a point where you have to restart the game, sometimes UNINSTALL the game to fix it.If an animal touches water..The server crashes. Yep. Straight up crashes. With servers of 64 people all running around and doing things, someone is gonna try to hunt. Someone is gonna crash the server. *The character model messes up, tears apart and will cover your entire screen. *Sometimes looking at trees will get the stuck on your screen to the point where you cant see anything.The Verdict This game was great before it released, granted the graphics werent great but there were much less bugs. So as it is, dont bother the game is, in my opinion, broken. When devs come out with fixes, sure by all means give it a shot. But never have I seen a more broken game on release. The devs are aware of it being broken. One of them has even apologized to players on the public forum about it. So theyre working on it. The game is currently the 7th top selling on steam, so theres loads of people playing. If you can look past the bugs, turn a blind eye..Youll have a great time. But its because of those bugs that  I DONT RECOMMEND THIS GAME. **The fix: Reinstall. People says it fixes it, others say it doesnt. Sooo take it as you will.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 14, 2016
												I wouldn't consider this a "survival game" (at least not yet). Much of the community for this game is waiting for it's MMO version to release (which is over a year behind schedule) before playing again. Life is Feudal is entertaining if you enjoy gathering resources for crafting and base building. Each of the large bases our small group built across a handful of servers took an average of 2 weeks to build from scratch. Be advised: all servers are currently player-hosted, and in my experience unfortunately, most don't stay around for more than a month. Your mileage may vary. It can be very difficult to know wether or not a server is worth your time investment. You will want decent admins and reasonable rules. Ask questions in their global chat and see if they have a Steam group or other web page that describes their server. Most servers are either PvE or PvP-based. In my opinion, a PvP-based server extends the enjoyment of the game by quite a bit, giving you more to do during or after your base is built. Overall, I think it's a great game, but gets stale after a while since it's completely focused on crafting and player-to-player interaction.

You guys need to really really really test these changes... I cannot keep people joining my YO server because of the constant bugs that keep getting introduced. I will let you know if 1.1.8.1 naturally heals the tree problem on the server or not. If you release untested patches when the MMO comes out you will lose your fan base quick... I really like this game and I am hoping it will be the next big thing for PC gamers... You guys have the power to really get this game to take off.

content:
Posted: September 22, 2014
Early Access Review
								An amazingly addictive and rich game if you are willing to sink a lot of time into it. There are some tedious tasks to be completed if you want to work on any kind of large project, but the payoff is well worth it. Don't expect to have anything crazy immediately and understand that the game is built to be played in large groups. If you play it solo, you may find it difficult to get much anywhere. If I were to sum this game up into something you might be able to relate to, I'd say it has the mechanics of Minecraft, the look of Mount and Blade, and the feel of playing DayZ - but with a far deeper end game. As the game has only recently just gone on sale, it is hard to judge just how the end game will play (because there is so much to do/create/learn in order to get there), but it looks like it may play out like an open ended WvW PvP style game similar to Guildwars 2 or Warhammer - only that everything is driven, created, and destroyed by other players.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 22, 2014
Early Access Review
								Alpha State : 9/22/14This game is a mix of Mount & Blade and Runescape; which is a dream come true. You start off in the middle of nowhere with just clothes in your backpack. Then you must wander around looking for tree branches, flint stones and other stuff to make simple primitive tools to help you gather resources and survive.So far people seem to be cooperating and this game has not turned into a KOS game, which is not the point of the game in my opinion. The small towns made of shacks I found were friendly and welcomed you to join them. There are servers however that will kill you on sight; so just beware when approaching settlements.It takes a long time to accomplish things, so finding a few buddies is necessary to actually build a town. I have not seen any fortesses or stone towns yet, just small shacks and farms.- The game seems to crash when you use a mic near other people for some reason.- It still needs to allow players to add servers to their favorites list so you don't have to search for them again when logging back on.- Way too many server crashes.In its current state I recommend if you are patient and willing to get frustated a little; the potential for this game is immense if the creators keep working hard at it and don't abandon the project.

												Pretty good.However, I think it's still a serious W.I.P. since there are updates coming out like every week.So far so good, however it's got a few minor bugs which might give your gameplay experience a hard time.The graphics are good however, it is has low FPS on top notch PC's too, for some reason - I hope it'll get fixed A.S.A.P.But yeah, it's a good 'Survival' game set in the medieval era, you'll have hard time surviving but once you'll settle down it'll be a great gameplay experience.PS: Most of the players are friendly, unlike other survival games where it's ''Kill-to-loot-to-become-the-best'' ... number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 21, 2014
Early Access Review
								It's... Incredibly intricate, interesting, and promising at the current state of it.  But that doesn't mean that it's something that everyone will find enjoyment in.  Taking survival elements that're comparable to DayZ and Rust with mechanics for needing food or proper medical attention, crafting elements that put Minecraft to shame, terraforming elements and potential building mechanics that seem almost obscenely intricate...  It's promising.  Time consuming would be an understatement of the year though; in a few hours in a single-player game with the skills-gain set to a hundred times the base, it still took me the better part of three hours to get merely the most primative toolset.It seems like one of the best potential games for creating, influencing, and enjoying the fruits of your and you friend's labor I've seen in a long time.  That feeling of actually getting together an actual township, of raising together against a common enemy to defend the little you've scrapped together seems like it will be absolutely incredible.I'll need to wait for some stability updates and some of the other promised features before I find myself playing it too terribly often, with two or three hourly disconnects from servers, but I'm certainly looking forwards to them.

								Right, first impressions. Well, first off, I can tell you that this game  BEAUTIFUL. I mean, at the moment it's terribly optmised (I have a GTX770 but have to set the tree details at very low in order to not lag) but it still looks great.Soundtrack is amazing and suits the game perfectly.One thing though, this game take forever to do anything. You have to be patient, you can't do stuff almost instantly like minecraft, stuff takes a long time. Also, its boring alone. Find someone to play it with whether its a friend or someone you met on a server.Loading is another problem. It takes FOREVER to load into to servers, to be prepared for that. Like I said, this game require serious patience. But the loading screens are pretty nice, so you have something nice to look at.The game needs serious work but it is in alpha, so, ye. It is fun though, but you'd be better off buying it off of {LINK REMOVED} or indiegala for cheaper, or off the devs website. $40 is pretty steep, so is $35 but it's better than $40.I'll update this when I put some more hours in.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 24, 2015
Early Access Review
								First thing you should do when starting a game in Life is Feudal; is to make sure your starting on the right server. Because theres alot of them, and that means theres alot of bad ones. There are more roleplaying servers than not, which is fair enough considering this is by far the best game I've ever played for Roleplayers. Which would be awesome if I was into that. But I am not. I prefer the open world sandbox PVP experience. Life is Feudal provides the most advanced way for me to enjoy that very experience. The best part about it would have to be the fact that - even in Alpha - it pretty much all works. Everything that they have in the game currently, mostly all works without any game breaking bugs or glitchs. There are plenty of those around, sure -  but none that make me want to not come back. This game is slow though. Progression is slow, but rewarding. However if you don't have some sort of goal to work towards in this game then it won't be enjoyable at all. You really do need to be able to envision what you want to create before you begin creating it. And before you even begin that your going to need to do a hell of a lot of basic work just to be able to make your vision a virtual reality. But it is so damn satisfying when you complete each and every little step of your goals. People you meet along the way will either help or hinder you. Either way it provides more fun, the survival aspects of the game are alot less visible in a non-PVP server - hence I do advise you play on a server that has no issues with theft from other players or murder. This IS a sandbox game and those mechanics ARE in it and they mostly all work. Plus this game is ALOT more fun when you make enemies as well as friends. No enemies makes your castle pretty useless anyway. So make sure not to join carebear servers. I might advise to wait a few more months before deciding to buy this game as they are planning on making it some sort of MMO, but...theres a big learning curve to it...so its probably a good idea to get it now just to learn how to start off when its fully released in September.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 21, 2014
Early Access Review
								It's... Incredibly intricate, interesting, and promising at the current state of it.  But that doesn't mean that it's something that everyone will find enjoyment in.  Taking survival elements that're comparable to DayZ and Rust with mechanics for needing food or proper medical attention, crafting elements that put Minecraft to shame, terraforming elements and potential building mechanics that seem almost obscenely intricate...  It's promising.  Time consuming would be an understatement of the year though; in a few hours in a single-player game with the skills-gain set to a hundred times the base, it still took me the better part of three hours to get merely the most primative toolset.It seems like one of the best potential games for creating, influencing, and enjoying the fruits of your and you friend's labor I've seen in a long time.  That feeling of actually getting together an actual township, of raising together against a common enemy to defend the little you've scrapped together seems like it will be absolutely incredible.I'll need to wait for some stability updates and some of the other promised features before I find myself playing it too terribly often, with two or three hourly disconnects from servers, but I'm certainly looking forwards to them.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 22, 2014
Early Access Review
								An amazingly addictive and rich game if you are willing to sink a lot of time into it. There are some tedious tasks to be completed if you want to work on any kind of large project, but the payoff is well worth it. Don't expect to have anything crazy immediately and understand that the game is built to be played in large groups. If you play it solo, you may find it difficult to get much anywhere. If I were to sum this game up into something you might be able to relate to, I'd say it has the mechanics of Minecraft, the look of Mount and Blade, and the feel of playing DayZ - but with a far deeper end game. As the game has only recently just gone on sale, it is hard to judge just how the end game will play (because there is so much to do/create/learn in order to get there), but it looks like it may play out like an open ended WvW PvP style game similar to Guildwars 2 or Warhammer - only that everything is driven, created, and destroyed by other players.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 21, 2014
Early Access Review
								Excellent early-alpha game. Mind the before, EARLY ALPHA. So no, it's not done and it's not perfect.Optimisation is still a long way to go IMO. I like to play my stuff full out on ULTRA but with LiF that's not a good thing to do right now even on my 4.5 GHZ i7 with 8GB Dominator Platinum RAM and a Geforce 780 GTX , I got like 20 FPS running it on full settings. I cut back to around 50% with all of it and it's pretty good now, still not 60 FPS but very playable, the slightly lower FPS doesn't get in the way considering it's not a super action packed game, it's pretty peaceful (so far). Being able to play on max settings with a reasonable FPS would be cool in the future though ! :)It has a few bugs here and there. UI could use some work, it's a little confusing sometimes which button to press, or when I want to craft something and need 2 menu's, i.e. my inventory and the crafting grid so I can drag stuff into my crafting grid, the crafting grid opens overlaying my inentory. So I had to drag drop it next to it in order to see it all, and it does this EVERY time, it doesn't remember me moving it from last time, which is annoying, but these are mere details that could be fixed easily. I did experience a crash here and there, but that's to be expected from Alpha stage.Crashing on this game sucks though, as the world takes forever to load, even on my beast PC when it's installed on an SSD it still takes a good 3 or 4 minutes for the world to load before I can actually enter the server and start playing. I hope that will still change later on so loading times are quicker!Now the reasons why I would recommend it big time! This game is EVERYTHING I've wanted for a long time. It's steep, learning curve wise, so you won't level to level 234353466 within 2 days. It takes time, and patience. Also I've found the community so far to be very friendly and helpful, which is rare nowadays. The game isn't based around fighting (yet) because it literally will take MONTHS to build a castle, and you'll need friends to do it. Without friends, alone, you'll take years. I'm like 6 hours in and just made my little wooden shed covered in clay and a furnace. That's all I've been able to get to, so it's a time investing game.Harvesting and growing crops is also a big part, as you need to eat. You can not farm and just find berries in the forest, but you'll have to go scavenge then. Or you could always go and catch fish, but obviously you'll need the tools to cook it properly. In real life you can't eat a raw fish either, so this is well done.It has mining, and you'll have to do it in order to upgrade♥♥♥♥♥♥as at some point you'll want metal tools instead of primitive ones. Mining is done well but could improve more IMO.To me this game is Minecraft, RUST, Harvest Moon, Mount & Blade and WORM combined. It's really good. I can't wait till it's out a bit longer and clans / groups of players have actually made entire castles and kingdoms and will try to take eachothers.As for the fighting physics I cannot comment as I have not yet been able to craft a sword. Maybe in a week or two ;-)The ammount of content you get for an early access alpha is great, bugs wise it's really not too bad the game is highly playable already. For the quality of alpha releases on STEAM lately where you spend money on totally broken games that never get finished, this is one I can actually recommend for a change.Highly recommended!-Link

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 21, 2014
Early Access Review
								I have played many Early Access and other Alphas.  This is by far the most feature-rich alpha experience I have had.  What is interesting about that, is that it is still considered alpha.  The content plans far exceed what is currently in the game, yet what is currently implemented outshines features found in most other alphas.  This Early Access release has yet to crash.  There are bugs here and there - mostly in the placement of items, or the cursor being slightly off from the item you just clicked - but nothing that has broken the gameplay.The only serious bug that has impacted enjoyment is the inability for me to find games hosted by friends, or for them to find mine.  I can see the list of servers, but it never displays the ones I'm looking for.  This is a known issue as of this writing.  As such, I'm not letting it affect how I feel about this game, but am listing it here so people know beforehand.All in all a great Early Access experience, and a game that will be easy to stick with, or keep coming back to, with each update.

content:
Posted: October 28, 2014
Early Access Review
								At the writing of this review the game has maybe 25% of the content implimented. I'd say maybe even less. Yet despite this My friends an myself have all easily averaged like 50 hours of gameplay and climbing. Especially if you play on the servers with a normal 1x skill progression and limited skill cap, it really makes you work together with otehrs as a community. It is an awesome sandbox game in it's own and it's not even nearly finished yet.I can't wait to see where this is headed!My only concern is the limits of the engine. Choosing Torque 3D over something like say Unity, is an odd developer decision. I've used Torque 3D before. It's not the worst engine ever made. But it has definite limitations compared to many other engines that they could have used.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 3, 2016
												Great game if you have friends that you wish to build a settlement with. - that said even if you play solo on a popular server you can meet great people.game does have a few server lag issues and random crashes on heavily populated servers but overall it's not game breaking.Amazing how picking herbs and flattening ground can take your whole day away but in the end EVERYTHING in your base is there because of your team. can't explain how satisfying that feeling is.  PROS: - great building and ground manipulation system- usually great role playing by real people- great graphics, grass looks amazing.- fun combat- hours of fun per $ spent- easy to learn controlsCONS:- random crashes/ lag (everyone has them not just me)- very grindy game for newcomers ( have seen many people get tired of the game before the game actually begins..)-  would like some more character customisation options.. only 3 hair colours :/

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 15, 2016
												My favorite game ever! Strongly reminiscent of Minecraft, but with much more realistic graphics. Customizable characters! You do lots of crafting, building, hunting, and gathering, like a real primitive society.The only drawback for me is that it takes so much time to do anything. Even minor tasks take 3-5 seconds. I don't have all day, so this is a bit frustrating for me.Also, the world is rather too uniform for an exciting exploration experience. Get around this by playing on one of the online servers, where you can discover settlements and meet the people who have built them.All around, this is definitely my favorite video game.

Overall - a great game if you have the time for it!

								Excellent early-alpha game. Mind the before, EARLY ALPHA. So no, it's not done and it's not perfect.Optimisation is still a long way to go IMO. I like to play my stuff full out on ULTRA but with LiF that's not a good thing to do right now even on my 4.5 GHZ i7 with 8GB Dominator Platinum RAM and a Geforce 780 GTX , I got like 20 FPS running it on full settings. I cut back to around 50% with all of it and it's pretty good now, still not 60 FPS but very playable, the slightly lower FPS doesn't get in the way considering it's not a super action packed game, it's pretty peaceful (so far). Being able to play on max settings with a reasonable FPS would be cool in the future though ! :)It has a few bugs here and there. UI could use some work, it's a little confusing sometimes which button to press, or when I want to craft something and need 2 menu's, i.e. my inventory and the crafting grid so I can drag stuff into my crafting grid, the crafting grid opens overlaying my inentory. So I had to drag drop it next to it in order to see it all, and it does this EVERY time, it doesn't remember me moving it from last time, which is annoying, but these are mere details that could be fixed easily. I did experience a crash here and there, but that's to be expected from Alpha stage.Crashing on this game sucks though, as the world takes forever to load, even on my beast PC when it's installed on an SSD it still takes a good 3 or 4 minutes for the world to load before I can actually enter the server and start playing. I hope that will still change later on so loading times are quicker!Now the reasons why I would recommend it big time! This game is EVERYTHING I've wanted for a long time. It's steep, learning curve wise, so you won't level to level 234353466 within 2 days. It takes time, and patience. Also I've found the community so far to be very friendly and helpful, which is rare nowadays. The game isn't based around fighting (yet) because it literally will take MONTHS to build a castle, and you'll need friends to do it. Without friends, alone, you'll take years. I'm like 6 hours in and just made my little wooden shed covered in clay and a furnace. That's all I've been able to get to, so it's a time investing game.Harvesting and growing crops is also a big part, as you need to eat. You can not farm and just find berries in the forest, but you'll have to go scavenge then. Or you could always go and catch fish, but obviously you'll need the tools to cook it properly. In real life you can't eat a raw fish either, so this is well done.It has mining, and you'll have to do it in order to upgrade♥♥♥♥♥♥as at some point you'll want metal tools instead of primitive ones. Mining is done well but could improve more IMO.To me this game is Minecraft, RUST, Harvest Moon, Mount & Blade and WORM combined. It's really good. I can't wait till it's out a bit longer and clans / groups of players have actually made entire castles and kingdoms and will try to take eachothers.As for the fighting physics I cannot comment as I have not yet been able to craft a sword. Maybe in a week or two ;-)The ammount of content you get for an early access alpha is great, bugs wise it's really not too bad the game is highly playable already. For the quality of alpha releases on STEAM lately where you spend money on totally broken games that never get finished, this is one I can actually recommend for a change.Highly recommended!-Link

												Excellent game!There are still some bugs in the game, but none that are detrimental to gameplay really. Most resolved with a quick relog. Game looks beautiful, especially on high settings, and music is fantastic. Well worth the price if you're into sandbox sims.A thing to note; this is not a game for you if you want to build your kingdom in a day! This game takes time. Depending on server settings, trees and crops can take 24 hrs (real time) to grow, houses can take (up to) 200 logs to build, and being able to carry 3 at a time = long process. Much quicker to play as a group. My suggestion is to get a friend or two, join a server with 3000 skill cap, and learn how to progress down the different trees first. From there you can find a server with a lower skill point cap and split the jobs between guild mates.

												While the game does have its issues, I cannot fathom how someone can 100+ hours on a game and say they didn't enjoy it. There's a lot of review complaining because of slow development. And yet they still have the audacity to not recommend the game. I really don't get it.

								Alright, so it's definetly in development...However, unlike some games out there in the world, this isn't a bad thing. The mining needs a tender loving touch, as it can be buggy alongside some of the terraforming (minor for terraforming, but they're related in terms of changing the world/ground). The game holds a lot of complexity, and the skills are all intertwined to some level. Failure to have a dedicated person in each profession in your growing little village in the woods means- eventually- one of you, if not all of you at some point, may be stunted in development. It holds a lot of potential, and is an enjoyable game is you can tolerate it's developmental status. The community if great, and unlike other games, not -everyone- wants to kill you...

content:
Posted: January 24, 2015
Early Access Review
								First thing you should do when starting a game in Life is Feudal; is to make sure your starting on the right server. Because theres alot of them, and that means theres alot of bad ones. There are more roleplaying servers than not, which is fair enough considering this is by far the best game I've ever played for Roleplayers. Which would be awesome if I was into that. But I am not. I prefer the open world sandbox PVP experience. Life is Feudal provides the most advanced way for me to enjoy that very experience. The best part about it would have to be the fact that - even in Alpha - it pretty much all works. Everything that they have in the game currently, mostly all works without any game breaking bugs or glitchs. There are plenty of those around, sure -  but none that make me want to not come back. This game is slow though. Progression is slow, but rewarding. However if you don't have some sort of goal to work towards in this game then it won't be enjoyable at all. You really do need to be able to envision what you want to create before you begin creating it. And before you even begin that your going to need to do a hell of a lot of basic work just to be able to make your vision a virtual reality. But it is so damn satisfying when you complete each and every little step of your goals. People you meet along the way will either help or hinder you. Either way it provides more fun, the survival aspects of the game are alot less visible in a non-PVP server - hence I do advise you play on a server that has no issues with theft from other players or murder. This IS a sandbox game and those mechanics ARE in it and they mostly all work. Plus this game is ALOT more fun when you make enemies as well as friends. No enemies makes your castle pretty useless anyway. So make sure not to join carebear servers. I might advise to wait a few more months before deciding to buy this game as they are planning on making it some sort of MMO, but...theres a big learning curve to it...so its probably a good idea to get it now just to learn how to start off when its fully released in September.

content:
Posted: February 17, 2016
												Life is hard and life is grindy (Note: i played this game before the release and somehow my progress of hours spent is removed)Life is Feudal has characteristics shared by many realistic sandbox survival games: progression is slow, it’s a challenge to learn, and finally, the endgame is simply a more elaborate and protracted version of the rest of the experience. Maybe in the end your community, if it can somehow survive the raids and attacks from others and finds a way to really communicate and cooperate, evolves into the Renaissance. I know that I will probably never see it, because I don’t have the time or commitment to find out. Life is Feudal  is not enough fun or rewarding in the short term, and the long game is only for true devotees.

												With almost 500 hours online in LiF I can definitely say I've got a feel for the game. If you are looking for a game with in-depth crafting this one is for you. If you are into contruction of houses and settlements then this is the game for you!  You can start with a simple hut and ultimately finish with your very own stone keep and villages.  As of this moment you can only play LiF on a private server but that is due to change after the March 2016 CBT of the MMO.  Once this game goes live as an MMO I can only see it getting better!

												Wurm Online meets Mount & Blade... kind of, but with a lot of bugs/crashes still to be worked out. I think this game does a good job at stopping all the trolls you would normally see on games like Reign of Kings. It creates a hard and soft health/stamina system so that recovery takes much longer.  A troll can still steal, raid, etc, but honestly I have seen ZERO hackers and it is much easier to supress trolls in this style of game. With the right GM's or settlements, this game is solid. So many skills are inter-twinned that you need to have either a lot of people working together actively or a much higher skill cap like some servers have.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 3, 2016
												Life is Feudal is certantly not for everyone.  It is my personal opinion that the majority of players on steam should give this a pass. But then why am I giving this not just a positive review, but an extremely high recommendation? Because I love the living jeebers out of this game. The amount that you can asprie to, the different things you can build, and above all the many different people you meet combine to create a next-level experience. But it is extremely important to find a server that YOU enjoy, that has rules that YOU want to live by. This game is grindy as all hell, but the satisfaction from watching your campfire grow into a fortress through pure hard work is immense. The labour is extreme, the time required enourmous. But the progress is undeniable. As of writing this review, I have approx. over 60 hours in this game. With the help of a group of about 10, we've managed to raise one house and one warhouse, train 5 horses, and fully arm 4 of us. This took us over a week, with players constantly on. There is no denying or mistaking just how hard progress in Life is Feudal is. But if you are the kind of person who enjoys putting in the hours to reach new heights, this game is for you. Make sure you find a nice server with good GMs, a nice group (or even person) willing to teach you, and the patience to see those garden herbs turn into a steel factory. Oh, and keep a sword close by at all times, and watch your back. PVP makes Life is Feudal truly Feudal.

I tried 3 servers, results about the same on each. But hey, YMMV and a really active server might be different experience.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 22
												A detailed review to put aside the confusion and misinformation you may see in other reviews, including many of the negative ones. Firstly, this game gives the impression it is a game not yet truly completed. They appear to be frequently updating the game and patching issues. The reason this is a good thing however, is this is a game already in a state workable enough to be a proper game, and as of yet I have only experienced minor connectivity issues for being on ♥♥♥♥♥♥ DSL internet. I'll be fixing that problem soon enough by getting broadband. Secondly, this game is full release, not some ♥♥♥♥♥♥ 2-bit indie game on early access with a dead community and shady devs. Now, let's get into the real meat of the game, the gameplay. It's worth saying up front this game may have a medieval setting but it's intended to be a sandbox RPG more akin to rust or minecraft rather than a survival combat game like DayZ, or a medieval combat game like mount and blade or chivalry. Most at least basically knowledged people understand this game is a life simulator and while there is a great deal of things you can do in the game it also means you need alot of time to do it. This is a hardcore game for hardcore, dedicated gamers to sink many hours of gameplay into.The crafting system is complex, realistic, and in depth. Not limiting you to just crafting items and buildings, you can change the very shape of the earth itself in the game with the terraforming system. A bit awkward at times, especially when trying to flatten out ground, but the overall mechanics are very easy to use once you know where to get them. RIGHT CLICKING IN THIS GAME IS YOUR FRIEND TRUST MESurvival is done by two things, health and eating. Your health comes back over time, and you can heal with medical equipment later on. Eating is easy, you can find apple trees, pick and eat apples. It's easy enough for the first several hours of gameplay I survived off apples until I could cook myself meat instead. I have only played on RP servers, rather than dedicated PvP servers, but I can safely say that most of the community is smart as long as you play this realistically. Think realistically, RP as a man or woman in the middle ages, play smart, and you'll usually survive. You'll have a better time if you make or play with friends. This game was clearly meant to be played by groups of people working together. You can solo this, but it's putting yourself on hard mode for no reason if you do. Now it's time for the Pros and Cons in my experience.Pros- Expansive and in depth crafting system, simple skill system to go with it.- Hardcore survival with some servers being PK for characters you make. - 64 player servers. - Can run on ultra settings with 60fps relatively smoothly with minimal framerate drop, ultra settings do not kill the game's framerate, and I'm only running an i5 alienware basic.- most of the community is friendly. - Definitely meant to be a social experience, teamwork, and friends make the experience much better.Cons.- High learning curve.- Not intended for "casuals" to be capable of remaining on the top.- Can't be done very well without dedication.- Not optimized to be played by solo players. - AI animals in the game are horribly awful, completely dysfunctional, stupidly OP, and glitch into objects (running in place)

content:
Posted: March 24, 2016
												Awesome game, can be slow to get started, recommend you find a group to have the most fun. The strength of the game is the attempt of realism... You start out with essentially nothing. Go to a tree, break off a branch, get a rock and some weeds.. and poof, you have an axe. You have to work for everything and all though its time consuming, its not difficult. When you get hungry you dont have to take on a wild boar or hope to find a carcass to devour, just dig in the grass for an edible root, or go to an apple tree and pick some apples.You wont be a master at everything in one day. You need to actually choose what direction you want to go. Want to focus on farming? Find a settlement that needs your crops to make armor and have them make you armor... want to be a carpenter? Trade your chests and furniture for weapons etc. You wont need to do meaningless quests, there are none. The game exist as it is, the story is what is actually happening, the bandits you encounter are real people that want your stuff... the alliances you form are with real people, the items you may find actually were made and belonged to some poor soul that met his demise by nature, or another player.There is no "leveling up". You dont need to reach level 25 to ride a horse... Gather some apples, find a wild horse and tame it. Build a stable, mate the horses and sell the offspring. If this all sounds tedious and boring then you probably wont like the game... The only complaint I have is the server wipes... I am eagerly awaiting the MMO with a persistent world because having you progress erased is the one total killer in this game. But still totally worth the money and time.

Early Access Review
								I'm not sure why I'm enjoying this game, but I am, lol.Life is Feudal combines the persistent world antics of DayZ, tech progression of Minecraft, and combat mechanics of Mount & Blade to make a fantastic Medieval MMO.  The skill branches and attribute allocation are the most logical and satisfying I've yet seen in an RPG.  This is a very intelligently-designed game with a lot of potential going for it.Yes, it's in alpha, but runs fairly well.  FPS drops and server crashes notwithstanding, there's plenty to do in the game and lots more on the way.  If persistent worlds are your thing, such as Rust or DayZ, you'll love Life is Feudal. :-D

content:
Posted: September 22, 2014
												::::Re Re Edit:::::So in this game I will point out right off the bat that it is time consuming.  However, It usually is rewarding.  The game for the most part is very realistic and now that it has fixed most of the bugs and performance issues, it can be a real joy to play.  It's a very in-depth game, and Lone wolfing in this game is not advised.  You should have a group of people to play with or find some group of people to live with, as thats the only way you can really get anywhere in this game.   Now on to the good stuff.In LIF:YO you Are able to create a character and customize what you name is, how you look, and what base skills you have.  Once you are done you are spawned onto a large island.  On this island you will either rule with an iron fist as a great ruler, Find fame and glory in the battles fought by rivals, trade goods, farm as a peasent, forge armor and weapons as a blacksmith, and so on.  It's a RPG with a whole lot to do, and everyman is important.  With the way this game is set up people are forced to not resort to KOS.  As every man is again, important.  So not like Minecraft or Rust where you alone or 2 other dudes can become the most feared group on the server who can destroy entire cities.  In this game, if you want to rule a large area with power, you need people.  Or you could be a small group of people that rob or kill random travelers (Bandits)  Really the best way to describe this game is that it's almost your Alt life.  It takes a team of like 15 people to build buildings, and you have to check the harvest all the time and Wars will end for a short time when Harvest time on the server comes around.  I mean this game NOW is pretty great, but it is not worth $40.  I would say if it where on sale or goes down to around $25 or so, then it is worth your money.  I Also wish that they would offer other maps in this version. They don't have to be Much bigger then defult one, just other styles so there is more variaty.::::Old(not important):::: I wanted to edit this.  The game is fun.  Or it can be fun if you find enough people.  However The time it takes to make things can take a very very long time.  It seems things have been shorten because people have made things quicker but I still really wish they would make it easier.  Also flux to make Steel is stupid change that please I really thing it should be mic iron with anouther ore or heat it with much higher heat useing charcole and it uses just a little more iron...  That would be better... Go for my secound idea devs please.  Your game would be so much better and make it where plants don't die out until 4 hours after there growth cycle is done.  I hope the devs read this get this

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 24, 2014
Early Access Review
								I've only played the game for 30 hours at this point so I don't know everything there is to know about this game, especially considering I'm trying to play w/o using outside resources/info. However, I can safely give some of the glaring pro's and con's that I've come across in this game thus far. PROS Very in depth crafting system with a semi-complicated "tech tree"Realism; no storing whole tree logs in a backpack (you gotta lug that♥♥♥♥♥♥back to your house VERY SLOWLY)Early signs of a robust "politics" system       +They're adding the starting of a "land claim system" in the next patch (Dec. 25-26)Graphics are surprisingly beautiful on higher settings and still hold up on the lower settingsCommunity, overall, has been "realistic" so to speak; there are many that want to help and/or include you in their      groups, but some that don't want anything to do with you or try and rob you.       +Coming from other survival games, it was a surprise to not have everyone you meet immediately try and kill youYou change the world! You cut down a tree and its gone, you dig holes in the sides of mountains, your quaint shack in the woods is a sign of your presence on this world. CONS Combat is on the broken side at the moment (but is being slowly fixed); some weapons are weak as balls, some armor makes you a war-godGrinding - you'll be doing a lot of it in this gameQuite difficult to figure out on your own (There are very few in-game explanations on how to do something). It took me an hour to realize that you need to flatten ground to build things (felt like an idiot afterwards)Server stability is relatively okay except some actions are restricted on most servers. Remember the digging in the sides of mountains? Well that can cause severe server lag and long load times for that server, so mining is restricted.Solo play is tedious and requires A LOT more effort to be rewardingThe game isn't fully optimized yet so there are some spots where fps can drop considerably, especially if there are a lot of man-made structures in a small areaI should also mention that this particular game, "Life is Feudal: Your Own" is a sort of "test run" for the larger game "Life is Feudal". The latter will be the former, but on a much grander scale. The servers will be hosted by the developers (they're currently all private) and hold thousands of people, the world will be 49x bigger, and will be complete!It goes without saying that this game is EARLY ACCESS, but there is still quite a lot of fun to be had. If you have a group of friends to play with or are social and can make new friends, this game is a hell of an adventure. If you like to play alone, there's still plenty to do, but be ready to work a lot more for it. Overall the game has a lot of potential, receives frequent enough updates (1-2 a month), has developers that communicate with their fans, and already offers a large amount of things to do in a medieval sandbox environment. Again, I'm only 30 hours in, but I forsee myself spending at least another 200 hours in this game given its current state, especially considering that within my first thirty hours, I've only managed to build a tiny house and plant a carrot.Life is indeed feudal.

Just then a rock whizzed by my head as i look to see what it was another just misses me, and I see a heavily armed woman loading her sling for a point blank shot being that she is now just 20 feet from where I stand. I raise my arms and kneel down in surrender and shout I yeild! she notices my brother dart of into the woods stupidly gives chase, for he has dropped everything on his person and is twice as agile as his persuer. I quickly jump up and sprint west to the coast where I see brother casually gathering sticks a quarter mile north of me. We now have a location set up at the base of the northwest mountain he is a blacksmith and I an alchamist. Once we are settled we are fit to supply nearby towns and villiages steel armor, swords and tools. If bandits don't kill us first.

content:
Posted: November 3, 2016
												As a lifelong roleplaying game fan, playing Life is Feudal: Your Own is an absolute treat. The server I'm on is well populated with people who are totally into the roleplaying aspect. We're all building something amazing together. I absolutely love it.Life is Feudal is played at a different pace to anything I've played before. I wouldn't say it's 'casual', because the depth in this game is astounding, but i'm not always looking over my shoulder or worried my house will be raided when I'm not online.When I first started, I played alone until I had an idea of how the game works, and I didn't get very far. I soon joined a guild and my experience of the game became so much deeper. I highly recommend finding a team of people to work with. You can't learn all the skills necessary to make a successful settlement, but teaming up spreads that skill burden around, you can specialise, choose a profession, kit out your team, go to war...The possibilities are only limited by your imagination.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 12
												Part Wurm, part Rust, ALL fun!  This game is trying hard to be the (non-fantasy) re-invention of Ultima Online, but in 1st-Person, while somehow managing to mitigate the negatives and building upon the strengths.  Some call it a 'medieval simulator'.  Is this game perfect?  No.    Most of the complainers are whining about how this game doesn't walk them through on how to get a fabled Crown of Idiocracy while solo, but instead makes them actually do work, maybe even having to trade with others, in order to accomplish anything of value.Is it easy?  Definitely No!  This is NOTHING like your child's World of Wizards101.Life IS Feudal.  Some people just can't handle difficulty.  Can you?

content:
Posted: October 11, 2014
Early Access Review
AMAZING!Okay the gameplay itself is astonishing. I have never played something of this quality. BUT.There are a few things that needs tweaking (YES I KNOW ITS ALPHA) but the thing is there is actually no way of creating a storage box of any sort in the early stages it requires mid level skills and well playing on my own server with 10X xp was a huge grind and the LiF server is going to be set at 1.As for the landscape WOW  it is pretty damn beautiful. The sun shining through the leaves of the trees flickering on the water and the waves wash up onto the sand, I have spent half of my gameplay admiring the mere beauty of the environment. Except for 2 occasions where I felt like I was going to fall to the pits of hell because of a few glitch spots in the landscape.Some sounds are also a little bit out of sink but obviously will be fixed later. Also some crafting times and skill times take a lot longer than they should I mean even opening a sack takes a good 3 seconds when you just want to look in it an be done.Overall the game is fantastic, obviously needs a few tweaks here and there as there are a few bugs that need attention for the next update. The realism is quite refreshing and fun in a gritty this is taking too long type of way. In comparrison to Minecraft and Rust once all of the features are active and even before release I believe this game is going to blow them out of the water. It is already coming close to it.For those of you borderline wanting to buy and not sure because you don't want something that is going to be a dead end, the quality of this game and the work that has already gone into it assures me that the devs are going all the way.10 / 10

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 19, 2016
												Life is Feudal appeals to some things I've longed for in a video game. Community.You're tasked to thrive in this land with others, but the journey is arduous to go alone, whilst you can do so by all means, the game does reward you for partying up due to the skill cap system, to go into depth;Every server has a unique skillcap and XP rates, some servers have a relatively low skill cap to ensure you can't do every single thing alone, and therefore endorse co operative play, some let you do it all alone and increase the XP rates so it doesn't take as long.I'm currently playing on a server with a 1600 skill cap, which therefore allows me to learn my core skills to survive, but I can't do everything, so I joined a few people early on.  Our small guild of 4 people consists of a hunter, a chef, a mason, and myself the architect, whilst these may be our 4 core strengths we can all help each other in other ways, I can forge whilst the chef can't, he can bowcraft whilst I can't.The only time I've ever felt such community was back in the days of the DayZ Arma 2 mod, before the KoS craze, it was amazing, I believe now LiF has filled this void.I intend to be a full time architect on this server, and to help build for those who can't, and get paid in resources I can't otherwise acquire. All you need to do, is thrive, and you can help others to do so too.The PvP is also greatly thought out but rarely sought after, Judgment Hour comes every 3 days in my experience, where all of your gear is not protected by your claim, but is free to be looted by all, this creates an intense purge like feeling that both scares me and makes me laugh. People tend to go crazy around this time to get anything they can get their paws on, I've not yet died at all in my (current) 42 hours of gameplay, but all you lose is the gear you hold, and some XP (More xp if you have negative karma)After 42 hours, I've only just obtained all my core skills, this can be percieved as a pro or a con, to me, It's both, I enjoy the everlasting gameplay but at times some skills are just a drag to learn.My point is, after 42 hours, I've barely scratched the surface of what the game has to offer, and I'm already loving it.I'm learning architecture, yet I've barely built anything amaazing so far, what happens when I learn Bowcraft, warfare engineering, herbology, Masonry, Carpentry? I can get endless gameplay out of something like this.TL;DR 10/10

content:
Posted: October 5, 2014
Early Access Review
								I was a little wary buying into the this alpha, especially when I had never heard of the studio that makes it before. However, since buying it and joining a community that hosts a server, I have had an absolute blast. At the moment, this game is what you make of it. If you buy it and play on your own, things will be painstakingly slow and lonely. If you join an active server, or better yet an active community that hosts one, you will have fun learning to play and get into hilarious scenarios with other players.For those who say this game is like DayZ, they are right in the fact that you need to eat in both games, you can be killed in both games, and you can play both games in first or third person. Those are pretty much the only simliarities.This game is focused on cooperative gameplay as opposed to every man for themself. If you like working with others, even if it is to raise an army to raid another castle, then this game is for you.So far I give it a 9/10. (not a 10/10 because of alpha bugs, crashed etc). I will review this game again in a few months.

Early Access Review
								Fantastic game for the reality side of things especially the length of time needed to earn the experience needed. This game is definitely a GROUP/COMMUNITY game as you will need to progress through the experience levels of each role in order to achieve your goals.Your role, no matter what it is will be critical for each other player in different stages throughout.More maps would be advantageous, as would a map creator.Life is Feudal: Your Won is, by no means, a short game. It will take a lot of time and effort put into the game in order to achieve.While there is no actual end game, the playability is dependant on those you play with and the time that every player puts in to it.Suggestion for this game is to have a group of people that will put in a certain amount of time on a specific day or days and to keep to the plan.Graphics are fantastic and the framerate is stable.Personally i love this game.

number of helpful: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 30, 2015
Early Access Review
								There's something soothing and peaceful about the crafting and farming side of this game.  You have very few storage options, and none at the start, so you have to get into the habit of only taking from the land what you absolutely need.  You can optimise the trees you find by paying attention to their quality, and before long you're surrounded only by big, green, healthy looking trees.  As long as you start somewhere close to water, clay, and game you'll have what you need to start your little settlement.The game needs a lot of work and refinement still, and has a lot of minor but recurring issues with its GUI setup, but once you get the hang of that it's pretty smooth sailing.  There are some issues with very basic things (like once you close the pop-up message box, which you almost have to, you can only exit the game by commanding the server to stop with "quit();" and then ending the process for the client through Task Manager) and there are problems with you needing to know so much about how to start before you do.  Tunnels are never clear exactly how they'll end up when you start them (so you might not be able to get out without the /stuck command), you need granite to make castle walls (the only way to level up your architecture skill--besides half making the walls with just the rocks then destroying them--which you need to build the keeps) which is only found in the centre mountain.All that said, it is a very enjoyable game once you get going with it.  After you make your  first full volley of mistakes, anyway, and are willing to start again in hopes that you'll make fewer of them and actually be able to get somewhere.Also a boar took over my little village briefly, and knocked me out and stood around like a smug little ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ every time he saw me until I could take his ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥out.  Now my little village has bacon.

number of helpful: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 13, 2015
Early Access Review
								This is not an easy game to pick up.  The learning curve is steep and success requires the investment of significant amounts of time.  That said, it's game with immense scope and huge potential.  Once you master the basics of how to "level" your character, the gameplay is quite enjoyable.The game is not finished.  I hope to see significant polish put on before official release.  That said, unlike many other games that need not only polish but also substantive content, the majority of the game already exists and it is solid.The emphasis is on realism: Say you have a animal hide and you need to dry it (one step in the tanning process).  You've built a drying rack (not too hard) and are ready to start.  There is no simple button with a quick progress bar: it takes an hour of actual time for the hide to dry.  Nevertheless, there are occasionally activities and game mechanics that need polish and certainly don't feel realistic (Hares drop chicken meat when killed?  Did I miss something in biology?).  Overall, the core is solid.

content:
Posted: October 25, 2014
Early Access Review
								After reading alot of negative reviews of people who have played the game less than 10 hours i'd formost like to start with the negatives. So bear with me there aren't many considering this game is early access.Negatives-1. Yes its buggy.  (not sure about people saying about constant client crashes i've played 50 hours and had 3 client crashes)2. Yes alot of functions aren't implimented (early access)3. The game play can seem like a grind, its slow moving, and the game definately requires team work.4. Wolves are OP, no way if i whack a wolf with a sword 10 times is it getting up to still take bites out of me.5. Graphics seem to take a toll on my machine, i can run battlefield 4 on ultra with no graphic lag but for some reason if i don't drop the graphics in this game i get alot of graphic lag.POSITIVES!1. Time investment is rewarding - I spent hours cutting logs, while my friend spent hours making nails and metal bands, while another friend spent hours flattening a large area.  At the end we sat on a hill over looking our 50-60 palisade wall settlement and said... f**k yeah.2. A Sense of community.  I am a GM on an aussie server called "Aussie LIF" open trade between settlements gives u a sense of diplomacy!3. Team work is fantastic, no better feeling!4. Even though incomplete i've sunk 50 hours into this game, i know not much compared to some people but i feel like i could play it for days on end if i had the time5. Going for a stroll, take a walk, smell the roses so to speak.  No other game of this genre that i have played has created the amazing beauitful atmosphere i have seen in this game.6. DANGER - A real sense of danger, will a wolf be sitting behind a tree, will you stumble across a band of thieves and murderers while you travel to a neighbouring village.7. If you want realism, if you want a hard core drop into medieval time period this game is for you!  If you want a mine craft hit a block 6 times with a pick and u have stone sadly i think you should probably stick to mine craft because this isn't for you.

content:
Posted: January 9
Product received for free
												TL;DR: This game is awesome but wait for the MMO or pick this up on a sale just to end your thirst for the MMO.----My first touch for LiF was from the MMO closed beta. Despite the crashes and occasional bugs, I enjoyed the game very much because everything is time consuming, hard and can sometimes feel like work but the feeling of accomplishement is way beyond explanation. Life truly is feudal. During my MMO closed beta period, I joined this guild X and after the Beta MMO went down for maintenance, we still decided to play together and my guild leader gave me free copy of LiF: YO so that I can join them.Life is Feudal: Your Own is very similar to LiF: MMO but since the servers in "Your Own" are hosted by other players, the rules can get messy and the leveling rating of skills can be adjusted so high that this game becomes way easier and this is a relief for those who do not like to work really hard to get nails or rope just to build a chicken coop or a well. Also the map of Your Own is a lot smaller and it's always the same island unlike the MMO that is one big world.Despite the fact that the world in "Your Own" is just boring and small, everything else in this game is nearly perfect. You can and have to do everything from scratch. It took me nearly 3 hours just to even out the ground so that I can build my first shack and basic stuff like Kiln so that I can make charcoal from billets that I saw out of the wood that I cut down myself with the axe that I made myself from the rocks, sticks and plant fiber I gathered with my bare hands. This game is very deep and like everything in this game, even explaining it is very time consuming.The thing about this game is that it's hard and complicated and it can be frustrating to start build a camp, a town or a fort when you realize that you really need to do so much work to be able to do the simpliest stuff. The thing here is that every player should find other players to play with and divide the jobs between players and actually play as a feudal community.  This game also has PvP and you can attack who ever you want where ever you want but if you die, you lose everything.Personally I enjoy this game vastly, I hope that the developers just make the MMO version for this game stable enough since it's pretty much perfect in all the other ways when it comes to open world sandbox game but I will wait for the MMO to come out and take it more seriously and use "Your Own" as an learning tool for incoming challenges.

number of helpful: 5 of 9 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 24, 2014
Early Access Review
								Since I've finished the tech tree I feel I can write a fair review.The game is basically Peasant Simulator, and it's a really good concept with a lot of promise. There's a few things it does really well and others it doesn't but luckily the bad ones are easy enough to fix.Let's get the bad out of the way:* This is currently a grind because of how many loading bars you have to suffer through to do pretty much everything. This however is a placeholder until they get minigames added for each task. It's singlehandedly the most unappealing thing this game has. Even if you get iron and steel tools they don't speed the process up, they're just lighter so you can carry more, which is a disappointment and I feel should change and add a multiplier to. Skills don't speed up the loading bars either, just unlocks things.* There is no property protection system at time of writing. If someone finds your stuff buried under a pile of dirt, well then tough luck. There are a lot of ways to get around this though, like creating multiple mule characters or being clever with how you hide items.* It's an grind until you are able to make metal things. But after that things get really exciting because your options explode.* No guilds or land claim systems at time of writing either.* The whole skill system and UI is uninuitive, and the wiki is pretty much required reading for your first time doing anything. There is no tutorial beyond an F1 menu that tells you what your hotkeys are.* Performance is pretty unoptimised but that's to be expected of a game in alpha.Now for the good:* Mount and Blade style combat. Need I say more? It's also got a Total War sort of formation system as well, provided you have enough people.* It has a focus on team-based gaming since the skill cap means that no one person can solo everything. There's a huge focus on trading and co-operation. If you play this alone it is going to take you forever to do things. More people means everything goes faster and has a set role to specialise in. I really enjoy that sort of aspect. Fun scales with how many people you're with.* Even in this early state the range of things you can build is absolutely fantastic. Towns actually have a meaning and a function and grow naturally with what you're doing. I've had my small shack with my friend grow into a respectable-looking trading outpost and that's just with two people.* The community is generally friendly. Just keep a respectful distance from their settlements when you talk to them or otherwise they may interperet you as smashing and grabbing, which is a fair assumption.* The building and placement of items is really incredibly freeform. Options to finely raise, translate and rotate pretty much everything. It really allow for a fluid and natural looking set of buildings.* It's got a really solid terrain deformation system. If you throw a bunch of dirt or rocks on a hill they will slide down the hill and raise it as it would in real life. It's quite impressive - never a seen a game deal with soil and gravel as fluid-like before. It also remembers properties of substrate. Fertility of soil, what kind of ground material you're dumping etc.As it stands, LiF has a ton of potential, and if you're playing with a medium-large group (4-5+) you're gonna have fun.  I don't regret paying 30$ for it when it was on sale elsewhere. Really looking forward to how they grow the features and fix the issues.

number of helpful: 6 of 11 people (55%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 11
												For a bit of background my ideal game would be a full PvP, full loot medieval mmo. Similar to the MUD's of old!This is a tricky one. On one hand I love the concept of the game and it does seem to run quite smoothly however it is extremely long winded which in itself isn't necessarily a bad thing but a new player should be aware of it.Crafting isn't overly intuitive and requries frequent looking at the wiki. Combat was straight forward enough, similar to Mount and Blade or War of Roses (although not as good). The biggest let down for me is the claimed areas which are fully protected against looting or damage, some servers have a judegement period but this just seems like a cheap cop out. This has always been the way though has it not? Crafters and PvE'rs wanting safe zones but the PvP'rs after at least the chance to wage war. This also prevents terraforming in the zone as well which is frustrating when people claim the zones next to an essential resource. I understand that this is done to prevent griefing when players are offline but it would be better if you could hire NPC's to guard your land or had player areas that would respawn after a certain time unless they were taken out my seige weapons and claimed by another group.Overall I wish Steam allowed for a maybe reccomendation. The keep building is fun and coming across other player settlements is great and it really is pretty free with what you can build and where. I think it has a solid base game here and will grow into something good albiet not what I am after. For people who like building their own bases, limited PvP and a free roam area it is a good bit (assuming you have plenty of time).For me though the search for a full loot mmo continues.
